CalorieCalculator.metadataDescription: Free calorie calculator using Mifflin-St Jeor formula. Calculate your BMR, TDEE, and daily calories for weight loss, maintenance, or muscle gain based on your activity level.
CalorieCalculator.caloriesPerDay: calories per day to maintain weight
CalorieCalculator.mifflinStJeor: Mifflin-St Jeor Equation (most accurate for modern populations)

activity.sedentaryDesc: Little or no exercise, desk job
activity.veryActiveDesc: Very hard exercise, physical job, training 2x/day

whatIs.title: What are Calories?
whatIs.content:
A calorie is a unit of energy. In nutrition, we typically refer to kilocalories (kcal), often simply called "calories." When we say a food has 100 calories, we mean it provides 100 kcal of energy.

Your body uses calories for:
  • Basal metabolism: Breathing, blood circulation, cell repair (60-75% of daily calories)
  • Physical activity: Walking, exercising, moving (15-30%)
  • Digesting food: Processing nutrients (10%)

Key concepts:
  • BMR (Basal Metabolic Rate): Calories burned at complete rest
  • TDEE (Total Daily Energy Expenditure): Total calories burned per day including activity
  • Calorie deficit: Eating fewer calories than you burn (weight loss)
  • Calorie surplus: Eating more calories than you burn (weight gain)

howToCalculate.title: How to Calculate Daily Calories
howToCalculate.content:
The Mifflin-St Jeor Equation

This calculator uses the Mifflin-St Jeor equation, developed in 1990 and considered the most accurate formula for estimating BMR in modern populations.

For men:
BMR = (10 × weight in kg) + (6.25 × height in cm) - (5 × age) + 5

For women:
BMR = (10 × weight in kg) + (6.25 × height in cm) - (5 × age) - 161

Then multiply by activity factor:
TDEE = BMR × Activity Multiplier

Example: A 30-year-old man, 80 kg, 180 cm, moderately active:
BMR = (10 × 80) + (6.25 × 180) - (5 × 30) + 5 = 800 + 1125 - 150 + 5 = 1,780 kcal
TDEE = 1,780 × 1.55 = 2,759 kcal/day

activityLevelsSection.title: Understanding Activity Levels
activityLevelsSection.content:
Choose your activity level honestly for accurate results:

LevelMultiplierDescription
Sedentary1.2Desk job, no exercise, minimal walking
Lightly Active1.375Light exercise 1-3 days/week, some walking
Moderately Active1.55Moderate exercise 3-5 days/week, active job
Very Active1.725Hard exercise 6-7 days/week, physically demanding job
Extremely Active1.9Professional athlete, training twice daily

Tips:
  • Most office workers are Sedentary or Lightly Active
  • If unsure, choose a lower activity level
  • Exercise doesn't burn as many calories as people think

weightGoals.title: Calories for Weight Loss or Gain
weightGoals.content:
The Science of Weight Change

1 pound (0.45 kg) of body fat = approximately 3,500 calories
1 kilogram of body fat = approximately 7,700 calories

For weight loss:
  • Mild (0.25 kg/week): Eat 250 calories below TDEE
  • Moderate (0.5 kg/week): Eat 500 calories below TDEE ✓ Recommended
  • Aggressive (1 kg/week): Eat 1000 calories below TDEE

For weight gain (muscle building):
  • Lean bulk: Eat 200-300 calories above TDEE
  • Standard bulk: Eat 500 calories above TDEE

Important guidelines:
  • Never eat below 1,200 calories (women) or 1,500 calories (men)
  • Aim for 0.5-1% of body weight loss per week maximum
  • Protein intake: 1.6-2.2g per kg of body weight for muscle preservation
  • Combine calorie deficit with strength training to preserve muscle

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: How accurate is this calorie calculator?
faq.a1: The Mifflin-St Jeor equation is considered the most accurate for estimating BMR, with about 10% margin of error. For precise tracking, monitor your weight for 2-4 weeks and adjust calories based on actual results.
faq.q2: Should I eat back exercise calories?
faq.a2: It depends. If you chose a higher activity level that includes your exercise, no. If you selected Sedentary and do separate workouts, eat back about 50% of exercise calories (fitness trackers often overestimate).
faq.q3: Why am I not losing weight despite eating at a deficit?
faq.a3: Common reasons include: underestimating food intake (not weighing portions), overestimating exercise calories, water retention (especially for women), or metabolism adaptation. Try tracking food more accurately for 2 weeks.
faq.q4: What's the minimum calories I should eat?
faq.a4: Generally, women shouldn't go below 1,200 calories and men below 1,500 calories without medical supervision. Very low calorie diets can cause muscle loss, nutrient deficiencies, and metabolic slowdown.
faq.q5: How do I know which activity level to choose?
faq.a5: Be honest and conservative. Most people overestimate their activity. If you have a desk job and exercise 3x/week for 30-45 minutes, you're likely Lightly Active, not Moderately Active.
faq.q6: Does metabolism slow down with age?
faq.a6: Yes, BMR decreases about 1-2% per decade after age 20, primarily due to loss of muscle mass. However, staying active and doing strength training can minimize this decline significantly.

LoanCalculator.title: Loan Calculator
LoanCalculator.subtitle: Calculate monthly payments, total interest, and view amortization schedule
LoanCalculator.metadataTitle: Loan Calculator - Monthly Payment & Amortization Schedule | MyCalcOnline
LoanCalculator.metadataDescription: Free loan calculator with amortization table. Calculate monthly payments, total interest, and total cost for mortgages, auto loans, and personal loans.

whatIs.title: What is a Loan?
whatIs.content:
A loan is a sum of money borrowed from a lender (typically a bank or financial institution) that must be repaid over time, usually with interest. The borrower agrees to repay the principal (original amount) plus interest (the cost of borrowing) according to a schedule.

Key loan terms:
  • Principal: The original amount borrowed
  • Interest Rate: The percentage charged for borrowing (APR - Annual Percentage Rate)
  • Term: The length of time to repay the loan
  • Monthly Payment: Fixed amount paid each month
  • Amortization: The schedule showing how each payment is split between principal and interest

How interest works: In the early years of a loan, most of your payment goes toward interest. As the loan matures, more goes toward principal. This is why paying extra early can significantly reduce total interest paid.

howToCalculate.title: How to Calculate Loan Payments
howToCalculate.content:
The Monthly Payment Formula

Monthly payments are calculated using this formula:

M = P × [r(1+r)ⁿ] / [(1+r)ⁿ - 1]

Where:
  • M = Monthly payment
  • P = Principal (loan amount)
  • r = Monthly interest rate (annual rate ÷ 12)
  • n = Total number of payments (years × 12)

Example: $200,000 loan at 6% for 30 years
  • P = $200,000
  • r = 0.06 ÷ 12 = 0.005
  • n = 30 × 12 = 360 payments

M = $200,000 × [0.005(1.005)³⁶⁰] / [(1.005)³⁶⁰ - 1]
M = $200,000 × [0.005 × 6.022] / [6.022 - 1]
M = $200,000 × 0.00599 = $1,199.10/month

Total paid: $1,199.10 × 360 = $431,676
Total interest: $431,676 - $200,000 = $231,676

loanTypes.title: Types of Loans
loanTypes.content:
Common loan types and typical terms:

Loan TypeTypical TermInterest RateSecured?
Mortgage15-30 years3-8%Yes (home)
Auto Loan3-7 years4-10%Yes (car)
Personal Loan1-7 years6-36%No
Student Loan10-25 years4-8%No
Home Equity5-30 years4-10%Yes (home)

Fixed vs Variable Rate:
  • Fixed: Interest rate stays the same for the entire loan term (predictable payments)
  • Variable: Interest rate can change based on market conditions (potentially lower initially, but risky)

tips.title: Tips to Save Money on Loans
tips.content:
Strategies to reduce your total loan cost:

1. Improve Your Credit Score
  • Pay bills on time
  • Reduce credit utilization below 30%
  • Don't open many new accounts at once
  • A higher score = lower interest rates

2. Make Extra Payments
  • Even $50-100 extra/month makes a big difference
  • Apply extra to principal, not future payments
  • Consider biweekly payments (26 half-payments = 13 full payments/year)

3. Choose a Shorter Term
  • 15-year mortgage vs 30-year saves huge interest
  • Higher monthly payment but much less total interest

4. Refinance When Rates Drop
  • If rates drop 0.5-1%, consider refinancing
  • Factor in closing costs before deciding

5. Make a Larger Down Payment
  • More down payment = smaller loan = less interest
  • 20% down on mortgage avoids PMI

Example: On a $200,000 mortgage at 6%:
30 years: $1,199/mo, total interest $231,676
15 years: $1,688/mo, total interest $103,788
Savings: $127,888!

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What is an amortization schedule?
faq.a1: An amortization schedule is a table showing each loan payment broken down into principal and interest. Early payments are mostly interest; later payments are mostly principal. It helps you understand exactly where your money goes each month.
faq.q2: Should I choose a 15-year or 30-year mortgage?
faq.a2: A 15-year mortgage has higher monthly payments but saves massive interest (often 50%+ less total interest). Choose 30-year if you need lower payments for cash flow, but consider paying extra when possible. Only commit to what you can comfortably afford.
faq.q3: What is APR vs interest rate?
faq.a3: The interest rate is the basic cost of borrowing. APR (Annual Percentage Rate) includes the interest rate PLUS fees, points, and other costs, giving you the true cost of the loan. Always compare APRs when shopping for loans.
faq.q4: How does paying extra principal work?
faq.a4: When you pay extra toward principal, you reduce the balance faster, which means less interest accrues. Even small extra payments early in the loan can save thousands. Always specify that extra payments go to principal, not toward future payments.
faq.q5: What credit score do I need for a loan?
faq.a5: Requirements vary: Mortgages typically need 620+ (740+ for best rates). Auto loans: 660+. Personal loans: 580-700+. Higher scores get significantly better rates. Check your score before applying and work on improving it if needed.
faq.q6: Can I pay off my loan early?
faq.a6: Usually yes, but check for prepayment penalties first. Some loans charge a fee for early payoff, especially in the first few years. Mortgages and auto loans typically allow early payoff without penalty. Always read your loan agreement.

DiscountCalculator.title: Discount Calculator
DiscountCalculator.subtitle: Calculate sale prices, savings, and discount percentages instantly
DiscountCalculator.metadataTitle: Discount Calculator - Sale Price & Savings Calculator | MyCalcOnline
DiscountCalculator.metadataDescription: Free discount calculator to find sale prices, calculate savings, and determine discount percentages. Perfect for shopping, comparing deals, and calculating markdowns.
DiscountCalculator.calculationType: What do you want to calculate?

whatIs.title: What is a Discount?
whatIs.content:
A discount is a reduction in the regular price of a product or service. Discounts are expressed as a percentage (%) off the original price and are commonly used in retail, e-commerce, and services to attract customers.

Types of discounts:
  • Percentage off: Most common type (e.g., 20% off)
  • Fixed amount off: Dollar amount reduction (e.g., $10 off)
  • Buy One Get One (BOGO): Effectively 50% off when buying two
  • Bulk/quantity discounts: Lower price per unit for larger quantities
  • Seasonal sales: Black Friday, holiday sales, clearance events

Why stores offer discounts:
  • Clear old inventory
  • Attract new customers
  • Increase sales volume
  • Compete with other retailers
  • Reward loyal customers

howToCalculate.title: How to Calculate Discounts
howToCalculate.content:
The Discount Formula

To find the sale price:
Sale Price = Original Price × (1 - Discount% ÷ 100)

Or step by step:
Savings = Original Price × (Discount% ÷ 100)
Sale Price = Original Price - Savings

Example: $80 item with 25% off
Savings = $80 × 0.25 = $20
Sale Price = $80 - $20 = $60

To find the discount percentage:
Discount% = ((Original - Sale) ÷ Original) × 100

Example: Item was $50, now $35
Discount% = (($50 - $35) ÷ $50) × 100 = 30%

To find the original price:
Original Price = Sale Price ÷ (1 - Discount% ÷ 100)

Example: Item is $60 after 20% off
Original = $60 ÷ 0.80 = $75

examples.title: Common Discount Examples
examples.content:
Quick reference for common discounts:

Original10% off20% off25% off50% off
$20$18$16$15$10
$50$45$40$37.50$25
$100$90$80$75$50
$200$180$160$150$100

Mental math tips:
  • 10% off: Move decimal one place left ($50 → $5 savings)
  • 20% off: Find 10%, then double it
  • 25% off: Divide by 4 ($100 ÷ 4 = $25 savings)
  • 50% off: Simply halve the price
  • 33% off: Divide by 3 for savings

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: How do I calculate multiple discounts (stackable discounts)?
faq.a1: Apply discounts sequentially, not by adding percentages. For 20% off then 10% off: First apply 20% ($100 → $80), then apply 10% to the new price ($80 → $72). This is NOT the same as 30% off ($70).
faq.q2: Is 50% off the same as buy one get one free (BOGO)?
faq.a2: BOGO is effectively 50% off only if you buy exactly 2 items. If you only need one item, BOGO isn't a deal at all. Always calculate the per-item cost to compare deals.
faq.q3: How do I know if a discount is a good deal?
faq.a3: Compare the sale price to: 1) Prices at other stores, 2) The item's usual price (not just the 'original' price shown), 3) Whether you actually need the item. A 70% discount on something you don't need is still 100% wasted money.
faq.q4: What's the difference between 'percent off' and 'percent of'?
faq.a4: '30% off' means you pay 70% of the original price. '30% of' means you pay only 30% (a 70% discount). They're opposites! '30% off $100' = $70. '30% of $100' = $30.
faq.q5: How do I calculate discount from a coupon code?
faq.a5: If the coupon is a percentage (e.g., SAVE20), apply it the same way: Original × (100% - 20%) = Final price. If it's a dollar amount (e.g., $10 OFF), simply subtract it from the total before or after other discounts as specified.
faq.q6: Why do stores use prices like $9.99 instead of $10?
faq.a6: This is called 'psychological pricing' or 'charm pricing.' Our brains tend to focus on the first digit, so $9.99 feels significantly cheaper than $10.00, even though it's only 1 cent less. Be aware of this when calculating true savings!

SalaryCalculator.title: Salary Calculator
SalaryCalculator.subtitle: Convert your salary between hourly, daily, weekly, monthly, and yearly amounts
SalaryCalculator.metadataTitle: Salary Calculator - Convert Hourly to Yearly & More | MyCalcOnline
SalaryCalculator.metadataDescription: Free salary calculator to convert between hourly, daily, weekly, biweekly, monthly, and yearly pay. Calculate your true income with customizable work hours.
SalaryCalculator.summaryText: At {hourly}/hour, working {hoursPerWeek} hours per week for {weeksPerYear} weeks, your annual salary is {yearly}.

whatIs.title: What is a Salary?
whatIs.content:
A salary is the regular payment an employee receives from an employer in exchange for work performed. Unlike hourly wages, salaries are typically expressed as an annual amount and paid on a regular schedule (weekly, biweekly, or monthly).

Key salary concepts:
  • Gross salary: Total earnings before any deductions
  • Net salary: Take-home pay after taxes and deductions
  • Base salary: Fixed compensation excluding bonuses and benefits
  • Total compensation: Base salary plus all benefits, bonuses, and perks

Salary vs Hourly Wages:
AspectSalaryHourly
PaymentFixed annual amountPer hour worked
OvertimeOften exemptUsually paid 1.5x
PredictabilityConsistent paychecksVariable income
BenefitsUsually includedOften limited

howToCalculate.title: How to Convert Salary Between Periods
howToCalculate.content:
Salary Conversion Formulas

Standard assumptions: 40 hours/week, 52 weeks/year, 2,080 work hours/year

Hourly to Yearly:
Yearly = Hourly × Hours per Week × 52
Example: $25/hour × 40 hours × 52 weeks = $52,000/year

Yearly to Hourly:
Hourly = Yearly ÷ (Hours per Week × 52)
Example: $60,000 ÷ 2,080 hours = $28.85/hour

Monthly to Yearly:
Yearly = Monthly × 12
Example: $5,000/month × 12 = $60,000/year

Weekly to Yearly:
Yearly = Weekly × 52
Example: $1,000/week × 52 = $52,000/year

Biweekly to Yearly:
Yearly = Biweekly × 26
Example: $2,000/biweekly × 26 = $52,000/year

Quick Reference Table:
HourlyWeeklyMonthlyYearly
$15$600$2,600$31,200
$20$800$3,467$41,600
$25$1,000$4,333$52,000
$30$1,200$5,200$62,400
$40$1,600$6,933$83,200
$50$2,000$8,667$104,000

salaryTypes.title: Types of Compensation
salaryTypes.content:
Understanding different types of pay:

1. Base Salary
  • Fixed annual compensation
  • Paid regardless of hours worked
  • Foundation of total compensation

2. Hourly Wage
  • Paid per hour worked
  • Usually eligible for overtime pay
  • Common in retail, hospitality, manufacturing

3. Commission
  • Percentage of sales made
  • Common in sales roles
  • Can be commission-only or base + commission

4. Bonuses
  • Performance bonus: Based on individual/company performance
  • Signing bonus: One-time payment when joining
  • Annual bonus: Year-end bonus based on performance
  • Spot bonus: Recognition for exceptional work

5. Benefits (Part of Total Compensation)
  • Health insurance ($5,000-$20,000+ value)
  • Retirement contributions (3-6% match)
  • Paid time off (2-4 weeks)
  • Stock options/equity
  • Education reimbursement

Tip: When comparing job offers, always look at total compensation, not just base salary!

tips.title: Tips for Salary Negotiations
tips.content:
Maximize your earning potential:

1. Research Before Negotiating
  • Use sites like Glassdoor, LinkedIn, PayScale
  • Know the market rate for your role and location
  • Consider company size and industry

2. Know Your Worth
  • List your achievements and quantify impact
  • Document skills that set you apart
  • Prepare specific examples of value you've added

3. Consider Total Compensation
  • Base salary is just one component
  • Benefits can be worth 20-40% of salary
  • Remote work saves commute costs
  • PTO and flexibility have real value

4. Timing Matters
  • Best time: After a job offer, before accepting
  • Annual reviews are opportunities
  • After major achievements
  • When taking on new responsibilities

5. Negotiation Tactics
  • Let them make the first offer
  • Use silence as a tool
  • Get offers in writing
  • Be prepared to walk away
  • Negotiate more than just salary

What to Negotiate Beyond Salary:
  • Signing bonus
  • Remote work days
  • Vacation time
  • Title/role scope
  • Professional development budget
  • Review timeline for raise

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: How do I calculate my hourly rate from annual salary?
faq.a1: Divide your annual salary by the total hours worked per year. For a standard 40-hour week over 52 weeks, that's 2,080 hours. Example: $52,000 ÷ 2,080 = $25/hour. If you work fewer weeks (due to unpaid time off), use your actual weeks worked.
faq.q2: Is a $50,000 salary good?
faq.a2: It depends on your location, industry, and experience level. $50,000 is above the US median household income but may be low in high cost-of-living areas like San Francisco or New York. Always compare to local cost of living and industry standards.
faq.q3: How much is $20 an hour annually?
faq.a3: At $20/hour working 40 hours per week for 52 weeks, you'd earn $41,600 per year before taxes. If you work fewer weeks (accounting for unpaid vacation), your annual total would be lower.
faq.q4: Should I take a higher hourly rate or salary?
faq.a4: Consider: Salaried positions often include benefits, job security, and consistent income. Hourly positions may offer overtime pay and flexibility. Calculate total compensation including benefits, overtime potential, and job security before deciding.
faq.q5: What's the difference between gross and net salary?
faq.a5: Gross salary is your total earnings before deductions. Net salary (take-home pay) is what you receive after taxes, insurance, retirement contributions, and other deductions. Net is typically 70-80% of gross, depending on your tax bracket and deductions.
faq.q6: How often are most people paid?
faq.a6: In the US, biweekly (every 2 weeks, 26 paychecks/year) is most common, followed by weekly and semi-monthly (twice per month, 24 paychecks/year). Monthly payment is more common in other countries and for executives.

RoiCalculator.title: ROI Calculator
RoiCalculator.subtitle: Calculate Return on Investment, annualized returns, and investment performance
RoiCalculator.metadataTitle: ROI Calculator - Return on Investment Calculator | MyCalcOnline
RoiCalculator.metadataDescription: Free ROI calculator to measure investment performance. Calculate return on investment, annualized ROI, profit/loss, and compare investment opportunities.
RoiCalculator.selectMode: What would you like to calculate?

whatIs.title: What is ROI (Return on Investment)?
whatIs.content:
Return on Investment (ROI) is a financial metric used to evaluate the profitability of an investment. It measures how much profit or loss an investment generates relative to its cost.

ROI is expressed as a percentage:
  • Positive ROI: Your investment gained value (profit)
  • Negative ROI: Your investment lost value (loss)
  • 0% ROI: You broke even (no gain or loss)

Why ROI Matters:
Use CaseDescription
Compare investmentsChoose between stocks, bonds, real estate
Business decisionsEvaluate marketing campaigns, equipment purchases
Personal financeTrack retirement savings, portfolio performance
Project evaluationDetermine if a project is worth pursuing

howToCalculate.title: How to Calculate ROI
howToCalculate.content:
Basic ROI Formula:
ROI = ((Final Value - Initial Investment) / Initial Investment) × 100
Example Calculation:
You invested $10,000 in stocks and sold for $12,500
  • Gain = $12,500 - $10,000 = $2,500
  • ROI = ($2,500 / $10,000) × 100 = 25%

Annualized ROI Formula:
For investments held over multiple years:
Annualized ROI = ((Final Value / Initial Investment)^(1/years) - 1) × 100
Example:
$10,000 grows to $15,000 over 3 years:
  • Annualized ROI = ((15000/10000)^(1/3) - 1) × 100
  • Annualized ROI = (1.5^0.333 - 1) × 100 = 14.47% per year

Quick Reference:
InvestedFinal ValueROI
$1,000$1,10010%
$5,000$6,25025%
$10,000$15,00050%
$25,000$50,000100%

examples.title: ROI Examples by Investment Type
examples.content:
1. Stock Market Investment
  • Buy 100 shares at $50 = $5,000 invested
  • Sell at $65 per share = $6,500
  • ROI = ($1,500 / $5,000) × 100 = 30%

2. Real Estate Investment
  • Purchase price: $200,000
  • Renovation costs: $25,000
  • Total investment: $225,000
  • Sold for: $280,000
  • ROI = ($55,000 / $225,000) × 100 = 24.4%

3. Business Marketing Campaign
  • Campaign cost: $2,000
  • Revenue generated: $8,000
  • ROI = ($6,000 / $2,000) × 100 = 300%

4. Education Investment
  • Degree cost: $40,000
  • Salary increase: $15,000/year
  • Payback period: 2.67 years
  • 10-year ROI: ($150,000 / $40,000) × 100 = 275%

Average Historical Returns:
Investment TypeAvg. Annual Return
S&P 500 (stocks)10-12%
Real Estate8-12%
Bonds4-6%
Savings Account0.5-5%

tips.title: Tips for Maximizing ROI
tips.content:
Investment Strategies:

1. Diversify Your Portfolio
  • Spread investments across asset classes
  • Reduces risk without sacrificing returns
  • Include stocks, bonds, real estate, etc.

2. Consider Time Horizon
  • Longer investments can weather volatility
  • Short-term: focus on liquidity
  • Long-term: focus on growth

3. Account for All Costs
  • Trading fees and commissions
  • Management fees (expense ratios)
  • Taxes on gains
  • Inflation erosion

4. Use Compound Returns
  • Reinvest dividends and interest
  • Let gains compound over time
  • $10,000 at 10% = $25,937 in 10 years

5. Compare Apples to Apples
  • Use annualized ROI for different time periods
  • Consider risk-adjusted returns
  • Factor in liquidity needs

ROI Limitations:
  • Doesn't account for risk
  • Ignores time value of money (use NPV for that)
  • Can be manipulated by changing timeframes
  • Doesn't consider opportunity cost

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What is a good ROI?
faq.a1: A 'good' ROI depends on the investment type and risk. For stocks, 10-12% annually is historically average. Real estate typically targets 8-12%. Any ROI above the risk-free rate (Treasury bonds ~4-5%) while accounting for risk can be considered good.
faq.q2: How do I calculate ROI with multiple investments?
faq.a2: Calculate ROI for each investment separately, then find the weighted average based on the amount invested in each. Alternatively, sum all initial investments and final values, then calculate total ROI.
faq.q3: What's the difference between ROI and ROE?
faq.a3: ROI (Return on Investment) measures the return on any investment relative to its cost. ROE (Return on Equity) specifically measures a company's profit relative to shareholders' equity. ROE is used for analyzing company performance, while ROI is more general.
faq.q4: Should I include dividends in ROI calculation?
faq.a4: Yes! Total return includes both capital gains (price appreciation) and income (dividends/interest). Add all dividends received to your final value before calculating ROI for an accurate picture of your investment's performance.
faq.q5: How do taxes affect ROI?
faq.a5: Taxes reduce your actual returns. Long-term capital gains (held >1 year) are taxed at lower rates (0-20%) than short-term gains (ordinary income rates up to 37%). Always calculate after-tax ROI for realistic expectations.
faq.q6: What is annualized ROI and why does it matter?
faq.a6: Annualized ROI converts any return into an equivalent yearly rate, allowing fair comparison between investments held for different periods. A 50% return over 5 years (8.45% annualized) is different from 50% over 1 year.

MortgageCalculator.title: Mortgage Calculator
MortgageCalculator.subtitle: Calculate monthly mortgage payments, including taxes, insurance, and PMI
MortgageCalculator.metadataTitle: Mortgage Calculator - Monthly Payment & Amortization | MyCalcOnline
MortgageCalculator.metadataDescription: Free mortgage calculator to estimate monthly payments, total interest, and payoffs. Include property taxes, homeowners insurance, and PMI for accurate results.

whatIs.title: What is a Mortgage?
whatIs.content:
A mortgage is a loan specifically used to purchase real estate. The property itself serves as collateral, meaning if you fail to make payments, the lender can take possession of the home through foreclosure.

Key Components of a Mortgage:
  • Principal: The amount of money you borrowed.
  • Interest: The cost of borrowing the money, expressed as an annual percentage.
  • Escrow: A managed account that holds funds for property taxes and homeowners insurance.
  • PMI: Insurance that protects the lender if you have a down payment less than 20%.

howToCalculate.title: How to Calculate Mortgage Payments
howToCalculate.content:
The Standard Mortgage Formula:

M = P [ i(1 + i)^n ] / [ (1 + i)^n – 1 ]

Where:
  • M: Total monthly principal and interest payment
  • P: Principal loan amount
  • i: Monthly interest rate (Annual Rate / 12)
  • n: Total number of months in the loan term

Note: This formula only calculates Principal and Interest. To get your true monthly cost, you must add Property Taxes, Homeowners Insurance, and HOA fees divided by 12.

buyingTips.title: Mortgage Buying Tips
buyingTips.content:
1. Save for a 20% Down Payment: This allows you to avoid Private Mortgage Insurance (PMI), which can save you hundreds of dollars every month.

2. Check Your Credit Score: Higher credit scores unlock lower interest rates, which can save you tens of thousands of dollars over the life of the loan.

3. Get Pre-Approved: Before house hunting, get a pre-approval letter from a lender to know exactly what you can afford and show sellers you are a serious buyer.

4. Compare Loan Terms: A 15-year mortgage usually has a lower interest rate and much lower total interest cost than a 30-year mortgage, but the monthly payments are significantly higher.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What is the 28/36 rule?
faq.a1: The 28/36 rule is a guide for how much debt you can afford. It suggests that your mortgage payment should not exceed 28% of your gross monthly income, and your total debt payments (including car loans, student loans, etc.) should not exceed 36%.
faq.q2: How much down payment do I really need?
faq.a2: While 20% is ideal to avoid PMI, many programs allow as little as 3% or 3.5% (FHA loans). VA loans for veterans can even be 0% down. However, a smaller down payment usually means a higher interest rate and monthly payment.
faq.q3: Can I pay off my mortgage early?
faq.a3: Most modern mortgages allow for extra principal payments without penalty. Paying even a small amount extra each month can shave years off your loan and save you a massive amount in interest.
faq.q4: What is an Adjustable-Rate Mortgage (ARM)?
faq.a4: An ARM has an interest rate that stays fixed for a few years and then adjusts periodically based on market indices. They often start with lower rates than fixed mortgages but carry the risk of payments increasing significantly in the future.
faq.q5: What does a mortgage payment include?
faq.a5: Most mortgage payments include PITI: Principal, Interest, Taxes, and Insurance. It may also include HOA (Homeowners Association) fees and PMI if applicable.

SpeedCalculator.title: Speed, Distance, Time Calculator
SpeedCalculator.subtitle: Solve for speed, distance, or time using the average speed formula
SpeedCalculator.metadataTitle: Speed Distance Time Calculator - Average Speed Formula | MyCalcOnline
SpeedCalculator.metadataDescription: Free online speed distance time calculator. Calculate average speed, total distance, or elapsed time. Supports km/h, mph, m/s, and various time formats.
SpeedCalculator.selectMode: What do you want to calculate?

whatIs.title: What is the Speed, Distance, Time Formula?
whatIs.content:
The relationship between speed, distance, and time is one of the most fundamental concepts in physics and everyday life. It describes how fast an object is moving and how long it takes to travel a certain path.

Key Definitions:
  • Speed (v): The rate at which an object covers distance.
  • Distance (d): The total length of the path traveled between two points.
  • Time (t): The duration during which the motion occurs.

howToCalculate.title: How to Calculate Speed, Distance, and Time
howToCalculate.content:
All three calculations are based on the same basic formula, which can be rearranged depending on what you need to find:

1. To Calculate Speed: Divide distance by time.
Speed = Distance / Time

2. To Calculate Distance: Multiply speed by time.
Distance = Speed × Time

3. To Calculate Time: Divide distance by speed.
Time = Distance / Speed

Remember the Triangle Trick: Imagine a triangle with 'D' at the top and 'S' and 'T' at the bottom. To find one, cover it with your hand and look at the position of the others.

examples.title: Real-World Examples
examples.ex1: Road Trip: If you drive 120 miles in 2 hours, your average speed is 120 / 2 = 60 mph.
examples.ex2: Running: If you run at a speed of 10 km/h for 30 minutes (0.5 hours), you will cover 10 × 0.5 = 5 km.
examples.ex3: Sprints: If an athlete runs 100 meters at a speed of 10 m/s, it will take them 100 / 10 = 10 seconds.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What is the difference between speed and velocity?
faq.a1: Speed is a scalar quantity, meaning it only has magnitude (how fast). Velocity is a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude and direction. For most everyday calculations, 'speed' is the term used.
faq.q2: What are the most common units for speed?
faq.a2: The most common units are kilometers per hour (km/h) used in most of the world, and miles per hour (mph) used in the US and UK. In scientific contexts, meters per second (m/s) is the standard SI unit.
faq.q3: How do I handle different units in a calculation?
faq.a3: It is crucial to ensure your units are consistent. For example, if your speed is in km/h, your time should be in hours to find distance in kilometers. Our calculator handles these conversions for you automatically.
faq.q4: What is average speed?
faq.a4: Average speed is the total distance traveled divided by the total time taken. It doesn't account for stops or changes in speed during the journey.
faq.q5: How fast is 1 knot?
faq.a5: One knot is equal to one nautical mile per hour, which is approximately 1.852 km/h or 1.151 mph. It is primarily used in maritime and aerial navigation.

AverageCalculator.title: Average Calculator
AverageCalculator.subtitle: Calculate mean, median, and mode for any set of numbers
AverageCalculator.metadataTitle: Average Calculator - Mean, Median, Mode Calculator | MyCalcOnline
AverageCalculator.metadataDescription: Free average calculator to find mean, median, and mode. Enter your numbers and get instant statistics including sum, count, range, and more.
AverageCalculator.placeholder: Type a number or paste list
AverageCalculator.tip: Tip: Paste comma-separated values (e.g., 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) or press Enter after each number

whatIs.title: What is an Average?
whatIs.content:
An average is a single number that represents a typical value from a set of data. There are several types of averages, each useful in different situations:

Types of Averages:
TypeDefinitionBest For
MeanSum of all values divided by countGeneral purposes, evenly distributed data
MedianMiddle value when sortedData with outliers, income statistics
ModeMost frequently occurring valueCategorical data, finding common values

Example:
For the numbers: 2, 3, 3, 5, 7
  • Mean: (2+3+3+5+7) ÷ 5 = 4
  • Median: 3 (middle value)
  • Mode: 3 (appears twice)

howToCalculate.title: How to Calculate Mean, Median, and Mode
howToCalculate.content:
1. Mean (Arithmetic Average)
Mean = Sum of all values ÷ Number of values
Example: Numbers: 10, 15, 20, 25, 30
Mean = (10 + 15 + 20 + 25 + 30) ÷ 5 = 100 ÷ 5 = 20

2. Median
Steps to find the median:
  1. Sort the numbers from smallest to largest
  2. If odd count: middle number is the median
  3. If even count: average of two middle numbers

Example (Odd): 3, 7, 9 → Median = 7
Example (Even): 3, 7, 9, 12 → Median = (7 + 9) ÷ 2 = 8

3. Mode
The mode is the value that appears most frequently.
Example: 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 4, 5 → Mode = 4 (appears 3 times)
Note: A dataset can have no mode, one mode, or multiple modes (bimodal, multimodal).

differences.title: When to Use Mean vs Median vs Mode
differences.content:
Choose the right average for your data:

Use MEAN when:
  • Data is evenly distributed (no extreme outliers)
  • You need the mathematical center
  • Calculating grades, scores, prices

Use MEDIAN when:
  • Data has outliers or is skewed
  • Analyzing income or house prices
  • You want the "typical" value

Use MODE when:
  • Data is categorical (colors, choices)
  • Finding the most popular option
  • Identifying common patterns

Example: Salary Data
Salaries: $40K, $45K, $50K, $55K, $500K
  • Mean: $138K (skewed by the $500K)
  • Median: $50K (better represents typical salary)
In this case, median is more useful because one outlier dramatically affects the mean.

Quick Reference:
SituationBest Average
Test scoresMean
House pricesMedian
Favorite colorMode
Income statisticsMedian
TemperatureMean

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What if my data has no mode?
faq.a1: If all values appear the same number of times, there is no mode. For example, in the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}, each number appears once, so there's no mode. This is common with continuous data like heights or weights.
faq.q2: Can there be multiple modes?
faq.a2: Yes! A dataset can be bimodal (two modes), trimodal (three modes), or multimodal (more than three). For example, in {1, 1, 2, 3, 3}, both 1 and 3 are modes because they each appear twice.
faq.q3: How does the median handle even numbers of values?
faq.a3: When there's an even count, the median is the average of the two middle values. For {2, 4, 6, 8}, the median is (4 + 6) ÷ 2 = 5, even though 5 isn't in the original data.
faq.q4: What is the geometric mean?
faq.a4: The geometric mean is the nth root of the product of n numbers. It's useful for averaging rates of change, percentages, or growth rates. For example, growth rates of 10%, 20%, and 30% have a geometric mean of about 19.7%.
faq.q5: Why is median often used for income?
faq.a5: Income data typically has a few very high earners that skew the mean upward. The median better represents what a 'typical' person earns. If Bill Gates walks into a bar, the mean income skyrockets, but the median barely changes.
faq.q6: What is range in statistics?
faq.a6: Range is the difference between the maximum and minimum values in a dataset. It's a simple measure of spread. For {3, 7, 12, 15}, the range is 15 - 3 = 12. While easy to calculate, it's sensitive to outliers.

UnitConverter.title: Unit Converter
UnitConverter.subtitle: Convert between length, weight, and temperature units instantly
UnitConverter.metadataTitle: Unit Converter - Length, Weight, Temperature | MyCalcOnline
UnitConverter.metadataDescription: Free unit converter for length, weight, and temperature. Convert meters to feet, kg to pounds, Celsius to Fahrenheit and more. Fast and accurate.

whatIs.title: What is Unit Conversion?
whatIs.content:
Unit conversion is the process of converting a measurement from one unit to another equivalent unit in a different system. This is essential for international communication, science, engineering, and everyday life.

Why Unit Conversion Matters:
  • International Trade: Different countries use different measurement systems
  • Science & Engineering: Precise conversions are critical for accuracy
  • Travel: Understanding local units (miles vs kilometers, Fahrenheit vs Celsius)
  • Cooking: Converting between metric and imperial measurements

Common Measurement Systems:
SystemUsed InCommon Units
Metric (SI)Most of the worldmeter, kilogram, Celsius
ImperialUS, UK (partially)foot, pound, Fahrenheit

howTo.title: How to Convert Units
howTo.content:
Length Conversion Formula:
Result = Value × (From Unit to Base) ÷ (To Unit to Base)
Example: Convert 5 feet to meters
  • 5 feet × 0.3048 (feet to meters) = 1.524 meters

Weight Conversion Formula:
Result = Value × (From Unit to Grams) ÷ (To Unit to Grams)
Example: Convert 10 pounds to kilograms
  • 10 lb × 453.592 (lb to grams) = 4535.92 grams
  • 4535.92 ÷ 1000 (grams to kg) = 4.536 kg

Temperature Conversion Formulas:
Celsius to Fahrenheit:
°F = (°C × 9/5) + 32
Example: 25°C × 9/5 + 32 = 77°F

Fahrenheit to Celsius:
°C = (°F - 32) × 5/9
Example: (98.6°F - 32) × 5/9 = 37°C

Celsius to Kelvin:
K = °C + 273.15
Example: 25°C + 273.15 = 298.15K

common.title: Common Conversions
common.content:
Length Conversions:
FromToConversion
1 inchCentimeters2.54 cm
1 footMeters0.3048 m
1 yardMeters0.9144 m
1 mileKilometers1.609 km

Weight Conversions:
FromToConversion
1 ounceGrams28.35 g
1 poundKilograms0.454 kg
1 kilogramPounds2.205 lb

Temperature Conversions:
CelsiusFahrenheitKelvin
0°C32°F273.15K
25°C77°F298.15K
37°C98.6°F310.15K
100°C212°F373.15K

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: Why are there different measurement systems?
faq.a1: Historical reasons! The metric system was developed in France in the 1790s for scientific standardization. The imperial system evolved from British measurements. Most countries adopted metric, but the US still primarily uses imperial units.
faq.q2: How many feet are in a meter?
faq.a2: 1 meter = 3.28084 feet (approximately 3.28 feet). Conversely, 1 foot = 0.3048 meters exactly. This is one of the most common conversions people need.
faq.q3: Is 1 kg equal to 2 pounds?
faq.a3: Close, but not exactly. 1 kilogram = 2.20462 pounds. So 1 kg is slightly more than 2 lbs. For rough estimates, you can use the 2:1 ratio, but for precision, use 2.2.
faq.q4: What temperature is 0°F in Celsius?
faq.a4: 0°F = -17.78°C. This is quite cold! Fahrenheit's zero was originally based on the freezing point of brine (salt water), while Celsius uses the freezing point of pure water (0°C = 32°F).
faq.q5: How do I remember Celsius to Fahrenheit conversion?
faq.a5: Remember: Double the Celsius, subtract 10%, add 32. Example: 20°C → 20×2=40, minus 4 (10%)=36, plus 32=68°F. The exact answer is 68°F, so this method works well for estimates!
faq.q6: Why does the US use imperial units?
faq.a6: The US almost adopted the metric system in the 1790s, but the ship carrying the metric standards was captured by pirates! Later, switching became expensive and culturally resistant. Industries like construction standardized on imperial, making change difficult.

TemperatureConverter.metadataTitle: Temperature Converter - Celsius, Fahrenheit, Kelvin | MyCalcOnline
TemperatureConverter.metadataDescription: Convert temperatures between Celsius, Fahrenheit, and Kelvin instantly. Free online temperature converter with formulas and reference temperatures.
TemperatureConverter.title: Temperature Converter
TemperatureConverter.subtitle: Convert between Celsius, Fahrenheit, and Kelvin with ease

whatIs.title: What is Temperature?
whatIs.content:
Temperature is a measure of how hot or cold something is, representing the average kinetic energy of particles in a substance. Different temperature scales have been developed for various purposes:

  • Celsius (°C) - Used worldwide, based on water's freezing (0°C) and boiling (100°C) points at standard pressure
  • Fahrenheit (°F) - Primarily used in the United States, with water freezing at 32°F and boiling at 212°F
  • Kelvin (K) - The SI unit used in science, starting at absolute zero (0 K = -273.15°C), the lowest possible temperature

Understanding temperature conversions is essential for cooking, weather forecasting, scientific research, and international travel.

howTo.title: How to Convert Temperature
howTo.content:
Celsius to Fahrenheit

Formula: °F = °C × 9/5 + 32

Example: 25°C = (25 × 9/5) + 32 = 45 + 32 = 77°F

Fahrenheit to Celsius

Formula: °C = (°F - 32) × 5/9

Example: 77°F = (77 - 32) × 5/9 = 45 × 5/9 = 25°C

Celsius to Kelvin

Formula: K = °C + 273.15

Example: 25°C = 25 + 273.15 = 298.15 K

Kelvin to Celsius

Formula: °C = K - 273.15

Example: 298.15 K = 298.15 - 273.15 = 25°C

Quick Mental Math for C to F

Double the Celsius, subtract 10%, add 32:

20°C → 20×2=40, minus 4=36, plus 32=68°F ✓

references.title: Reference Temperatures
references.content:
DescriptionCelsiusFahrenheitKelvin
Absolute Zero-273.15°C-459.67°F0 K
Water Freezes0°C32°F273.15 K
Room Temperature20°C68°F293.15 K
Body Temperature37°C98.6°F310.15 K
Water Boils100°C212°F373.15 K
Baking Temperature175°C350°F448.15 K

Weather Reference Points

  • -40°C = -40°F - The only point where Celsius and Fahrenheit are equal!
  • 0°C = 32°F - Freezing point of water
  • 10°C = 50°F - Cool autumn day
  • 20°C = 68°F - Comfortable room temperature
  • 30°C = 86°F - Hot summer day
  • 40°C = 104°F - Extreme heat warning

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What temperature are Celsius and Fahrenheit equal?
faq.a1: Celsius and Fahrenheit are equal at -40 degrees (-40°C = -40°F). This is the only temperature where both scales show the same numerical value.
faq.q2: Why does the US use Fahrenheit instead of Celsius?
faq.a2: Historical reasons! The US adopted Fahrenheit before the metric system was standardized. While most countries switched to Celsius in the 20th century, the US maintained Fahrenheit due to established infrastructure, cultural preference, and the high cost of switching.
faq.q3: What is absolute zero?
faq.a3: Absolute zero is 0 Kelvin (-273.15°C or -459.67°F), the lowest possible temperature. At this point, molecular motion theoretically stops completely. It's impossible to reach in practice, but scientists have gotten within billionths of a degree.
faq.q4: Is 0°C the same as 0°F?
faq.a4: No! 0°C = 32°F (water's freezing point). 0°F = -17.78°C, which is much colder. Fahrenheit's zero was based on the freezing point of brine (salt water), not pure water.
faq.q5: How do I quickly estimate Celsius to Fahrenheit?
faq.a5: Quick method: Double the Celsius, subtract 10%, add 32. Example: 20°C → 40 - 4 + 32 = 68°F. This gives you a close approximation perfect for everyday use!
faq.q6: Why doesn't Kelvin use the degree symbol?
faq.a6: Kelvin is an absolute temperature scale (starting at absolute zero), not a relative one like Celsius or Fahrenheit. Because it measures absolute thermodynamic temperature, it's written as 'K' without the degree symbol (°).

GPACalculator.metadataTitle: GPA Calculator - Calculate Your Grade Point Average | MyCalcOnline
GPACalculator.metadataDescription: Free GPA calculator to calculate semester and cumulative GPA. Track your academic performance with our easy-to-use grade point average calculator.
GPACalculator.title: GPA Calculator
GPACalculator.subtitle: Calculate your semester and cumulative Grade Point Average

whatIs.title: What is GPA?
whatIs.content:
GPA (Grade Point Average) is a numerical representation of your academic performance, calculated by averaging the grade points you earned in your courses, weighted by the credit hours of each course.

Understanding the GPA Scale

The standard 4.0 GPA scale assigns numerical values to letter grades:

  • A/A+ = 4.0 - Excellent performance
  • A- = 3.7 - Very good performance
  • B+ = 3.3 - Good performance
  • B = 3.0 - Above average
  • B- = 2.7 - Slightly above average
  • C+ = 2.3 - Average performance
  • C = 2.0 - Satisfactory
  • C- = 1.7 - Below average
  • D+ = 1.3 - Poor performance
  • D = 1.0 - Barely passing
  • F = 0.0 - Failing grade

GPA is crucial for academic standing, scholarships, graduate school admissions, and job applications. A strong GPA demonstrates consistent academic achievement and discipline.

howTo.title: How to Calculate GPA
howTo.content:
Step-by-Step GPA Calculation

Step 1: Convert letter grades to grade points

Use the standard 4.0 scale (A=4.0, B=3.0, C=2.0, D=1.0, F=0.0)

Step 2: Multiply grade points by credit hours

For each course: Grade Points × Credit Hours = Quality Points

Step 3: Sum all quality points and credit hours

Add up all quality points and all credit hours separately

Step 4: Divide total quality points by total credit hours

GPA = Total Quality Points ÷ Total Credit Hours

Example Calculation

CourseGradePointsCreditsQuality Pts
Calculus IA4.0312.0
English 101B+3.339.9
ChemistryA-3.7414.8
Total1036.7

GPA = 36.7 ÷ 10 = 3.67

Cumulative GPA

To calculate cumulative GPA across multiple semesters:

Cumulative GPA = (Previous Total Quality Points + Current Quality Points) ÷ (Previous Total Credits + Current Credits)

tips.title: Tips for Improving Your GPA
tips.content:
Academic Success Strategies

  • Prioritize high-credit courses - Since GPA is weighted by credits, performing well in 4-credit courses has more impact than 1-credit courses
  • Retake failed courses - Many institutions allow grade replacement, where the new grade replaces the F in your GPA calculation
  • Take easier electives strategically - Balance difficult major courses with manageable electives to maintain your GPA
  • Use Pass/Fail options wisely - Some schools offer P/F grading that doesn't affect GPA, useful for challenging courses outside your major
  • Seek help early - Don't wait until midterms to get tutoring or visit office hours if you're struggling

GPA Benchmarks

GPA RangeStatusTypical Requirements
3.5 - 4.0ExcellentSumma/Magna Cum Laude, Top grad schools
3.0 - 3.49GoodCum Laude, Most grad schools, Scholarships
2.5 - 2.99AverageGood standing, Some opportunities
2.0 - 2.49Below AverageMinimum for graduation, Academic probation risk
Below 2.0At RiskAcademic probation or dismissal

Time Management Tips

  • Study consistently - 2 hours of study per credit hour per week (e.g., 6 hours/week for a 3-credit course)
  • Attend all classes - Missing lectures makes it exponentially harder to keep up
  • Form study groups - Collaborative learning improves retention and understanding
  • Use campus resources - Writing centers, tutoring services, and academic advisors are there to help

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What is a good GPA?
faq.a1: A 'good' GPA depends on your goals. For most purposes, 3.0+ is considered good. For competitive graduate programs or scholarships, aim for 3.5+. For honors graduation, you typically need 3.5-3.7+ (Cum Laude), 3.7-3.9+ (Magna Cum Laude), or 3.9-4.0 (Summa Cum Laude).
faq.q2: Is a 3.5 GPA good?
faq.a2: Yes! A 3.5 GPA is excellent and places you in approximately the top 15% of students. It qualifies you for Cum Laude honors at most universities, makes you competitive for most scholarships, and meets requirements for most graduate programs.
faq.q3: How can I raise my GPA quickly?
faq.a3: Focus on high-credit courses where A's will have maximum impact. If you have a low cumulative GPA from many credits, improvement will be gradual—a student with 60 credits at 2.5 GPA needs 15 credits of straight A's (4.0) to reach 2.875. Early in your academic career, GPA changes more quickly.
faq.q4: Do all schools use a 4.0 scale?
faq.a4: Most US colleges use the 4.0 scale, but some use 5.0 (weighted for honors/AP), 10.0, or 100-point scales. Some countries use entirely different systems (UK uses First Class/Upper Second, etc.). Always check your institution's specific grading system.
faq.q5: What's the difference between semester and cumulative GPA?
faq.a5: Semester GPA only includes courses from one semester (or quarter). Cumulative GPA includes all courses you've ever taken. Your transcript shows both. Most people reference cumulative GPA when asked about their GPA.
faq.q6: Can I get into graduate school with a 3.0 GPA?
faq.a6: Yes, but it depends on the program. Many master's programs accept 3.0+ GPAs. Competitive programs (medical, law, top MBA) typically want 3.5+. Strong GRE/GMAT scores, work experience, research, and recommendation letters can offset a lower GPA.

WeightConverter.metadataTitle: Weight Converter - Kilograms, Pounds, Ounces, Grams | MyCalcOnline
WeightConverter.metadataDescription: Convert weight between kilograms, pounds, ounces, grams, stones, and tons instantly. Free online weight and mass converter with conversion formulas.
WeightConverter.title: Weight Converter
WeightConverter.subtitle: Convert between metric and imperial weight units

whatIs.title: Understanding Weight Units
whatIs.content:
Weight and mass are measured using different unit systems around the world. The two main systems are:

Metric System (SI)

  • Milligram (mg) - Used for tiny amounts like medication doses
  • Gram (g) - Common for food and cooking measurements
  • Kilogram (kg) - The base SI unit, used for body weight and most everyday measurements
  • Metric Tonne (t) - 1,000 kg, used for heavy cargo and industrial purposes

Imperial/US System

  • Ounce (oz) - Common for food portions and postal weight
  • Pound (lb) - Standard unit for body weight in US/UK
  • Stone (st) - Used in UK/Ireland for body weight (1 stone = 14 pounds)
  • US Ton (ton) - 2,000 pounds, used for heavy materials

Understanding weight conversions is essential for cooking, fitness tracking, shipping, and international trade.

howTo.title: How to Convert Weight
howTo.content:
Key Conversion Formulas

Kilograms to Pounds:

lb = kg × 2.20462

Example: 70 kg = 70 × 2.20462 = 154.32 lb

Pounds to Kilograms:

kg = lb ÷ 2.20462 (or lb × 0.453592)

Example: 150 lb = 150 ÷ 2.20462 = 68.04 kg

Ounces to Grams:

g = oz × 28.3495

Example: 8 oz = 8 × 28.3495 = 226.8 g

Grams to Ounces:

oz = g ÷ 28.3495

Example: 100 g = 100 ÷ 28.3495 = 3.53 oz

Quick Mental Math Tips

  • kg to lb: Double the kg and add 10%. Example: 50 kg → 100 + 10 = 110 lb (actual: 110.23)
  • lb to kg: Halve the lb and subtract 10%. Example: 100 lb → 50 - 5 = 45 kg (actual: 45.36)
  • oz to g: Multiply by 30 for rough estimate. Example: 4 oz ≈ 120 g (actual: 113.4)

references.title: Common Weight References
references.content:
ItemMetricImperial
Paperclip1 g0.035 oz
Apple200 g7 oz
Basketball600 g1.3 lb
Liter of water1 kg2.2 lb
Average adult (US)80 kg176 lb / 12.5 st
Small car1,200 kg2,645 lb / 1.32 ton

Cooking Conversions

  • 1 cup of flour ≈ 125 g (4.4 oz)
  • 1 cup of sugar ≈ 200 g (7 oz)
  • 1 cup of butter ≈ 227 g (8 oz / 2 sticks)
  • 1 tablespoon of butter ≈ 14 g (0.5 oz)

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: How many pounds are in a kilogram?
faq.a1: 1 kilogram equals 2.20462 pounds. For quick mental math, multiply kilograms by 2.2 to get an approximate pound value. Example: 5 kg × 2.2 = 11 lb.
faq.q2: What's the difference between weight and mass?
faq.a2: Mass is the amount of matter in an object (measured in kg), while weight is the force of gravity on that mass (technically measured in Newtons). On Earth, we use kg and lb interchangeably for weight, but in space, you'd weigh nothing while your mass stays the same!
faq.q3: Why does the UK use stones for body weight?
faq.a3: The stone (14 pounds) is a traditional British unit that predates the metric system. While most countries use kilograms, the UK and Ireland still commonly express body weight in stones and pounds (e.g., '10 stone 5 pounds' = 145 lb = 65.8 kg).
faq.q4: What's the difference between a US ton and a metric tonne?
faq.a4: A US ton (short ton) = 2,000 pounds = 907.185 kg. A metric tonne = 1,000 kg = 2,204.62 pounds. The metric tonne is about 10% heavier. There's also the UK/long ton = 2,240 pounds, used in shipping.
faq.q5: How do I convert ounces to grams for cooking?
faq.a5: Multiply ounces by 28.35 to get grams. Common conversions: 1 oz = 28g, 4 oz = 113g (1/4 lb), 8 oz = 227g (1/2 lb), 16 oz = 454g (1 lb). For precision baking, use a digital kitchen scale.
faq.q6: Is 1 kg of feathers heavier than 1 kg of steel?
faq.a6: They weigh exactly the same - 1 kilogram! This classic riddle tricks people because we intuitively think of steel as 'heavier' than feathers. The difference is density: you'd need a much larger volume of feathers to reach 1 kg compared to steel.

CircleCalculator.metadataTitle: Circle Calculator - Area, Circumference, Diameter, Radius | MyCalcOnline
CircleCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate circle area, circumference, diameter, and radius instantly. Enter any value and get all measurements with step-by-step formulas.
CircleCalculator.title: Circle Calculator
CircleCalculator.subtitle: Calculate area, circumference, diameter, and radius from any measurement

whatIs.title: What is a Circle?
whatIs.content:
A circle is a perfectly round 2D shape where every point on the edge is exactly the same distance from the center. This distance is called the radius.

Key Components

  • Radius (r) - The distance from the center to any point on the circle's edge
  • Diameter (d) - The distance across the circle through the center (d = 2r)
  • Circumference (C) - The distance around the circle (perimeter)
  • Area (A) - The space enclosed by the circle

The Constant π (Pi)

Pi (π) is a mathematical constant approximately equal to 3.14159. It represents the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter. Pi is irrational, meaning its decimal expansion never ends or repeats.

Famous approximations: 22/7 ≈ 3.142857, 355/113 ≈ 3.1415929

howTo.title: How to Use This Calculator
howTo.content:
Steps

  1. Select what you know - Choose whether you have the radius, diameter, circumference, or area
  2. Enter the value - Type in your measurement
  3. Get all results - The calculator instantly shows radius, diameter, circumference, and area

Tips

  • Use Quick Values buttons for common measurements
  • Adjust Decimal Places for more or less precision
  • Click the copy icon next to any result to copy it to clipboard
  • Results update in real-time as you type

formulas.title: Circle Formulas
formulas.content:
Basic Relationships

FindFormula
Diameter from Radiusd = 2r
Radius from Diameterr = d/2
Circumference from RadiusC = 2πr
Circumference from DiameterC = πd
Area from RadiusA = πr²
Radius from Circumferencer = C/(2π)
Radius from Arear = √(A/π)

Example Calculation

Given: radius = 5 cm

  • Diameter = 2 × 5 = 10 cm
  • Circumference = 2 × π × 5 = 31.4159 cm
  • Area = π × 5² = π × 25 = 78.5398 cm²

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What is the difference between radius and diameter?
faq.a1: The radius is the distance from the center of the circle to its edge. The diameter is the distance across the entire circle through the center. The diameter is always exactly twice the radius (d = 2r).
faq.q2: How do I find the area of a circle?
faq.a2: Use the formula A = πr². Square the radius, then multiply by π (approximately 3.14159). For example, a circle with radius 5 has area = π × 5² = π × 25 ≈ 78.54 square units.
faq.q3: What is π (pi) and why is it important?
faq.a3: Pi (π) is a mathematical constant representing the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter. It equals approximately 3.14159 and appears in every circle formula. Pi is irrational, meaning its digits never end or repeat.
faq.q4: How do I find radius from area?
faq.a4: Use the formula r = √(A/π). Divide the area by π, then take the square root. For example, if area = 100, then r = √(100/π) = √(31.831) ≈ 5.64.
faq.q5: What units should I use?
faq.a5: Use any unit for radius/diameter/circumference (cm, m, inches, feet). Area will be in square units (cm², m², in², ft²). Just be consistent - don't mix units in the same calculation.
faq.q6: How accurate is π = 3.14?
faq.a6: Using π = 3.14 gives about 0.05% error, which is fine for most everyday calculations. For more precision, use 3.14159 (6 digits, 0.000008% error) or let the calculator use the full value of π stored in the computer.

whatIs.title: What is a Triangle?
whatIs.content:
A triangle is a polygon with three edges and three vertices. It's one of the most fundamental shapes in geometry.

Triangle Properties

  • Three sides - Usually labeled a, b, and c
  • Three angles - Usually labeled A, B, and C (or α, β, γ)
  • Sum of angles - Always equals 180° (π radians)
  • Triangle inequality - The sum of any two sides must be greater than the third side

Types of Triangles

By angles:

  • Right triangle - Has one 90° angle
  • Acute triangle - All angles are less than 90°
  • Obtuse triangle - Has one angle greater than 90°

By sides:

  • Equilateral - All three sides equal (all angles = 60°)
  • Isosceles - Two sides equal
  • Scalene - All sides different

howTo.title: How to Use This Calculator
howTo.content:
Choose Your Method

Select the method based on what information you have:

  1. SSS (Side-Side-Side) - When you know all three sides
  2. SAS (Side-Angle-Side) - When you know two sides and the angle between them
  3. ASA (Angle-Side-Angle) - When you know two angles and the side between them

Enter Your Values

  • Input the known measurements
  • Sides can be any positive number
  • Angles must be between 0° and 180°
  • The calculator will automatically compute all missing values

Results

The calculator shows:

  • All three sides and angles
  • Area (using Heron's formula)
  • Perimeter
  • Triangle type (right, acute, or obtuse)

formulas.title: Triangle Formulas
formulas.content:
Basic Formulas

FormulaDescription
A + B + C = 180°Sum of angles
a + b > cTriangle inequality (for all combinations)
P = a + b + cPerimeter

Law of Cosines

Used to find missing sides or angles when you have SSS or SAS:

c² = a² + b² - 2ab·cos(C)

cos(A) = (b² + c² - a²) / (2bc)

Law of Sines

Used when you have ASA or AAS:

a/sin(A) = b/sin(B) = c/sin(C)

Heron's Formula (Area)

Calculate area when you know all three sides:

s = (a + b + c) / 2

Area = √[s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)]

Where s is the semi-perimeter.

Alternative Area Formulas

  • With base and height: A = (1/2) × base × height
  • With two sides and included angle: A = (1/2) × a × b × sin(C)

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: How do I know if three sides can form a triangle?
faq.a1: Use the triangle inequality theorem: the sum of any two sides must be greater than the third side. For example, sides 3, 4, 5 work because 3+4 > 5, 3+5 > 4, and 4+5 > 3. But 1, 2, 10 don't work because 1+2 < 10.
faq.q2: What's the difference between SSS, SAS, and ASA?
faq.a2: SSS = all three sides known. SAS = two sides and the angle between them. ASA = two angles and the side between them. These are the minimum information needed to uniquely determine a triangle. There's also AAS (two angles and a non-included side) and HL (hypotenuse-leg for right triangles).
faq.q3: Why do all triangle angles add up to 180°?
faq.a3: This is a fundamental property of Euclidean geometry (flat surfaces). If you draw a triangle on a flat surface and measure the angles with a protractor, they'll always sum to 180°. On curved surfaces (spheres or saddles), this isn't true - spherical triangles have angles that sum to more than 180°!
faq.q4: How do I find the area without the height?
faq.a4: Use Heron's formula if you know all three sides: First calculate s = (a+b+c)/2, then Area = √[s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)]. Or if you know two sides and the angle between them, use Area = (1/2)ab·sin(C).
faq.q5: What is a right triangle?
faq.a5: A right triangle has one 90° angle. The side opposite the right angle is called the hypotenuse (the longest side). Right triangles follow the Pythagorean theorem: a² + b² = c². Common examples include 3-4-5, 5-12-13, and 8-15-17 triangles.
faq.q6: Can I use degrees or radians?
faq.a6: This calculator uses degrees (°) for all angle measurements. To convert: radians × (180/π) = degrees, or degrees × (π/180) = radians. Most everyday applications use degrees (90° for a right angle), while advanced math and physics often use radians (π/2 for a right angle).

InflationCalculator.metadataTitle: Inflation Calculator - Calculate Future & Past Value | MyCalcOnline
InflationCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate the impact of inflation on money over time. Find future value, past purchasing power, or inflation rate between two amounts.
InflationCalculator.title: Inflation Calculator
InflationCalculator.subtitle: Calculate how inflation affects the value of money over time
InflationCalculator.selectMode: What do you want to calculate?
InflationCalculator.modeFutureDesc: How much will money be worth?

whatIs.title: What is Inflation?
whatIs.content:
Inflation is the rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services rises, causing purchasing power to fall. When inflation occurs, each dollar (or unit of currency) buys fewer goods and services.

Key Concepts

  • Inflation Rate - The percentage increase in prices over a period (usually annual)
  • Purchasing Power - The value of currency in terms of what it can buy
  • Future Value - How much money will be worth in the future
  • Real vs Nominal Value - Adjusted for inflation vs face value

Why Inflation Matters

Understanding inflation is crucial for:

  • Retirement planning - Ensuring your savings maintain value
  • Salary negotiations - Cost of living adjustments
  • Investment decisions - Returns must beat inflation
  • Historical comparisons - Comparing prices across time periods

Common Inflation Rates

  • Low inflation: 1-2% annually (stable economy)
  • Moderate inflation: 2-5% annually (healthy growth)
  • High inflation: 5-10% annually (concerning)
  • Hyperinflation: 50%+ monthly (economic crisis)

howTo.title: How to Use This Calculator
howTo.content:
Calculate Future Value

Find out how much money will be worth in the future due to inflation:

  1. Enter the current amount
  2. Select start year and end year
  3. Enter the expected annual inflation rate
  4. View the future value and total increase

Example: $1,000 today with 3% inflation for 10 years = $1,344 in the future

Calculate Past Value

Discover what money was worth in the past (purchasing power):

  1. Enter today's amount
  2. Select current year and a past year
  3. Enter the average inflation rate for that period
  4. See what that amount would have bought in the past

Example: $1,000 today equals $744 in purchasing power 10 years ago (at 3% inflation)

Calculate Inflation Rate

Find the average inflation rate between two amounts:

  1. Enter the starting amount
  2. Enter the ending amount
  3. Specify the number of years
  4. The calculator shows the average annual inflation rate

Formula: Rate = ((End Amount / Start Amount)^(1/Years) - 1) × 100

examples.title: Real-World Examples
examples.content:
Example 1: Retirement Planning

Scenario: You plan to retire in 30 years and need $50,000/year to live.

Question: How much will you actually need in 30 years?

Calculation: $50,000 with 3% inflation for 30 years

Result: $121,363 per year needed (2.43× more)

Insight: Your retirement savings must grow faster than 3% annually just to maintain purchasing power.

Example 2: Salary Comparison

Scenario: Your grandpa earned $10,000/year in 1970. You earn $60,000 today.

Question: Who earned more in real terms?

Calculation: $10,000 in 1970 with ~4% average inflation for 54 years

Result: $10,000 in 1970 ≈ $86,000 in 2024 purchasing power

Insight: Despite earning 6× nominally, you're actually earning about 30% less in real terms!

Example 3: Investment Returns

Scenario: Your investment returned 7% annually over 10 years, but inflation averaged 3%.

Real Return: Approximately 4% (7% - 3%)

Insight: Always subtract inflation from investment returns to get the "real" return - what you actually gained in purchasing power.

Historical US Inflation Examples

Item1970 Price2024 PriceIncrease
Gallon of Gas$0.36$3.509.7×
Movie Ticket$1.55$12.007.7×
New Car$3,500$48,00013.7×
Median Home$23,000$420,00018.3×

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What is a normal inflation rate?
faq.a1: Most central banks (like the US Federal Reserve) target around 2% annual inflation. This is considered healthy for a growing economy. Historical US inflation has averaged about 3-3.5% since 1913. Rates of 1-3% are generally considered low and stable.
faq.q2: Why does inflation happen?
faq.a2: Inflation occurs when demand for goods and services exceeds supply (demand-pull), when production costs increase (cost-push), or when the money supply grows faster than economic output. Government policies, international events, and market speculation also play roles.
faq.q3: How is inflation measured?
faq.a3: The most common measure is the Consumer Price Index (CPI), which tracks the average change in prices for a basket of consumer goods and services (food, housing, transportation, medical care, etc.). Other measures include the Producer Price Index (PPI) and PCE (Personal Consumption Expenditures).
faq.q4: What's the difference between inflation and deflation?
faq.a4: Inflation is when prices rise and purchasing power falls. Deflation is the opposite - when prices fall and purchasing power increases. While deflation sounds good, it can be harmful because consumers delay purchases expecting lower prices, which hurts the economy.
faq.q5: How do I protect my money from inflation?
faq.a5: Invest in assets that typically outpace inflation: stocks (historically ~10% annual returns), real estate, Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS), commodities, or I-Bonds. Keep only emergency funds in cash. Diversification is key to managing inflation risk.
faq.q6: Is 3% inflation the same every year?
faq.a6: No. The 3% is an average - actual inflation varies yearly. The US had near 0% in 2015, 1.4% in 2020, but 8% in 2022. When using this calculator for long periods, use the average historical rate for that timeframe, not a single year's rate.

PythagoreanCalculator.metadataTitle: Pythagorean Theorem Calculator - Find Sides of Right Triangle | MyCalcOnline

PythagoreanCalculator.title: Pythagorean Theorem Calculator

PythagoreanCalculator.modeHypotenuseDesc: Calculate c from a and b
PythagoreanCalculator.modeLegADesc: Calculate a from b and c
PythagoreanCalculator.modeLegBDesc: Calculate b from a and c
PythagoreanCalculator.errorHypotenuseTooSmall: The hypotenuse must be longer than each leg. Please check your values.

whatIs.title: What is the Pythagorean Theorem?
whatIs.content:
The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most fundamental relationships in geometry. It states that in a right triangle (a triangle with one 90° angle), the square of the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle) equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

The Formula

a² + b² = c²

Where:

  • a and b are the legs (the two shorter sides that form the right angle)
  • c is the hypotenuse (the longest side, opposite the right angle)

History

Although named after the Greek mathematician Pythagoras (c. 570-495 BC), this theorem was known to earlier civilizations including the Babylonians and Indians. Pythagoras or his followers are credited with the first proof.

Why It Matters

The Pythagorean theorem is essential in:

  • Construction and architecture
  • Navigation and surveying
  • Computer graphics and game development
  • Physics and engineering
  • GPS and distance calculations

howTo.title: How to Use This Calculator
howTo.content:
Finding the Hypotenuse

  1. Select "Find Hypotenuse (c)" mode
  2. Enter the lengths of both legs (a and b)
  3. The calculator instantly shows c = √(a² + b²)

Finding a Leg

  1. Select "Find Leg A" or "Find Leg B"
  2. Enter the hypotenuse (c) and the known leg
  3. The calculator computes the missing leg

Quick Triples

Click on any Pythagorean triple (like 3-4-5) to instantly populate the fields with known values. These are triangles where all three sides are whole numbers.

Formulas Used

FindingFormula
Hypotenuse (c)c = √(a² + b²)
Leg aa = √(c² - b²)
Leg bb = √(c² - a²)

examples.title: Examples & Practice Problems
examples.content:
Example 1: Classic 3-4-5 Triangle

Given: a = 3, b = 4

Find: Hypotenuse c

Solution:

  • c² = a² + b² = 3² + 4² = 9 + 16 = 25
  • c = √25 = 5

✓ This is a Pythagorean triple (all whole numbers)

Example 2: Finding a Leg

Given: b = 12, c = 13

Find: Leg a

Solution:

  • a² = c² - b² = 13² - 12² = 169 - 144 = 25
  • a = √25 = 5

Example 3: Real-World Application

Problem: A ladder is 10 feet long and leans against a wall. If the base is 6 feet from the wall, how high up the wall does it reach?

Solution:

  • We know: c (ladder) = 10, a (distance from wall) = 6
  • b² = c² - a² = 10² - 6² = 100 - 36 = 64
  • b = √64 = 8 feet

Common Pythagorean Triples

TripleMultiples
3-4-56-8-10, 9-12-15, 12-16-20...
5-12-1310-24-26, 15-36-39...
8-15-1716-30-34, 24-45-51...
7-24-2514-48-50, 21-72-75...

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What is the Pythagorean theorem?
faq.a1: The Pythagorean theorem states that in a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse (longest side, opposite the right angle) equals the sum of squares of the two legs: a² + b² = c². It only works for right triangles (triangles with one 90° angle).
faq.q2: What is a Pythagorean triple?
faq.a2: A Pythagorean triple is a set of three positive integers (a, b, c) that satisfy a² + b² = c². Famous examples include 3-4-5, 5-12-13, and 8-15-17. Any multiple of a triple is also a triple (e.g., 6-8-10 from 3-4-5).
faq.q3: Why must the hypotenuse be the longest side?
faq.a3: By definition, the hypotenuse is opposite the largest angle (90°). In any triangle, the longest side is always opposite the largest angle. If you try to use a shorter side as the hypotenuse, the math won't work (you'd get a negative number under the square root).
faq.q4: Can the Pythagorean theorem work with any triangle?
faq.a4: No, the classic a² + b² = c² only works for right triangles (90° angle). For other triangles, you need the Law of Cosines: c² = a² + b² - 2ab·cos(C), where C is the angle opposite side c. When C = 90°, cos(90°) = 0, giving us the Pythagorean theorem.
faq.q5: How do I find the distance between two points?
faq.a5: The distance formula is derived from the Pythagorean theorem! For points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂): distance = √[(x₂-x₁)² + (y₂-y₁)²]. The horizontal and vertical differences are the legs, and the distance is the hypotenuse.
faq.q6: What is the 3D Pythagorean theorem?
faq.a6: In 3D space, the diagonal of a rectangular box with sides a, b, c is: d = √(a² + b² + c²). This is an extension of the 2D theorem. For example, a room 3m × 4m × 12m has a diagonal of √(9+16+144) = √169 = 13 meters.

RandomNumberGenerator.title: Random Number Generator
RandomNumberGenerator.subtitle: Generate random numbers for any purpose

whatIs.title: What is a Random Number Generator?
whatIs.content:
A Random Number Generator (RNG) is a tool that produces numbers in a sequence that cannot be reasonably predicted. These generators are essential in many fields:

  • Gaming: Dice rolls, card shuffling, loot drops in video games
  • Statistics: Random sampling for surveys and experiments
  • Cryptography: Generating secure keys and tokens
  • Simulations: Monte Carlo methods and modeling
  • Lotteries: Fair and unbiased number selection

This tool uses JavaScript's Math.random() function, which provides pseudo-random numbers suitable for most everyday purposes.

howTo.title: How to Use This Generator
howTo.content:
Generation Modes

  • Single Number: Generate one random number within your specified range
  • Multiple Numbers: Generate several random numbers (duplicates allowed)
  • Unique List: Generate a list of unique numbers without duplicates
  • Dice Roller: Simulate rolling dice (D4, D6, D8, D10, D12, D20, D100)

Steps to Generate

  1. Choose your generation mode
  2. Set the minimum and maximum values (or select dice type)
  3. If generating multiple numbers, specify how many
  4. Click 'Generate Random Numbers'
  5. Copy the results or generate again

Pro Tips

  • Use 'Unique List' for lottery-style picks or raffle winners
  • D20 dice are popular in tabletop RPGs like D&D
  • The history shows your last 10 generations

useCases.title: Common Use Cases
useCases.content:
Games & Entertainment

  • Board games: Virtual dice when physical dice are unavailable
  • Raffles: Pick random winners from numbered tickets
  • Decision making: Random choice between options (assign numbers to choices)

Education & Research

  • Random sampling: Select random participants for surveys
  • Classroom activities: Random student selection for presentations
  • Randomized trials: Assign subjects to control/experimental groups

Programming & Development

  • Test data: Generate random values for testing
  • Seed values: Starting points for simulations
  • Game development: Randomize game elements

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: Are these numbers truly random?
faq.a1: These are pseudo-random numbers generated by an algorithm. They're random enough for games, sampling, and everyday use, but not cryptographically secure. For security applications (passwords, encryption), use specialized tools.
faq.q2: Can I generate decimal numbers?
faq.a2: This generator produces whole numbers (integers) only. For decimal random numbers, you could generate a larger range and divide. For example, generate 1-100 and divide by 10 for one decimal place (0.1 to 10.0).
faq.q3: Why use 'Unique List' instead of 'Multiple Numbers'?
faq.a3: Use 'Unique List' when you need distinct numbers without any repeats - like drawing lottery numbers, picking raffle winners, or assigning unique IDs. Note: you can't generate more unique numbers than exist in your range.
faq.q4: What dice types are available?
faq.a4: D4 (4-sided), D6 (standard 6-sided), D8, D10, D12, D20 (popular in D&D), and D100 (percentile). You can roll multiple dice at once and see both individual results and the total.
faq.q5: Is there a limit to how many numbers I can generate?
faq.a5: For performance, we limit multiple number generation to 1,000 numbers at once. For unique lists, you're limited by the range size - you can't pick 100 unique numbers from a 1-50 range.
faq.q6: Why do I get different numbers each time?
faq.a6: That's the point of randomness! The generator starts with a different seed each time, producing unpredictable sequences. If you need reproducible 'random' numbers for testing, you'd need a seeded random number generator.

DateDifferenceCalculator.metadataTitle: Date Difference Calculator - Days Between Dates | MyCalcOnline

DateDifferenceCalculator.title: Date Difference Calculator
