whatIs.title: What is a Date Difference Calculator?
whatIs.content:
A date difference calculator computes the exact time span between two dates. It can tell you how many days, weeks, months, and years have passed between any two calendar dates.

Common Uses

  • Project Planning - Calculate project duration and deadlines
  • Age Calculation - Find exact age in days or weeks
  • Contract Duration - Count days in employment or rental periods
  • Event Countdown - Days until or since important dates
  • Billing Cycles - Calculate pro-rated amounts based on days

What This Calculator Shows

Our calculator provides:

  • Total days - Exact day count between dates
  • Weekdays vs weekends - Business days breakdown
  • Multiple units - Hours, minutes, and seconds
  • Approximate conversions - Estimated months and years

howTo.title: How to Calculate Days Between Dates
howTo.content:
Using This Calculator

  1. Enter Start Date - Select or type your starting date
  2. Enter End Date - Select or type your ending date
  3. Include/Exclude End Date - Choose whether to count the end date
  4. View Results - See comprehensive breakdown instantly

Including vs Excluding End Date

This option affects the count:

  • Include end date: Jan 1 to Jan 3 = 3 days (Jan 1, 2, 3)
  • Exclude end date: Jan 1 to Jan 3 = 2 days (Jan 1, 2)

Use "include" for counting full days (vacations, rental periods). Use "exclude" for time elapsed since an event.

Quick Ranges

Click preset buttons to quickly set common time periods: 7 days (week), 30 days (month), 90 days (quarter), 365 days (year).

examples.title: Real-World Examples
examples.content:
Example 1: Vacation Days

Scenario: You're taking vacation from March 15 to March 22.

With end date included: 8 days total (you're gone for 8 full days)

Weekdays: 6 days (potential work days missed)

Weekend days: 2 days

Example 2: Project Deadline

Scenario: Project starts April 1, due May 31.

Total days: 61 days

Weekdays only: ~44 working days

This helps with: Resource allocation, sprint planning, milestone setting

Example 3: Lease Period

Scenario: Rent is $1,500/month. You move in on the 15th.

Days in month: 30

Days you lived there: 16 (including move-in day)

Pro-rated rent: $1,500 × (16/30) = $800

Common Date Spans

PeriodDaysWeeks
1 Week71
2 Weeks142
1 Month (avg)30.444.35
1 Quarter91.3113
1 Year365.2552.18

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: Should I include or exclude the end date?
faq.a1: Include the end date when counting complete days (vacation days, rental periods, age in days). Exclude it when measuring time elapsed since an event (days since a birthday, time since a purchase). The choice depends on whether the end date is a 'full' day or just a cutoff point.
faq.q2: How do you count weekdays vs weekends?
faq.a2: Weekdays are Monday through Friday (5 days per week). Weekends are Saturday and Sunday (2 days per week). We check each date in the range to give you an exact count, accounting for partial weeks at the start and end of your date range.
faq.q3: Why is 'months' an approximation?
faq.a3: Months have different lengths (28-31 days), so there's no exact 'days per month' value. We use the average month length of 30.437 days. For precise month calculations between specific dates, our breakdown shows exact years, months, and days.
faq.q4: Does this account for leap years?
faq.a4: Yes! The calculator uses actual calendar dates, so February 29 is correctly counted in leap years. The average year length (365.25 days) also accounts for the extra leap day every 4 years.
faq.q5: What's the maximum date range I can calculate?
faq.a5: You can calculate any date range your browser's date picker supports - typically from year 0001 to 9999. The calculator handles spans of thousands of years accurately.
faq.q6: How do I calculate business days only?
faq.a6: Look at the 'Weekdays' result, which shows Monday-Friday count. For more precise business day calculations that exclude holidays, you'd need to use a specialized business day calculator with a holiday calendar for your region.

CountdownCalculator.metadataTitle: Countdown Timer - Days Until Event Calculator | MyCalcOnline
CountdownCalculator.metadataDescription: Create a countdown timer to any date. Track days, hours, minutes and seconds until your event. Free online countdown calculator with preset holidays.
CountdownCalculator.title: Countdown Timer

whatIs.title: What is a Countdown Timer?
whatIs.content:
A countdown timer calculates and displays the remaining time until a specific date and event. It shows the countdown in real-time, updating every second.

Why Use a Countdown Timer?

  • Event Planning: Track time until weddings, parties, or celebrations
  • Holiday Anticipation: Count down to Christmas, New Year, or other holidays
  • Goal Tracking: Stay motivated by seeing progress toward deadlines
  • Travel Planning: Build excitement for upcoming vacations
  • Product Launches: Create urgency for releases or sales

Features of This Timer

  • Real-time updates: Seconds tick down live
  • Multiple units: Days, hours, minutes, and seconds
  • Progress bar: Visual representation of time elapsed
  • Save events: Store multiple countdowns locally
  • Share links: Send countdown to friends

howTo.title: How to Use This Countdown Timer
howTo.content:
Quick Start

  1. Click a preset: Use New Year, Christmas, or other holiday buttons
  2. Or set custom date: Enter any target date and time
  3. Name your event: Give it a memorable name
  4. Watch it count: See real-time countdown

Features

  • Quick Countdown: Click day buttons (7, 30, 90 days) for fast setup
  • Save Events: Store multiple countdowns in your browser
  • Share: Copy a link to share your countdown with others
  • Progress Bar: See how much time has passed since you started tracking

Tips

  • Set the time to midnight (00:00) for all-day events
  • Use specific times for events like flight departures
  • Saved events persist even if you close the browser

ideas.title: Countdown Ideas
ideas.content:
Personal Events

  • Birthdays: Count down to your or loved ones' birthdays
  • Anniversaries: Wedding anniversaries, dating milestones
  • Graduation: End of school or university
  • Retirement: Your last day of work

Holidays & Celebrations

  • New Year's Eve: The classic countdown
  • Christmas: Days until Santa arrives
  • Summer Break: End of school year
  • Religious holidays: Easter, Diwali, Eid, Hanukkah

Life Events

  • Wedding Day: Count down to 'I do'
  • Baby Due Date: Anticipate the arrival
  • Moving Day: New home countdown
  • Vacation: Build excitement for your trip

Professional

  • Project Deadlines: Stay on track
  • Product Launches: Build anticipation
  • Conferences: Count to industry events
  • End of Quarter: Business milestones

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: Does the countdown work if I close the browser?
faq.a1: The countdown calculation is always accurate based on the target date. If you save the event, it will be stored in your browser and you can reload it anytime. The countdown resumes automatically when you return.
faq.q2: Can I share my countdown with others?
faq.a2: Yes! Click the 'Share' button to copy a link. When others open this link, they'll see the same countdown. Note that saved events are stored locally and won't transfer - only the countdown parameters are shared.
faq.q3: What happens when the countdown reaches zero?
faq.a3: The timer will show that the event has passed and display how much time ago it occurred. The progress bar will show 100% complete. You can keep the countdown to track time since the event.
faq.q4: Can I count up from a past date?
faq.a4: Yes! If you set a date in the past, the calculator will show how much time has elapsed since that date. This is useful for tracking anniversaries or 'days since' events.
faq.q5: Are my saved events private?
faq.a5: Yes, saved events are stored only in your browser's local storage. They're not uploaded anywhere and only you can see them. Clearing browser data will remove saved events.
faq.q6: Why does the seconds counter animate?
faq.a6: The pulsing animation on seconds helps indicate that the countdown is live and actively updating. It draws attention to the real-time nature of the timer and creates a sense of urgency.

RatioCalculator.whatIsDetail: A ratio is a mathematical expression that compares two or more quantities by showing their relative sizes. Ratios are written as a:b or a/b, where 'a' and 'b' are numbers. For example, if a recipe requires 2 cups of flour for every 3 cups of sugar, the ratio is 2:3. Ratios are used in cooking, mixing paints, calculating speeds, comparing prices, and many other real-world applications.
RatioCalculator.howToDetail: There are several ways to work with ratios: 1) Simplifying: Divide both numbers by their greatest common divisor (GCD) to get the simplest form. 2) Equivalent Ratios: Multiply or divide both parts by the same number to find equivalent ratios. 3) Comparing: Convert ratios to decimals or find a common denominator to compare. 4) Dividing: To split a total amount in a given ratio, divide the total by the sum of ratio parts, then multiply by each part.
RatioCalculator.example1Detail: To simplify 8:12, find the GCD of 8 and 12, which is 4. Divide both by 4: 8÷4 = 2 and 12÷4 = 3. The simplified ratio is 2:3.
RatioCalculator.example2Detail: If 2:3 = 6:x, cross-multiply: 2x = 3×6, so 2x = 18, therefore x = 9. The equivalent ratio is 6:9.
RatioCalculator.example3Detail: Sum of parts = 2+3 = 5. First part = (2/5)×100 = $40. Second part = (3/5)×100 = $60. Total check: $40 + $60 = $100 ✓
RatioCalculator.faqQ1: What is the difference between a ratio and a fraction?
RatioCalculator.faqA1: A ratio compares two or more quantities (like 2:3), while a fraction represents a part of a whole (like 2/3). Ratios can be written as fractions, but they have different meanings. A ratio shows relative sizes, while a fraction shows a portion of something.
RatioCalculator.faqQ2: How do you simplify a ratio?
RatioCalculator.faqA2: To simplify a ratio, find the greatest common divisor (GCD) of all numbers in the ratio, then divide each number by the GCD. For example, 10:15 simplified: GCD is 5, so 10÷5:15÷5 = 2:3.
RatioCalculator.faqQ3: What does a ratio of 1:1 mean?
RatioCalculator.faqA3: A ratio of 1:1 (also written as 1 to 1) means both quantities are equal. For example, if mixing two liquids in a 1:1 ratio, you use equal amounts of each. It's the simplest ratio possible.
RatioCalculator.faqQ4: How do you find a missing value in a proportion?
RatioCalculator.faqA4: Use cross-multiplication. If a:b = c:x, then a×x = b×c, so x = (b×c)/a. For example, if 2:3 = 4:x, then x = (3×4)/2 = 6.
RatioCalculator.faqQ5: Can ratios have more than two numbers?
RatioCalculator.faqA5: Yes! Ratios can compare 3 or more quantities. For example, 2:3:5 means for every 2 parts of the first, there are 3 parts of the second and 5 parts of the third. To divide $100 in ratio 2:3:5, sum=10, so parts are $20, $30, and $50.
RatioCalculator.faqA6: The golden ratio is approximately 1.618:1 (or 1:1.618), denoted by the Greek letter φ (phi). It appears frequently in nature, art, and architecture and is considered aesthetically pleasing. It's calculated as (1+√5)/2.

ScientificNotationCalculator.metadataTitle: Scientific Notation Calculator - Convert & Calculate | MyCalcOnline
ScientificNotationCalculator.metadataDescription: Free scientific notation calculator. Convert between decimal and scientific notation, perform operations with exponents. Calculate and simplify instantly.
ScientificNotationCalculator.metadataKeywords: scientific notation calculator, scientific notation converter, exponential notation, decimal to scientific notation, scientific notation operations
ScientificNotationCalculator.h1Subtitle: Convert between decimal and scientific notation, and perform calculations with exponential numbers
ScientificNotationCalculator.operationsDescription: Add, subtract, multiply, divide in scientific notation
ScientificNotationCalculator.whatIsDetail: Scientific notation is a way of expressing very large or very small numbers in a compact form. Numbers are written as a × 10^n, where 'a' is a coefficient between 1 and 10, and 'n' is an integer exponent. For example, 300,000 is written as 3 × 10^5, and 0.00045 is written as 4.5 × 10^-4. This notation is widely used in science, engineering, and mathematics to make calculations with extreme values more manageable.
ScientificNotationCalculator.howToDetail: To convert to scientific notation: 1) Move the decimal point until you have a number between 1 and 10. 2) Count how many places you moved - this is your exponent. 3) If you moved left, the exponent is positive; if right, negative. To convert back to decimal: multiply the coefficient by 10 raised to the exponent power. For operations: multiply/divide by adding/subtracting exponents (when bases are the same), or convert to decimal first for addition/subtraction.
ScientificNotationCalculator.example1Detail: The speed of light is approximately 300,000,000 meters per second, which in scientific notation is 3.0 × 10^8 m/s. Moving the decimal 8 places to the left gives us the coefficient 3.0 and exponent 8.
ScientificNotationCalculator.example2Detail: The mass of an electron is about 0.000000000000000000000000000000911 kg, written as 9.11 × 10^-31 kg in scientific notation. This makes it much easier to read and work with.
ScientificNotationCalculator.example3Detail: To multiply (2 × 10^3) × (3 × 10^4): multiply coefficients (2 × 3 = 6) and add exponents (3 + 4 = 7). Result: 6 × 10^7 or 60,000,000.
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqQ1: When should I use scientific notation?
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqA1: Scientific notation is useful when dealing with very large numbers (like astronomical distances: 1.5 × 10^11 meters to the sun) or very small numbers (like atomic sizes: 1 × 10^-10 meters). It makes these numbers easier to read, write, and calculate with.
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqQ2: What is the difference between scientific notation and standard form?
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqA2: Scientific notation and standard form are the same thing. Both express numbers as a × 10^n where 1 ≤ a < 10. Some regions use 'standard form' while others say 'scientific notation', but they mean the same mathematical concept.
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqQ3: Can the coefficient be negative in scientific notation?
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqA3: Yes! The coefficient can be positive or negative. For example, -4.5 × 10^3 = -4,500. The sign of the coefficient indicates whether the overall number is positive or negative, while the exponent shows the magnitude.
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqQ4: How do you add numbers in scientific notation?
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqA4: To add or subtract, the exponents must be the same. Either adjust one number to match the other's exponent, or convert both to decimal, perform the operation, then convert back. For example, (2 × 10^3) + (3 × 10^2) = (2 × 10^3) + (0.3 × 10^3) = 2.3 × 10^3.
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqQ5: What does a negative exponent mean?
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqA5: A negative exponent means the number is less than 1 (a decimal). For example, 10^-3 = 0.001. The negative exponent tells you how many places to move the decimal point to the left. So 4.5 × 10^-2 = 0.045.
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqQ6: Why is scientific notation important in science?
ScientificNotationCalculator.faqA6: Scientific notation is essential in science because it allows us to work with the extreme scales found in nature - from subatomic particles (10^-15 m) to galaxies (10^21 m). It makes calculations clearer, reduces errors from writing many zeros, and helps maintain precision in measurements.

ExponentCalculator.metadataTitle: Exponent Calculator - Powers, Roots & Logarithms | MyCalcOnline
ExponentCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate exponents, roots, and logarithms instantly. Free online exponent calculator for powers, nth roots, and log operations with step-by-step formulas.
ExponentCalculator.metadataKeywords: exponent calculator, power calculator, root calculator, logarithm calculator, nth root, square root, cube root, log calculator
ExponentCalculator.title: Exponent Calculator
ExponentCalculator.subtitle: Calculate powers, roots, and logarithms
ExponentCalculator.whatIsContent: An exponent (or power) represents repeated multiplication. When we write b^n (read as 'b to the power of n'), it means multiplying b by itself n times. For example, 2^3 = 2 × 2 × 2 = 8. Exponents are fundamental in mathematics, science, and engineering for expressing very large or very small numbers efficiently. Special cases include: any number to the power of 0 equals 1 (e.g., 5^0 = 1), any number to the power of 1 equals itself (e.g., 7^1 = 7), and negative exponents represent fractions (e.g., 2^-3 = 1/8).
ExponentCalculator.howToUseContent: Choose from three calculation modes: Power mode calculates base^exponent (e.g., 2^8 = 256), Root mode finds the nth root of a number (e.g., cube root of 27 = 3), and Logarithm mode finds what power you need to raise a base to get a value (e.g., log₂(8) = 3, because 2^3 = 8). Enter your numbers in the input fields and the result updates automatically. Use the Quick Values buttons to test common calculations and understand how each mode works.
ExponentCalculator.commonUsesContent: Exponents are widely used in science (population growth: 2^t, radioactive decay: e^-kt), finance (compound interest: P(1+r)^t), computer science (binary powers: 2^n for memory sizes like 2^10 = 1024 bytes = 1 KB), physics (inverse square law: 1/r^2), and engineering (signal processing, electrical circuits). Roots are essential for geometry (finding side lengths from areas/volumes) and statistics (standard deviation calculations). Logarithms are used in measuring earthquakes (Richter scale), sound (decibels), pH levels in chemistry, and information theory.
ExponentCalculator.faqQ1: What does a negative exponent mean?
ExponentCalculator.faqA1: A negative exponent means you divide by that number of times instead of multiply. For example, 2^-3 = 1/(2^3) = 1/8 = 0.125. Negative exponents create fractions. This is useful for expressing very small numbers: 10^-6 = 0.000001 (one millionth).
ExponentCalculator.faqQ2: What is the difference between square root and cube root?
ExponentCalculator.faqA2: A square root (²√ or √) asks 'what number multiplied by itself gives this?' For example, √16 = 4 because 4 × 4 = 16. A cube root (³√) asks 'what number multiplied by itself three times gives this?' For example, ³√27 = 3 because 3 × 3 × 3 = 27. Generally, an nth root asks for n multiplications.
ExponentCalculator.faqA3: A logarithm answers the question: 'What power do I raise the base to get this number?' For example, log₂(8) = 3 because 2^3 = 8. Common logarithm bases are 10 (log₁₀, called 'log') and e (logₑ, called 'ln' or natural log). If log₁₀(100) = 2, it means 10^2 = 100.
ExponentCalculator.faqQ4: What happens when you raise a number to the power of 0?
ExponentCalculator.faqA4: Any non-zero number raised to the power of 0 equals 1. For example, 5^0 = 1, 100^0 = 1, even (-3)^0 = 1. This is because of the exponent rule: a^(m-m) = a^m / a^m = 1, and m - m = 0. Note: 0^0 is mathematically undefined.
ExponentCalculator.faqQ5: How do you multiply numbers with exponents?
ExponentCalculator.faqA5: When multiplying numbers with the same base, add the exponents: a^m × a^n = a^(m+n). For example, 2^3 × 2^4 = 2^(3+4) = 2^7 = 128. When dividing, subtract exponents: a^m ÷ a^n = a^(m-n). For example, 3^5 ÷ 3^2 = 3^(5-2) = 3^3 = 27.
ExponentCalculator.faqA6: A fractional exponent like a^(m/n) means take the nth root first, then raise to the mth power. For example, 8^(2/3) = (³√8)^2 = 2^2 = 4. Alternatively, raise to m first then take the nth root: 8^(2/3) = ³√(8^2) = ³√64 = 4. The notation a^(1/n) is the same as the nth root: 16^(1/2) = √16 = 4.

CompoundInterestCalculator.metadataTitle: Compound Interest Calculator - Investment Growth Calculator
CompoundInterestCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate compound interest with monthly contributions. Free online calculator for savings, investments, and retirement planning with detailed breakdowns.
CompoundInterestCalculator.metadataKeywords: compound interest calculator, investment calculator, savings calculator, interest calculator, retirement calculator, future value calculator
CompoundInterestCalculator.title: Compound Interest Calculator
CompoundInterestCalculator.subtitle: Calculate investment growth with compound interest
CompoundInterestCalculator.whatIsContent: Compound interest is interest calculated on both the initial principal and the accumulated interest from previous periods. Unlike simple interest (calculated only on principal), compound interest allows your money to grow exponentially over time. Albert Einstein allegedly called it 'the eighth wonder of the world,' saying 'He who understands it, earns it; he who doesn't, pays it.' The formula is A = P(1 + r/n)^(nt), where A is the final amount, P is principal, r is annual rate, n is compounding frequency per year, and t is time in years.
CompoundInterestCalculator.howToCalculateContent: To calculate compound interest: (1) Determine your principal amount (initial investment), (2) Find your annual interest rate as a decimal (5% = 0.05), (3) Decide how often interest compounds (monthly = 12 times per year, daily = 365), (4) Determine the time period in years. Apply the formula: A = P(1 + r/n)^(nt). For example, $1,000 at 5% compounded monthly for 10 years: A = 1000(1 + 0.05/12)^(12×10) = $1,647.01. If you add monthly contributions, use the annuity formula for the additional amount: FV = PMT × [((1 + r/n)^(nt) - 1) / (r/n)].
CompoundInterestCalculator.benefitsContent: Compound interest is powerful for long-term wealth building: (1) Exponential Growth: Your money grows faster over time as interest earns interest. (2) Time Advantage: Starting early dramatically increases returns - a 25-year-old investing $200/month at 7% will have $528,000 by 65, while starting at 35 yields only $244,000. (3) Passive Income: Once invested, your money works for you automatically. (4) Inflation Protection: Returns often outpace inflation, preserving purchasing power. (5) Retirement Security: Regular contributions with compound interest can build substantial retirement funds. The key is consistency and time - even small amounts grow significantly over decades.
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqQ1: What's the difference between compound and simple interest?
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqA1: Simple interest is calculated only on the principal: I = P × r × t. For $1,000 at 5% for 10 years, you earn $500 total. Compound interest includes interest on previously earned interest, growing exponentially. The same investment compounded annually yields $628.89 in interest - 26% more! The difference becomes dramatic over longer periods.
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqQ2: How often should interest compound for best returns?
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqA2: More frequent compounding yields higher returns. Daily compounding (365 times/year) earns slightly more than monthly (12 times), which beats annual (1 time). However, the difference is small - for $10,000 at 5% over 10 years: annually = $16,289, monthly = $16,470, daily = $16,487. The compounding frequency matters less than the interest rate and time invested.
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqA3: The Rule of 72 estimates how long it takes to double your money: divide 72 by your interest rate. At 6% annual return, your money doubles in approximately 72 ÷ 6 = 12 years. At 9%, it doubles in 8 years (72 ÷ 9). This quick mental math helps you understand investment growth without complex calculations.
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqQ4: Should I make monthly contributions or lump sum investments?
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqA4: Both are valuable! Lump sum investments have more time to compound, but monthly contributions (dollar-cost averaging) are practical for most people and reduce market timing risk. Example: $10,000 lump sum at 7% for 30 years = $76,123. Contributing $27.78/month ($10,000 total) over 30 years = $34,003. The lump sum wins, but monthly contributions are easier to maintain and build discipline.
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqQ5: How does compound interest affect debt?
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqA5: Compound interest works against you in debt! Credit cards often compound daily at high rates (18-24% APR). A $5,000 balance at 20% APR with minimum payments can take 20+ years and cost $8,000+ in interest. This is why paying off high-interest debt should precede investing - you're 'earning' the interest rate by avoiding it.
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqQ6: What's a realistic annual return for investments?
CompoundInterestCalculator.faqA6: Historical stock market returns (S&P 500) average about 10% annually before inflation, or ~7% after inflation. Conservative estimates use 6-8% for long-term planning. Bonds yield 3-5%, savings accounts 1-3%. High-yield savings might offer 4-5%. Use realistic rates in your calculations - assuming 15%+ is overly optimistic and can lead to undersaving for goals.

GcdLcmCalculator.metadataTitle: GCD and LCM Calculator - Greatest Common Divisor & Least Common Multiple
GcdLcmCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate GCD (Greatest Common Divisor) and LCM (Least Common Multiple) for multiple numbers. Free online calculator with step-by-step explanations.
GcdLcmCalculator.metadataKeywords: GCD calculator, LCM calculator, greatest common divisor, least common multiple, HCF calculator, common factor, common multiple
GcdLcmCalculator.title: GCD & LCM Calculator
GcdLcmCalculator.subtitle: Calculate Greatest Common Divisor and Least Common Multiple
GcdLcmCalculator.numbersHint: Separate numbers with commas. You can enter 2 or more numbers.
GcdLcmCalculator.enterAtLeastTwo: Please enter at least 2 positive numbers
GcdLcmCalculator.whatIsContent: GCD (Greatest Common Divisor), also called HCF (Highest Common Factor), is the largest positive integer that divides all given numbers without a remainder. For example, GCD(12, 18) = 6 because 6 is the largest number that divides both 12 and 18 evenly. LCM (Least Common Multiple) is the smallest positive integer that is divisible by all given numbers. For example, LCM(12, 18) = 36 because 36 is the smallest number that both 12 and 18 divide evenly. These concepts are fundamental in number theory, fractions, and many practical applications.
GcdLcmCalculator.howToCalculate: How to Calculate GCD and LCM
GcdLcmCalculator.howToCalculateContent: GCD can be calculated using the Euclidean algorithm: repeatedly divide the larger number by the smaller and replace the larger with the remainder until the remainder is 0. The last non-zero remainder is the GCD. For example, GCD(48, 18): 48 = 18×2 + 12, then 18 = 12×1 + 6, then 12 = 6×2 + 0, so GCD = 6. LCM can be calculated using the formula: LCM(a,b) = (a × b) / GCD(a,b). For example, LCM(12, 18) = (12 × 18) / 6 = 216 / 6 = 36. For more than 2 numbers, find GCD or LCM of the first two, then combine with the third, and so on.
GcdLcmCalculator.commonUses: Common Uses of GCD and LCM
GcdLcmCalculator.commonUsesContent: GCD is used to simplify fractions (divide numerator and denominator by their GCD), find equivalent ratios, solve Diophantine equations, and in cryptography (RSA algorithm). LCM is essential for adding/subtracting fractions with different denominators (find LCM of denominators), scheduling problems (when will two recurring events coincide?), pattern repetition, and synchronization tasks. For example, if buses arrive every 12 and 18 minutes, they'll arrive together every LCM(12,18) = 36 minutes. In music, LCM helps find when different rhythmic patterns align.
GcdLcmCalculator.faqQ1: What's the difference between GCD and LCM?
GcdLcmCalculator.faqA1: GCD is the largest number that divides all given numbers (a divisor, so it's ≤ the smallest number). LCM is the smallest number divisible by all given numbers (a multiple, so it's ≥ the largest number). For 12 and 18: GCD = 6 (divides both), LCM = 36 (divisible by both). They're inversely related: smaller GCD means larger LCM.
GcdLcmCalculator.faqQ2: How do you find GCD of more than 2 numbers?
GcdLcmCalculator.faqA2: Find the GCD of the first two numbers, then find the GCD of that result with the third number, and continue. For example, GCD(12, 18, 24): First GCD(12,18) = 6, then GCD(6,24) = 6. So GCD(12,18,24) = 6. The Euclidean algorithm works for any pair.
GcdLcmCalculator.faqA3: If GCD = 1, the numbers are called 'coprime' or 'relatively prime' - they share no common factors except 1. For example, GCD(15, 28) = 1 because 15 = 3×5 and 28 = 2²×7 have no common prime factors. When numbers are coprime, LCM(a,b) = a×b.
GcdLcmCalculator.faqQ4: How do you use LCM to add fractions?
GcdLcmCalculator.faqA4: To add fractions with different denominators, find the LCM of the denominators to get a common denominator. For 1/4 + 1/6: LCM(4,6) = 12. Convert: 1/4 = 3/12 and 1/6 = 2/12. Add: 3/12 + 2/12 = 5/12. This ensures the smallest common denominator.
GcdLcmCalculator.faqQ5: What's the relationship between GCD and LCM for two numbers?
GcdLcmCalculator.faqA5: For any two positive integers a and b: a × b = GCD(a,b) × LCM(a,b). This is a fundamental property. For example, with 12 and 18: 12 × 18 = 216, and GCD(12,18) × LCM(12,18) = 6 × 36 = 216. This relationship doesn't hold for more than 2 numbers.
GcdLcmCalculator.faqQ6: Can GCD and LCM be calculated for decimals?
GcdLcmCalculator.faqA6: GCD and LCM are defined only for positive integers. For decimals, you can convert to fractions first. For example, to find GCD(0.6, 0.9): convert to 6/10 and 9/10, then GCD(6,9) = 3, so the answer is 3/10 = 0.3. Or multiply by a power of 10 to make them integers, calculate, then divide back.

PercentageChangeCalculator.metadataTitle: Percentage Change Calculator - Calculate Increase & Decrease
PercentageChangeCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate percentage change, increase, or decrease between two values. Free online calculator for comparing old and new values with instant results.
PercentageChangeCalculator.metadataKeywords: percentage change calculator, percent increase, percent decrease, percentage difference, growth rate calculator, change calculator
PercentageChangeCalculator.title: Percentage Change Calculator
PercentageChangeCalculator.subtitle: Calculate the percentage increase or decrease between two values
PercentageChangeCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid numbers. Old value cannot be zero.
PercentageChangeCalculator.whatIsContent: Percentage change measures how much a value has increased or decreased relative to its original value, expressed as a percentage. It's calculated using the formula: ((New Value - Old Value) / Old Value) × 100. A positive result indicates an increase, while a negative result indicates a decrease. For example, if a stock price increases from $100 to $150, the percentage change is +50% because it grew by $50, which is 50% of the original $100. This metric is essential for understanding growth rates, price changes, and comparing changes across different scales.
PercentageChangeCalculator.howToCalculateContent: To calculate percentage change: (1) Subtract the old value from the new value to find the absolute change, (2) Divide the absolute change by the old value (the original amount), (3) Multiply by 100 to convert to a percentage. For example, if sales increase from 200 to 250 units: Change = 250 - 200 = 50, then 50 / 200 = 0.25, finally 0.25 × 100 = 25% increase. For a decrease, the result will be negative. If a price drops from $80 to $60: Change = 60 - 80 = -20, then -20 / 80 = -0.25, finally -0.25 × 100 = -25% (a 25% decrease).
PercentageChangeCalculator.commonUsesContent: Percentage change is widely used in finance (stock price changes, portfolio returns, inflation rates), business (sales growth, profit margins, market share changes), economics (GDP growth, unemployment rate changes), science (population growth, experimental results), and everyday life (price increases, weight loss/gain, test score improvements). It allows fair comparison across different scales - a $10 price increase on a $20 item (50%) is more significant than the same $10 increase on a $1,000 item (1%). This metric helps identify trends, measure performance, and make informed decisions based on relative rather than absolute changes.
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqQ1: What's the difference between percentage change and percentage difference?
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqA1: Percentage change compares a new value to an old value, showing how much something has increased or decreased from a starting point. It's directional (can be positive or negative). Percentage difference compares two values without implying which came first, calculated as |A - B| / ((A + B)/2) × 100. Use percentage change for time-series data (before/after), and percentage difference for comparing two independent values.
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqQ2: Can percentage change be greater than 100%?
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqA2: Yes! A percentage change greater than 100% means the value more than doubled. For example, if something increases from 50 to 150, the change is (150-50)/50 × 100 = 200% - it tripled (increased by 200% of the original). A 100% increase means doubling, 200% means tripling, 300% means quadrupling, and so on.
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqQ3: Why can't the old value be zero?
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqA3: Division by zero is mathematically undefined. The formula requires dividing by the old value, so if it's zero, the calculation is impossible. For example, going from 0 to 100 doesn't have a meaningful percentage change because there's no baseline to compare against. In such cases, describe the change differently (e.g., 'increased from 0 to 100' or 'started at 100').
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqQ4: How do you calculate percentage decrease?
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqA4: Use the same formula as percentage increase. The result will automatically be negative, indicating a decrease. For example, from 200 to 150: (150-200)/200 × 100 = -25%. Some prefer to report this as '25% decrease' (dropping the negative sign), while others keep it as '-25%' to show direction. Both are correct - choose based on context.
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqQ5: What if the change is negative to positive (or vice versa)?
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqA5: The formula still works, but results can be counterintuitive. From -50 to +50: (50-(-50))/-50 × 100 = -200% (a decrease, even though the value went up). This happens because you're dividing by a negative number. For values crossing zero, percentage change is often misleading - use absolute change or describe the situation qualitatively instead.
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqQ6: How do you reverse a percentage change?
PercentageChangeCalculator.faqA6: If something increased by X%, divide by (1 + X/100) to get back. If it decreased by X%, divide by (1 - X/100). For example, if a price increased 25% to $125, the original was $125 / 1.25 = $100. Note: a 50% increase followed by a 50% decrease doesn't return to the original - you end up 25% lower (100 → 150 → 75).

BodyFatCalculator.metadataTitle: Body Fat Calculator - US Navy & BMI Methods | MyCalcOnline
BodyFatCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate your body fat percentage using the US Navy method or BMI formula. Free online body composition calculator with lean mass and fat mass breakdown.
BodyFatCalculator.metadataKeywords: body fat calculator, body fat percentage, US Navy method, body composition, lean mass calculator, fat mass, body fat percentage calculator
BodyFatCalculator.title: Body Fat Calculator
BodyFatCalculator.subtitle: Calculate your body fat percentage using tape measurements or BMI
BodyFatCalculator.navyMethodNote: This method uses circumference measurements and is considered accurate within 3-4% when measured correctly.
BodyFatCalculator.bmiMethodNote: This method estimates body fat from BMI, age, and gender. Less accurate than the Navy method but requires fewer measurements.
BodyFatCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid measurements to calculate body fat percentage.
BodyFatCalculator.whatIsContent: Body fat percentage is the proportion of your total body weight that consists of fat tissue. It's a more accurate indicator of health and fitness than weight alone because it distinguishes between fat mass and lean mass (muscles, bones, organs). Essential fat is necessary for normal body functions - men need at least 2-5% and women need 10-13%. Beyond essential fat, the amount you carry affects your health, appearance, and athletic performance. Athletes typically have lower body fat (6-13% for men, 14-20% for women), while acceptable ranges for general health are 18-24% for men and 25-31% for women.
BodyFatCalculator.howToMeasure: How to Measure for the Navy Method
BodyFatCalculator.howToMeasureContent: For accurate results with the Navy method, use a soft tape measure and measure at these specific points: NECK - Measure just below the larynx (Adam's apple), keeping the tape level. WAIST - For men, measure at the navel level. For women, measure at the narrowest point of the waist. HIP (women only) - Measure at the widest point of the hips and buttocks. Take measurements in the morning before eating, standing relaxed but not sucking in. Measure each point 2-3 times and use the average. Pull the tape snug but not tight enough to compress the skin.
BodyFatCalculator.categoriesContent: Body fat is categorized differently for men and women due to physiological differences. ESSENTIAL FAT (Men: 2-5%, Women: 10-13%): The minimum required for basic physical and physiological health. Going below this is dangerous. ATHLETES (Men: 6-13%, Women: 14-20%): Typical for competitive athletes and those who train intensively. FITNESS (Men: 14-17%, Women: 21-24%): Healthy range for regular exercisers with visible muscle definition. ACCEPTABLE (Men: 18-24%, Women: 25-31%): Average healthy range for most adults. OBESE (Men: 25%+, Women: 32%+): Associated with increased health risks including diabetes, heart disease, and metabolic disorders.
BodyFatCalculator.faqQ1: How accurate is this body fat calculator?
BodyFatCalculator.faqA1: The US Navy method is accurate within 3-4% when measurements are taken correctly. It's more accurate than BMI-based estimates but less precise than methods like DEXA scans or hydrostatic weighing. The BMI-based formula provides a rough estimate and can be off by 5-10%, especially for muscular individuals or those with unusual body compositions.
BodyFatCalculator.faqQ2: Why is body fat percentage better than BMI?
BodyFatCalculator.faqA2: BMI only considers height and weight, so it can't distinguish between muscle and fat. A muscular athlete might have a 'overweight' BMI despite having low body fat. Conversely, someone with little muscle ('skinny fat') might have normal BMI but high body fat. Body fat percentage directly measures what matters for health - the proportion of fat tissue in your body.
BodyFatCalculator.faqQ3: What's the ideal body fat percentage?
BodyFatCalculator.faqA3: It depends on your goals. For general health, 10-20% for men and 18-28% for women is considered healthy. For visible abs, men typically need 10-14% and women 16-20%. Athletes often maintain 6-13% (men) or 14-20% (women) for performance. Very low body fat (below essential levels) is dangerous and unsustainable.
BodyFatCalculator.faqQ4: Why do women have higher body fat percentages?
BodyFatCalculator.faqA4: Women naturally carry more essential fat for reproductive functions, breast tissue, and hormonal regulation. This biological difference means healthy body fat ranges are 8-10% higher for women than men. A woman at 25% body fat and a man at 15% body fat are considered comparably fit.
BodyFatCalculator.faqQ5: How can I reduce my body fat percentage?
BodyFatCalculator.faqA5: Create a moderate caloric deficit (300-500 calories below maintenance) through diet and exercise. Prioritize protein intake (0.7-1g per pound of body weight) to preserve muscle. Include resistance training to build/maintain muscle while losing fat. Add cardio for extra calorie burn. Sleep 7-9 hours and manage stress, as both affect fat storage. Avoid crash diets which cause muscle loss and metabolic adaptation.
BodyFatCalculator.faqQ6: Why does the Navy method need neck measurements?
BodyFatCalculator.faqA6: The Navy formula accounts for how fat distributes across the body. Neck circumference helps calibrate the calculation because people with larger necks relative to their waist tend to have more lean mass. This adjustment improves accuracy compared to using waist measurement alone. The formula was developed by the US Navy in 1984 and is still used by military organizations worldwide.

TimezoneCalculator.metadataTitle: Time Zone Converter - Convert Time Between Cities | MyCalcOnline
TimezoneCalculator.metadataDescription: Convert time between different time zones worldwide. Free online time zone calculator with 35+ major cities and instant conversion results.
TimezoneCalculator.metadataKeywords: time zone converter, time zone calculator, world clock, convert time zones, time difference calculator, international time converter
TimezoneCalculator.title: Time Zone Converter
TimezoneCalculator.subtitle: Convert time between different time zones around the world
TimezoneCalculator.whatIsContent: Time zones are regions of the Earth that observe a uniform standard time. The world is divided into 24 primary time zones, each approximately 15 degrees of longitude wide, corresponding to one hour of time difference. Time zones are based on Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), with zones ranging from UTC-12 to UTC+14. Countries may adjust their time zones for political or practical reasons, and some use 30 or 45-minute offsets. Daylight Saving Time (DST) further complicates time zones, as many regions shift their clocks forward by one hour during summer months.
TimezoneCalculator.howToConvertContent: To convert time between zones: 1) Find the UTC offset for both time zones, 2) Calculate the difference between the offsets, 3) Add or subtract this difference from your starting time. For example, to convert 3:00 PM in New York (UTC-5) to London (UTC+0): The difference is 5 hours, so add 5 hours to get 8:00 PM in London. Be careful when crossing midnight - you may need to change the date. During DST periods, remember that offsets change (e.g., New York becomes UTC-4 in summer).
TimezoneCalculator.commonConversionsContent: Popular conversions include: New York to London (+5 hours), Los Angeles to New York (+3 hours), London to Tokyo (+9 hours), and Sydney to London (-10/11 hours depending on DST). Business hours overlap is crucial for international meetings: when it's 9 AM in New York, it's 2 PM in London, 3 PM in Paris, 10 PM in Tokyo, and midnight in Sydney. The International Date Line (roughly along 180° longitude) is where the calendar date changes - crossing westward adds a day, eastward subtracts a day.
TimezoneCalculator.faqQ1: What is UTC and why is it important?
TimezoneCalculator.faqA1: UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) is the primary time standard by which the world regulates clocks. It replaced GMT as the world's reference time in 1972. UTC doesn't observe Daylight Saving Time, making it a stable reference. All time zones are defined as offsets from UTC (e.g., UTC-5 for New York, UTC+9 for Tokyo). Using UTC as a common reference simplifies international coordination, aviation, computing, and telecommunications.
TimezoneCalculator.faqQ2: How does Daylight Saving Time affect time zones?
TimezoneCalculator.faqA2: DST shifts clocks forward by one hour in spring and back in fall, changing the UTC offset. Not all countries observe DST, and those that do may switch on different dates. For example, the US shifts in March/November while Europe shifts in late March/October. Some regions in the same country observe DST while others don't (like Arizona in the US). This can change time differences between cities temporarily - New York and London are 5 hours apart most of the year but only 4 hours during the brief periods when one has switched but the other hasn't.
TimezoneCalculator.faqQ3: Why do some time zones have 30 or 45-minute offsets?
TimezoneCalculator.faqA3: Some countries adopted non-standard offsets for historical, geographical, or political reasons. India uses UTC+5:30 to have a single time zone for the entire country while being centered between neighboring zones. Nepal uses UTC+5:45 as a symbol of independence from India. Iran uses UTC+3:30, and Afghanistan uses UTC+4:30. Australia's Northern Territory uses UTC+9:30. These half-hour or quarter-hour offsets help certain regions align better with their solar time.
TimezoneCalculator.faqQ4: What is the International Date Line?
TimezoneCalculator.faqA4: The International Date Line (IDL) is an imaginary line running roughly along 180° longitude in the Pacific Ocean. When you cross it going west, you add one day; going east, you subtract one day. This prevents confusion that would occur if you could travel around the world and arrive on a different date. The line isn't straight - it zigzags to keep certain island nations and regions on the same day as their trading partners or parent countries.
TimezoneCalculator.faqQ5: How do I schedule meetings across multiple time zones?
TimezoneCalculator.faqA5: Find overlapping business hours by comparing time zones. Tools like this converter help identify when it's reasonable hours for all parties. For US-Europe calls, morning US time (9-11 AM ET) works well, as it's afternoon in Europe. US-Asia calls are trickier - early morning US or late evening Asia often works. Consider rotating meeting times to share the inconvenience. Always specify the time zone when sending invitations, and use calendar apps that automatically convert times.
TimezoneCalculator.faqQ6: Why does China have only one time zone?
TimezoneCalculator.faqA6: Despite spanning five geographical time zones, China uses a single time zone (UTC+8, Beijing Time) nationwide since 1949 for national unity and administrative simplicity. This means when it's noon in Beijing, it's also officially noon in western regions like Xinjiang, even though solar noon there occurs around 3 PM Beijing time. Some western regions unofficially use 'Xinjiang Time' (UTC+6) in daily life, especially among Uyghur communities, while businesses and government operate on Beijing Time.

QuadraticCalculator.metadataTitle: Quadratic Equation Calculator - Solve ax² + bx + c = 0 | MyCalcOnline
QuadraticCalculator.metadataDescription: Solve quadratic equations instantly with step-by-step solutions. Find real and complex roots, discriminant, vertex, and axis of symmetry. Free online calculator.
QuadraticCalculator.metadataKeywords: quadratic equation calculator, solve quadratic, quadratic formula, find roots, discriminant calculator, ax2+bx+c solver, polynomial solver
QuadraticCalculator.title: Quadratic Equation Calculator
QuadraticCalculator.subtitle: Solve ax² + bx + c = 0 and find roots, discriminant, and vertex
QuadraticCalculator.notQuadratic: When a = 0, the equation is linear, not quadratic. Please enter a non-zero value for a.
QuadraticCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid numbers for coefficients a, b, and c.
QuadraticCalculator.whatIsContent: A quadratic equation is a second-degree polynomial equation in the form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a, b, and c are constants and a ≠ 0. The term 'quadratic' comes from 'quadratus,' the Latin word for square. Quadratic equations always have exactly two solutions (roots), which may be real or complex numbers. The graph of a quadratic function is a parabola - opening upward if a > 0 or downward if a < 0. Quadratic equations appear throughout mathematics, physics, engineering, and economics, modeling everything from projectile motion to profit optimization.
QuadraticCalculator.formulaContent: The quadratic formula x = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac)) / 2a gives the solutions to any quadratic equation ax² + bx + c = 0. The ± symbol means there are two solutions: one using addition and one using subtraction. This formula was known to ancient Babylonians around 2000 BCE, though they used geometric methods. The modern algebraic form was developed by Indian and Islamic mathematicians. The formula works for all quadratic equations, including those with complex solutions when the discriminant is negative.
QuadraticCalculator.discriminantContent: The discriminant Δ = b² - 4ac determines the nature of the roots without calculating them. If Δ > 0, the equation has two distinct real roots (the parabola crosses the x-axis twice). If Δ = 0, there's exactly one real root with multiplicity 2 (the parabola touches the x-axis at its vertex). If Δ < 0, the roots are complex conjugates (the parabola doesn't cross the x-axis). The discriminant also indicates whether a quadratic expression can be factored over the real numbers: it factors nicely if Δ is a perfect square.
QuadraticCalculator.faqQ1: What if my quadratic equation has complex roots?
QuadraticCalculator.faqA1: Complex roots occur when the discriminant (b² - 4ac) is negative. The solutions will be in the form a ± bi, where i = √(-1) is the imaginary unit. Complex roots always come in conjugate pairs - if 3 + 2i is a root, then 3 - 2i is also a root. While complex numbers may seem abstract, they're essential in electrical engineering, quantum mechanics, and signal processing. The parabola doesn't cross the x-axis when roots are complex.
QuadraticCalculator.faqQ2: How do I find the vertex of a parabola?
QuadraticCalculator.faqA2: The vertex of y = ax² + bx + c is at the point (-b/2a, f(-b/2a)), where f(-b/2a) = c - b²/4a. The x-coordinate -b/2a is also the axis of symmetry. If a > 0, the vertex is the minimum point; if a < 0, it's the maximum. The vertex form of a quadratic is y = a(x - h)² + k, where (h, k) is the vertex. You can convert between standard and vertex forms by completing the square.
QuadraticCalculator.faqQ3: Can I solve quadratic equations without the formula?
QuadraticCalculator.faqA3: Yes! Methods include: (1) Factoring - works when the equation factors nicely (e.g., x² - 5x + 6 = (x-2)(x-3) = 0), (2) Completing the square - rewrite as (x + p)² = q and take square roots, (3) Graphing - find where the parabola crosses the x-axis, (4) Square root method - for equations like x² = 9. Factoring is fastest when applicable, but the quadratic formula always works.
QuadraticCalculator.faqQ4: What do the coefficients a, b, and c tell us?
QuadraticCalculator.faqA4: The coefficient 'a' determines the parabola's direction (up if positive, down if negative) and width (larger |a| means narrower). The coefficient 'b' affects the horizontal position of the vertex and axis of symmetry through x = -b/2a. The coefficient 'c' is the y-intercept - where the parabola crosses the y-axis (at point (0, c)). Together, they completely determine the parabola's shape and position.
QuadraticCalculator.faqQ5: What are some real-world applications of quadratic equations?
QuadraticCalculator.faqA5: Quadratics model many phenomena: projectile motion (height vs. time for thrown objects), profit/revenue optimization (maximum profit at optimal price), area problems (maximizing enclosed area with fixed perimeter), physics (kinetic energy, lens equations), engineering (arch bridges, satellite dishes), and economics (supply-demand equilibrium). The vertex often represents the maximum or minimum of whatever is being modeled.
QuadraticCalculator.faqQ6: What's the difference between roots, zeros, and x-intercepts?
QuadraticCalculator.faqA6: These terms are closely related but used in different contexts. 'Roots' or 'solutions' are values of x that satisfy the equation ax² + bx + c = 0. 'Zeros' are values where the function f(x) = ax² + bx + c equals zero. 'X-intercepts' are points where the graph crosses the x-axis, written as (x, 0). For real roots, all three concepts give the same x-values. Complex roots are solutions/zeros but don't correspond to x-intercepts since they're not real numbers.

ProbabilityCalculator.metadataTitle: Probability Calculator - Calculate Event Probability | MyCalcOnline
ProbabilityCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate probability of events with our free online probability calculator. Supports single events, multiple events, conditional probability, and complements.
ProbabilityCalculator.metadataKeywords: probability calculator, event probability, conditional probability, odds calculator, probability formula, statistics calculator
ProbabilityCalculator.title: Probability Calculator
ProbabilityCalculator.subtitle: Calculate the probability of events with multiple calculation modes
ProbabilityCalculator.whatIsContent: Probability is a measure of the likelihood that an event will occur. It is quantified as a number between 0 and 1, where 0 indicates impossibility and 1 indicates certainty. Probability theory is fundamental to statistics, gambling, science, artificial intelligence, and everyday decision-making. The probability of an event E, written as P(E), can be calculated as the ratio of favorable outcomes to the total number of possible outcomes when all outcomes are equally likely. Understanding probability helps us make informed decisions under uncertainty.
ProbabilityCalculator.formulasContent: BASIC PROBABILITY: P(E) = favorable outcomes / total outcomes. For a fair die, P(rolling 3) = 1/6. COMPLEMENT: P(A') = 1 - P(A). If P(rain) = 0.3, then P(no rain) = 0.7. ADDITION RULE: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B). For mutually exclusive events (can't both happen): P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B). MULTIPLICATION RULE: For independent events: P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B). For dependent events: P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B|A). CONDITIONAL: P(B|A) = P(A and B) / P(A), the probability of B given that A has occurred.
ProbabilityCalculator.examplesContent: COIN FLIP: P(heads) = 1/2 = 0.5 = 50%. Two heads in a row: 0.5 × 0.5 = 0.25 = 25%. DICE: P(rolling 6) = 1/6 ≈ 16.67%. P(rolling even) = 3/6 = 1/2 = 50%. CARDS: P(drawing ace) = 4/52 = 1/13 ≈ 7.69%. P(heart) = 13/52 = 1/4 = 25%. COMPLEMENT: If P(rain) = 30%, P(no rain) = 70%. MULTIPLE EVENTS: If P(A) = 0.4 and P(B) = 0.3 are independent, P(A and B) = 0.4 × 0.3 = 0.12, P(A or B) = 0.4 + 0.3 - 0.12 = 0.58.
ProbabilityCalculator.faqQ1: What's the difference between probability and odds?
ProbabilityCalculator.faqA1: Probability expresses likelihood as a ratio of favorable outcomes to total outcomes (e.g., 1/4 or 25%). Odds express the ratio of favorable to unfavorable outcomes (e.g., 1:3 means 1 success for every 3 failures). To convert: if probability is p, odds for are p/(1-p) and odds against are (1-p)/p. For 25% probability, odds for are 0.25/0.75 = 1:3, meaning for every 1 time it happens, it won't happen 3 times.
ProbabilityCalculator.faqQ2: What are independent and dependent events?
ProbabilityCalculator.faqA2: Independent events don't affect each other's probability - coin flips are independent because one flip doesn't change the next. Dependent events affect each other - drawing cards without replacement is dependent because each draw changes the remaining possibilities. For independent events, P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B). For dependent events, you need P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B|A), where P(B|A) is the probability of B given that A happened.
ProbabilityCalculator.faqA3: Conditional probability P(B|A) is the probability of B occurring given that A has already occurred. For example, P(heart | red card) = 1/2 because half of the red cards are hearts. The formula is P(B|A) = P(A and B) / P(A). Conditional probability is essential in medical testing (probability of disease given positive test), weather forecasting, and Bayesian statistics.
ProbabilityCalculator.faqQ4: When should I use AND vs OR probability?
ProbabilityCalculator.faqA4: Use AND (intersection, P(A∩B)) when you want BOTH events to happen - like rolling two 6s in a row, or picking a card that's both red AND a face card. Use OR (union, P(A∪B)) when you want AT LEAST ONE to happen - like rolling a 6 OR a 5, or picking a card that's red OR a face card. AND typically gives smaller probabilities, OR gives larger probabilities.
ProbabilityCalculator.faqQ5: What is the complement of an event?
ProbabilityCalculator.faqA5: The complement of event A (written as A' or 'not A') includes all outcomes where A doesn't happen. Since something either happens or it doesn't, P(A) + P(A') = 1, so P(A') = 1 - P(A). Complements are useful when it's easier to calculate 'not happening' - for example, P(at least one head in 3 flips) is easier calculated as 1 - P(all tails) = 1 - (1/2)³ = 7/8.
ProbabilityCalculator.faqA6: The Gambler's Fallacy is the mistaken belief that past random events affect future probabilities. After flipping 10 heads in a row, the probability of the next flip being heads is still exactly 50% - coins have no memory. Similarly, 'hot' or 'cold' streaks in gambling are psychological, not statistical. Each independent event has the same probability regardless of what came before. This fallacy leads to poor decisions in casinos, investments, and everyday risk assessment.
ProbabilityCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid numbers. For probabilities, use values between 0 and 1.

CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate combinations, permutations, and factorials with our free online calculator. Supports with and without repetition. Get instant results with formulas.
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.metadataKeywords: combinations calculator, permutations calculator, factorial calculator, nCr, nPr, combinatorics, probability, statistics
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.title: Combinations & Permutations Calculator
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.subtitle: Calculate combinations, permutations, and factorials instantly
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.allowRepetition: Allow repetition (items can be selected more than once)
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.combinationDesc: Number of ways to choose r items from n items (order doesn't matter)
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.combinationRepDesc: Number of ways to choose r items from n items with repetition allowed
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.permutationDesc: Number of ways to arrange r items from n items (order matters)
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.permutationRepDesc: Number of ways to arrange r items from n items with repetition allowed
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.factorialDesc: Product of all positive integers up to n
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.whatIsContent: Combinations and permutations are fundamental concepts in combinatorics, the branch of mathematics dealing with counting. A COMBINATION is a selection of items where ORDER DOESN'T MATTER - choosing cards A, B, C is the same as choosing C, B, A. A PERMUTATION is an arrangement where ORDER MATTERS - the password ABC is different from CBA. Factorials (n!) are the building blocks for both calculations, representing the product of all positive integers from 1 to n. These concepts are essential in probability, statistics, cryptography, and computer science. For example, lottery odds use combinations (order of numbers drawn doesn't matter), while arranging books on a shelf uses permutations (order matters).
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.formulasContent: FACTORIAL: n! = n × (n-1) × (n-2) × ... × 2 × 1. Example: 5! = 5×4×3×2×1 = 120. Special cases: 0! = 1 and 1! = 1. COMBINATION without repetition: C(n,r) = n! / (r! × (n-r)!). This counts ways to choose r items from n items where order doesn't matter. Example: C(5,2) = 5!/(2!×3!) = 10 ways to choose 2 items from 5. COMBINATION with repetition: C(n+r-1,r) = (n+r-1)! / (r! × (n-1)!). Used when items can be selected multiple times. PERMUTATION without repetition: P(n,r) = n! / (n-r)!. This counts ordered arrangements. Example: P(5,2) = 5!/3! = 20 ways to arrange 2 items from 5. PERMUTATION with repetition: P(n,r) = n^r. Each position can be any of n items.
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.examplesContent: LOTTERY (Combination): Picking 6 numbers from 49 where order doesn't matter: C(49,6) = 13,983,816 possible combinations. PASSWORDS (Permutation with repetition): A 4-digit PIN using digits 0-9: P(10,4) = 10^4 = 10,000 possible PINs. COMMITTEE (Combination): Selecting 3 members from 10 candidates: C(10,3) = 120 different committees possible. RACE FINISHING (Permutation): First, second, third place from 8 runners: P(8,3) = 336 different podium outcomes. CARD HANDS (Combination): 5-card poker hand from 52 cards: C(52,5) = 2,598,960 possible hands. ICE CREAM SCOOPS (Combination with repetition): Choosing 3 scoops from 5 flavors, repetition allowed: C(5+3-1,3) = 35 combinations.
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.faqQ1: What's the difference between combinations and permutations?
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.faqA1: The key difference is ORDER. In combinations, order doesn't matter - selecting items A, B, C is the same as C, B, A (one combination). In permutations, order matters - ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA are all different (six permutations). Use combinations when you're just selecting a group. Use permutations when the arrangement or sequence matters.
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.faqA2: Use 'with repetition' when the same item can be chosen more than once. Examples: creating a PIN (you can use the same digit multiple times), choosing ice cream scoops (you can pick the same flavor twice), or combinations with replacement in statistics. Without repetition means once an item is chosen, it can't be chosen again - like dealing cards from a deck.
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.faqA3: This is defined mathematically for consistency. One way to understand it: n! represents the number of ways to arrange n items. There's exactly ONE way to arrange zero items - do nothing. Also, the formula n! = n × (n-1)! requires 0! = 1 to work for 1! = 1 × 0! = 1. This convention keeps formulas like C(n,0) = 1 (there's one way to choose nothing) working correctly.
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.faqQ4: What's the maximum number I can calculate?
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.faqA4: This calculator handles very large numbers using BigInt, but has practical limits. Factorials grow extremely fast: 20! is already 2.4 quintillion, and 170! is about 7×10^306. Numbers beyond n=170 would overflow most systems. For combinations and permutations, the result depends on both n and r. The calculator will show an error if the input would produce an overflow.
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.faqQ5: How are these used in probability?
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.faqA5: Combinations and permutations are essential for calculating probability. Probability = (favorable outcomes) / (total outcomes). To find 'total outcomes' in many situations, you need combinations or permutations. Example: Probability of being dealt a flush in poker = C(13,5) × 4 / C(52,5) ≈ 0.2%. The C(13,5) counts ways to get 5 cards of one suit, times 4 suits, divided by all possible 5-card hands.
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.faqQ6: What's the relationship between nCr and Pascal's Triangle?
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.faqA6: Pascal's Triangle is a triangular array where each number is the sum of the two numbers above it. The nth row (starting from 0) contains all values of C(n,r) for r from 0 to n. For example, row 4 is [1, 4, 6, 4, 1], representing C(4,0), C(4,1), C(4,2), C(4,3), C(4,4). This relationship gives us C(n,r) = C(n-1,r-1) + C(n-1,r), and is connected to binomial expansion (a+b)^n.
CombinationsPermutationsCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid numbers. For combinations/permutations without repetition, r must be ≤ n. Maximum n is 170.

ZScoreCalculator.metadataTitle: Z-Score Calculator - Standard Score & Percentile | MyCalcOnline
ZScoreCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate z-scores, convert between raw scores and standard scores, and find probabilities. Free online z-score calculator with percentile rankings.
ZScoreCalculator.metadataKeywords: z-score calculator, standard score, z value, normal distribution, percentile calculator, statistics, standard deviation
ZScoreCalculator.title: Z-Score Calculator
ZScoreCalculator.subtitle: Calculate z-scores, raw scores, and probabilities for normal distributions
ZScoreCalculator.whatIsContent: A z-score (also called standard score) measures how many standard deviations a data point is from the mean. It standardizes values from any normal distribution to a standard normal distribution (mean = 0, standard deviation = 1). Z-scores are fundamental in statistics for comparing values from different distributions, finding percentiles, and calculating probabilities. A positive z-score means the value is above the mean, while a negative z-score means it's below. About 68% of data falls within ±1 standard deviation (z between -1 and 1), 95% within ±2, and 99.7% within ±3 - this is the empirical rule or 68-95-99.7 rule.
ZScoreCalculator.formulaContent: Z-SCORE FORMULA: Z = (X - μ) / σ, where X is the raw score, μ (mu) is the population mean, and σ (sigma) is the standard deviation. This transforms any value to its position on the standard normal distribution. REVERSE FORMULA: X = μ + Z × σ converts a z-score back to the original scale. PROBABILITY: The cumulative distribution function Φ(z) gives the probability that a random value is less than or equal to z. For example, Φ(0) = 0.5 (50% of values are below the mean), Φ(1.96) ≈ 0.975 (97.5% below), and Φ(-1.96) ≈ 0.025 (2.5% below). The area between two z-scores gives the probability of falling in that range.
ZScoreCalculator.examplesContent: IQ SCORES: IQ tests have mean=100, SD=15. An IQ of 130: Z = (130-100)/15 = 2.0, meaning 2 standard deviations above average, approximately 98th percentile. TEST SCORES: On a test with mean=75, SD=10, a score of 60: Z = (60-75)/10 = -1.5, or 1.5 SDs below average, about 7th percentile. HEIGHT: US adult male height has mean=69.1 inches, SD=2.9. A 74-inch man: Z = (74-69.1)/2.9 = 1.69, about 95th percentile. FINDING CUTOFFS: To find the score at the 90th percentile (Z ≈ 1.28) on a test with mean=500, SD=100: X = 500 + 1.28 × 100 = 628.
ZScoreCalculator.faqQ1: What does a z-score of 0 mean?
ZScoreCalculator.faqA1: A z-score of 0 means the value is exactly at the mean. Since z = (X - μ) / σ, when X equals the mean (μ), the numerator becomes 0, so z = 0. This is the center of the normal distribution. Approximately 50% of values fall below and 50% above a z-score of 0.
ZScoreCalculator.faqA2: It depends on context. In testing, higher is usually better, so z = 2 (top ~2.3%) is excellent. In manufacturing, z-scores near 0 indicate products close to target specifications. In statistics, z-scores beyond ±2 are often considered unusual (outside 95% of data), and beyond ±3 are rare outliers (outside 99.7%). 'Six Sigma' quality aims for defect rates at z = ±6.
ZScoreCalculator.faqQ3: How do I interpret percentiles from z-scores?
ZScoreCalculator.faqA3: A percentile tells you what percentage of the distribution falls below your value. Z = 0 → 50th percentile (average), Z = 1 → 84th percentile, Z = 2 → 98th percentile, Z = -1 → 16th percentile, Z = -2 → 2nd percentile. For example, if your SAT score has z = 1.5, you scored higher than about 93% of test-takers.
ZScoreCalculator.faqQ4: Can z-scores be greater than 3 or less than -3?
ZScoreCalculator.faqA4: Yes, but they're rare in normally distributed data. Only about 0.3% of values fall beyond ±3 standard deviations. However, in large datasets or non-normal distributions, extreme z-scores are more common. Values beyond ±3 are often investigated as potential outliers or data errors, though they can be legitimate in some contexts.
ZScoreCalculator.faqQ5: What's the difference between z-score and t-score?
ZScoreCalculator.faqA5: Z-scores use the standard normal distribution and assume you know the population standard deviation. T-scores use the t-distribution and are used when working with sample standard deviations, especially with small samples (n < 30). As sample size increases, the t-distribution approaches the normal distribution. T-tests use t-scores; z-tests use z-scores.
ZScoreCalculator.faqQ6: Why is the normal distribution so important?
ZScoreCalculator.faqA6: The normal distribution appears naturally in many phenomena (heights, test scores, measurement errors) due to the Central Limit Theorem: when you average many random factors, the result tends toward normal distribution. This makes z-scores universally applicable for comparing data, calculating probabilities, and making statistical inferences. Many statistical tests assume normality.
ZScoreCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid numbers. Standard deviation must be greater than 0.

TTestCalculator.metadataTitle: T-Test Calculator - One Sample, Two Sample, Paired | MyCalcOnline
TTestCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate t-tests online with our free calculator. Supports one-sample, two-sample (independent), and paired t-tests. Get t-statistic, p-value, and significance.
TTestCalculator.metadataKeywords: t-test calculator, student t test, one sample t test, two sample t test, paired t test, p-value calculator, hypothesis testing
TTestCalculator.title: T-Test Calculator
TTestCalculator.subtitle: Perform hypothesis testing with t-tests for statistical significance
TTestCalculator.notSignificant: Not statistically significant at α = 0.05 level
TTestCalculator.whatIsContent: A t-test is a statistical hypothesis test used to determine if there is a significant difference between means. Developed by William Sealy Gosset under the pseudonym 'Student' in 1908, it's one of the most common statistical tests. The ONE-SAMPLE t-test compares a sample mean to a known or hypothesized population mean. The TWO-SAMPLE (independent) t-test compares means of two separate groups. The PAIRED t-test compares means from the same group at different times or under different conditions. T-tests assume the data is approximately normally distributed and use the t-distribution, which accounts for uncertainty when sample sizes are small.
TTestCalculator.formulaContent: ONE-SAMPLE: t = (x̄ - μ₀) / (s / √n), where x̄ is sample mean, μ₀ is hypothesized mean, s is sample standard deviation, n is sample size. df = n - 1. TWO-SAMPLE (Welch's): t = (x̄₁ - x̄₂) / √(s₁²/n₁ + s₂²/n₂). Degrees of freedom calculated using Welch-Satterthwaite equation. PAIRED: t = d̄ / (sᵈ / √n), where d̄ is mean of differences, sᵈ is standard deviation of differences. df = n - 1. The p-value is then calculated from the t-distribution with the appropriate degrees of freedom.
TTestCalculator.examplesContent: ONE-SAMPLE: A class of 25 students has mean test score 78 with SD 12. Is this different from the national average of 75? t = (78-75)/(12/√25) = 1.25, df=24, p≈0.22. Not significant at α=0.05. TWO-SAMPLE: Drug group (n=30, mean=85, SD=10) vs placebo (n=28, mean=78, SD=12). t = (85-78)/√(100/30+144/28) = 2.48, p≈0.016. Significant at α=0.05. PAIRED: 15 patients' blood pressure before/after treatment. Mean difference = -8, SD of differences = 6. t = -8/(6/√15) = -5.16, p<0.001. Highly significant.
TTestCalculator.faqQ1: When should I use a t-test vs z-test?
TTestCalculator.faqA1: Use a t-test when you're working with sample data and don't know the population standard deviation (which is almost always the case). Z-tests require knowing the population standard deviation and are mainly used with very large samples (n > 30) or when testing proportions. For most practical purposes involving means, t-tests are the appropriate choice.
TTestCalculator.faqQ2: What's the difference between one-tailed and two-tailed tests?
TTestCalculator.faqA2: A two-tailed test checks if there's any difference (higher or lower), while a one-tailed test only checks for difference in one direction. Use two-tailed when you just want to know if groups differ. Use one-tailed only when you have a specific directional hypothesis before collecting data (e.g., 'the new drug will increase scores'). Two-tailed is more conservative and generally preferred.
TTestCalculator.faqA3: The p-value is the probability of getting results as extreme as yours if there were actually no difference (null hypothesis true). A small p-value (typically < 0.05) suggests the difference is unlikely due to chance alone, so we 'reject the null hypothesis.' It does NOT tell you the size or importance of the effect, just whether it's statistically detectable.
TTestCalculator.faqA4: Degrees of freedom (df) represent the number of independent pieces of information in your data. For a one-sample t-test, df = n - 1 because once you know the mean and n-1 values, the last value is determined. More df means the t-distribution is closer to normal. The df affects the critical values and p-value calculation.
TTestCalculator.faqQ5: When should I use paired vs independent t-tests?
TTestCalculator.faqA5: Use paired t-test when measurements come from the same subjects (before/after studies, matched pairs, repeated measures). Use independent (two-sample) t-test when comparing two separate groups of different subjects. Paired tests are more powerful because they control for individual variation, but require the paired relationship to be meaningful.
TTestCalculator.faqQ6: What if my data isn't normally distributed?
TTestCalculator.faqA6: T-tests are fairly robust to mild violations of normality, especially with larger samples (n > 30) due to the Central Limit Theorem. For severely non-normal data with small samples, consider: (1) transforming the data (log, square root), (2) using non-parametric alternatives like Mann-Whitney U test or Wilcoxon signed-rank test, or (3) bootstrapping methods.
TTestCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid numbers. Standard deviation must be greater than 0, and sample size must be at least 2.

OhmsLawCalculator.metadataTitle: Ohm's Law Calculator - Voltage, Current, Resistance, Power | MyCalcOnline
OhmsLawCalculator.metadataDescription: Calculate voltage, current, resistance, and power using Ohm's Law. Free online calculator for electronics with V=IR and P=VI formulas.
OhmsLawCalculator.metadataKeywords: ohms law calculator, voltage calculator, current calculator, resistance calculator, power calculator, V=IR, electronics calculator
OhmsLawCalculator.title: Ohm's Law Calculator
OhmsLawCalculator.subtitle: Calculate voltage, current, resistance, and power for electrical circuits
OhmsLawCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
OhmsLawCalculator.formulaDescription: Voltage = Current × Resistance | Power = Voltage × Current
OhmsLawCalculator.whatIsContent: Ohm's Law is a fundamental principle in electrical engineering that describes the relationship between voltage (V), current (I), and resistance (R) in an electrical circuit. Discovered by German physicist Georg Simon Ohm in 1827, it states that the current through a conductor is directly proportional to the voltage across it and inversely proportional to its resistance. The formula V = I × R is the foundation of circuit analysis. Combined with the power equation P = V × I, these relationships allow us to calculate any electrical quantity when two others are known. Ohm's Law applies to 'ohmic' materials where resistance remains constant regardless of voltage.
OhmsLawCalculator.formulasContent: VOLTAGE (V): V = I × R = P / I = √(P × R). Measured in Volts (V). Voltage is the electrical pressure that pushes current through a circuit. CURRENT (I): I = V / R = P / V = √(P / R). Measured in Amperes/Amps (A). Current is the flow of electrical charge. RESISTANCE (R): R = V / I = V² / P = P / I². Measured in Ohms (Ω). Resistance opposes the flow of current. POWER (P): P = V × I = V² / R = I² × R. Measured in Watts (W). Power is the rate of energy transfer. These 12 formulas (3 for each quantity) form the 'Ohm's Law Wheel' used by electricians and engineers.
OhmsLawCalculator.examplesContent: LED CIRCUIT: An LED needs 2V and 20mA. With a 12V supply, what resistor is needed? R = (12-2)/0.02 = 500Ω. CAR HEADLIGHT: A 55W headlight on a 12V system draws I = 55/12 = 4.58A of current. PHONE CHARGER: A 5V/2A charger delivers P = 5 × 2 = 10W. The phone's charging circuit has effective resistance R = 5/2 = 2.5Ω. HOME APPLIANCE: A 1500W heater on 120V draws I = 1500/120 = 12.5A. Its resistance is R = 120/12.5 = 9.6Ω. BATTERY CAPACITY: A 12V car battery delivering 100A has internal resistance causing voltage drop V = I × R_internal.
OhmsLawCalculator.faqQ1: Why doesn't Ohm's Law work for all components?
OhmsLawCalculator.faqA1: Ohm's Law only applies to 'ohmic' or 'linear' components where resistance stays constant regardless of voltage or current. Many real components are 'non-ohmic': diodes conduct in one direction only, LEDs need minimum voltage to turn on, incandescent bulbs change resistance with temperature, and transistors have complex V-I relationships. For these, we use more complex models or measure V-I curves directly.
OhmsLawCalculator.faqQ2: What's the difference between AC and DC for Ohm's Law?
OhmsLawCalculator.faqA2: Ohm's Law V = IR applies directly to DC (direct current) circuits. For AC (alternating current), we replace resistance with 'impedance' (Z), which includes resistance plus the effects of capacitors and inductors. The formula becomes V = IZ. AC calculations also involve phase angles and often use complex numbers or phasor notation.
OhmsLawCalculator.faqQ3: How do I calculate power dissipation for component selection?
OhmsLawCalculator.faqA3: Use P = I²R or P = V²/R to find power dissipation. Always choose components rated higher than calculated - typically 2x for safety margin. For example, if a resistor dissipates 0.3W, use at least a 0.5W or 1W rated resistor. Excess power becomes heat, which can damage components or cause fires.
OhmsLawCalculator.faqQ4: What happens if resistance is zero?
OhmsLawCalculator.faqA4: If R = 0 (a short circuit), Ohm's Law predicts infinite current (I = V/0). In reality, current is limited by wire resistance, power source limitations, and safety devices like fuses or circuit breakers. Short circuits are dangerous - they cause extreme heating, fires, and equipment damage. This is why overcurrent protection is essential in all circuits.
OhmsLawCalculator.faqQ5: How do series and parallel circuits affect calculations?
OhmsLawCalculator.faqA5: In SERIES: resistances add (R_total = R1 + R2 + ...), current is the same through all components, voltages add up to total. In PARALLEL: use 1/R_total = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + ..., voltage is the same across all branches, currents add up to total. Power in both cases: P_total = P1 + P2 + ... Most real circuits combine both series and parallel elements.
OhmsLawCalculator.faqA6: For consistent results, use base SI units: Volts (V), Amperes (A), Ohms (Ω), and Watts (W). Common prefixes: milli (m) = 10⁻³, kilo (k) = 10³, mega (M) = 10⁶. So 4.7kΩ = 4700Ω, 20mA = 0.02A. Mixing units is a common error - always convert to base units before calculating. For example: 12V across 4.7kΩ gives I = 12/4700 = 0.00255A = 2.55mA.
OhmsLawCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter at least two valid values to calculate the others. Values must be positive numbers.

DensityCalculator.title: Density Calculator
DensityCalculator.subtitle: Calculate density, mass, or volume using the density formula
DensityCalculator.metadataTitle: Density Calculator - Calculate Density, Mass, Volume Online
