DensityCalculator.metadataDescription: Free density calculator. Calculate density (ρ = m/V), mass, or volume. Essential tool for physics, chemistry, and engineering.
DensityCalculator.metadataKeywords: density calculator, mass volume calculator, density formula, kg/m3, physics calculator, material density
DensityCalculator.selectCalculation: What would you like to calculate?
DensityCalculator.formulaDescription: ρ = Density (kg/m³) | m = Mass (kg) | V = Volume (m³)
DensityCalculator.whatIsContent: Density is a fundamental physical property that measures how much mass is contained in a given volume. Defined as mass per unit volume (ρ = m/V), density determines whether objects float or sink, how materials respond to forces, and their thermal properties. First precisely formulated by Archimedes around 250 BC through his famous bath discovery, density is measured in kg/m³ (SI units), though g/cm³ and lb/ft³ are also common. Water has a density of 1000 kg/m³ (1 g/cm³) at 4°C, which serves as a convenient reference point. Different materials have vastly different densities: osmium (22,590 kg/m³) is the densest naturally occurring element, while hydrogen gas (0.09 kg/m³) is among the least dense. Density is crucial in fields from materials science to oceanography, helping us understand why ice floats, how submarines control buoyancy, and which materials are best for specific engineering applications.
DensityCalculator.formulaContent: BASIC FORMULA: ρ = m / V, where ρ (rho) is density, m is mass, and V is volume. CALCULATE DENSITY: ρ = m / V. Divide mass by volume. For example, 10 kg divided by 0.01 m³ gives 1000 kg/m³ (water). CALCULATE MASS: m = ρ × V. Multiply density by volume. A 2 m³ block of iron (7870 kg/m³) has mass 15,740 kg. CALCULATE VOLUME: V = m / ρ. Divide mass by density. 1000 kg of aluminum (2700 kg/m³) occupies 0.37 m³. UNIT CONVERSIONS: 1 g/cm³ = 1000 kg/m³. 1 lb/ft³ = 16.02 kg/m³. RELATIVE DENSITY (Specific Gravity): SG = ρ_material / ρ_water. Dimensionless ratio comparing material density to water (1000 kg/m³).
DensityCalculator.examplesContent: EXAMPLE 1: A gold bar measures 10cm × 5cm × 2cm and has mass 1.93 kg. What's its density? V = 0.1 × 0.05 × 0.02 = 0.0001 m³. ρ = 1.93 / 0.0001 = 19,300 kg/m³ (confirms it's gold). EXAMPLE 2: You need to fill a 5 m³ swimming pool. How much does the water weigh? m = 1000 × 5 = 5000 kg (5 metric tons). EXAMPLE 3: An iceberg with density 917 kg/m³ weighs 10,000 kg. What's its volume? V = 10,000 / 917 = 10.9 m³. EXAMPLE 4: A piece of wood floats in water (density 600 kg/m³). What fraction is submerged? Submerged fraction = 600/1000 = 0.6 = 60%.
DensityCalculator.faqQ1: Why do some objects float and others sink?
DensityCalculator.faqA1: Objects float when their average density is less than the fluid they're in, and sink when denser. A steel ship floats despite steel's high density (7850 kg/m³) because its hollow hull creates an average density less than water (1000 kg/m³). Ice floats on water because ice is less dense (917 kg/m³) - unusual since most solids are denser than their liquid form. Hot air balloons rise because heated air is less dense than cool air.
DensityCalculator.faqQ2: Does density change with temperature or pressure?
DensityCalculator.faqA2: Yes! For most materials, density decreases as temperature increases (thermal expansion). Water is unusual - it's densest at 4°C and expands both when cooled (forming ice) and heated. Gases are highly compressible, so their density changes dramatically with pressure (ideal gas: ρ ∝ P/T). Liquids and solids compress much less, with density changes typically <1% even at extreme pressures.
DensityCalculator.faqA3: GASES (at STP): Air ~1.2, Hydrogen ~0.09, CO₂ ~1.98 kg/m³. LIQUIDS: Water 1000, Oil 920, Mercury 13,600 kg/m³. SOLIDS: Ice 917, Wood 400-800, Aluminum 2700, Steel 7850, Copper 8960, Lead 11,340, Gold 19,300, Osmium 22,590 kg/m³. The huge range - from 0.09 (H₂) to 22,590 (Os) - spans five orders of magnitude!
DensityCalculator.faqQ4: How do you measure density experimentally?
DensityCalculator.faqA4: REGULAR SHAPES: Measure dimensions to calculate volume, weigh to get mass, divide. IRREGULAR OBJECTS: Use water displacement (Archimedes method) - submerge object in graduated cylinder, volume equals water rise. Mass from scale. FLOATING OBJECTS: Force them underwater with a pin, or use Archimedes principle (weight_in_air - weight_in_water = weight_of_displaced_water). PRECISION METHODS: Pycnometer for liquids, gas displacement for porous materials.
DensityCalculator.faqQ5: What's the difference between density and specific gravity?
DensityCalculator.faqA5: Density is an absolute measure (kg/m³), while specific gravity (relative density) is a dimensionless ratio comparing material density to a reference (usually water at 4°C, 1000 kg/m³). Specific gravity = ρ_material / 1000. A material with SG = 2.5 has density 2500 kg/m³. Specific gravity is convenient because it's unitless and indicates floating behavior directly: SG < 1 floats, SG > 1 sinks.
DensityCalculator.faqQ6: Why is density important in real applications?
DensityCalculator.faqA6: ENGINEERING: Select materials balancing strength and weight (aircraft use aluminum, density 2700 vs steel 7850). GEOLOGY: Oil (density ~900) floats on water (1000), enabling extraction. METEOROLOGY: Air density differences drive weather. MEDICINE: Bone density scans detect osteoporosis. QUALITY CONTROL: Check if materials are pure (gold should be 19,300 kg/m³). SAFETY: Proper ballast keeps ships stable. Understanding density is essential across science and industry.
DensityCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid positive numbers for at least two quantities to calculate the third.

ForceCalculator.title: Force Calculator
ForceCalculator.subtitle: Calculate force, mass, or acceleration using Newton's Second Law
ForceCalculator.metadataTitle: Force Calculator - Calculate F, m, a using F=ma | Newton's Law
ForceCalculator.metadataDescription: Free force calculator using Newton's Second Law. Calculate force (F=ma), mass, or acceleration. Essential physics tool for students and engineers.
ForceCalculator.metadataKeywords: force calculator, newton's second law, F=ma calculator, mass acceleration, physics calculator, newtons calculator
ForceCalculator.selectCalculation: What would you like to calculate?
ForceCalculator.formulaDescription: F = Force (N) | m = Mass (kg) | a = Acceleration (m/s²)
ForceCalculator.whatIsContent: Force is a fundamental concept in physics that describes any interaction that changes the motion of an object. Defined by Newton's Second Law of Motion (F = ma), force equals mass times acceleration. A force can cause an object with mass to change its velocity (accelerate), meaning to begin moving, stop moving, or change direction. Force is measured in Newtons (N) in the SI system, named after Sir Isaac Newton who formulated the laws of motion in 1687. One Newton is the force required to accelerate a 1 kg mass by 1 m/s². Forces are vectors, meaning they have both magnitude and direction. Common examples include gravity (weight = mg, where g ≈ 9.8 m/s² on Earth), friction, tension, normal force, and applied forces. Understanding force is essential for analyzing motion in mechanics, engineering, sports, and everyday life - from why cars need brakes to how rockets launch into space.
ForceCalculator.formulaContent: BASIC FORMULA: F = m × a, where F is force (Newtons), m is mass (kilograms), and a is acceleration (meters per second squared). CALCULATE FORCE: F = m × a. A 10 kg object accelerating at 5 m/s² experiences 50 N of force. CALCULATE MASS: m = F / a. A 100 N force causing 2 m/s² acceleration acts on a 50 kg mass. CALCULATE ACCELERATION: a = F / m. A 60 N force on a 20 kg object produces 3 m/s² acceleration. WEIGHT CALCULATION: Weight is a special case where a = g (gravitational acceleration ≈ 9.8 m/s² on Earth). Weight (N) = mass (kg) × 9.8. A 70 kg person weighs 686 N. NET FORCE: When multiple forces act on an object, calculate the net (total) force by vector addition. F_net determines acceleration via F_net = m × a.
ForceCalculator.examplesContent: EXAMPLE 1: A car with mass 1500 kg accelerates from rest to 20 m/s in 10 seconds. What force does the engine apply? a = (20-0)/10 = 2 m/s². F = 1500 × 2 = 3000 N. EXAMPLE 2: A person weighs 180 N on the Moon (g = 1.6 m/s²). What's their mass? m = F/a = 180/1.6 = 112.5 kg. Same person on Earth weighs 112.5 × 9.8 = 1102.5 N. EXAMPLE 3: A 5000 N rocket force acts on a 500 kg spacecraft in space. What's the acceleration? a = 5000/500 = 10 m/s². EXAMPLE 4: Brakes apply 8000 N force to stop a 1600 kg car. Deceleration = 8000/1600 = 5 m/s² (negative acceleration).
ForceCalculator.faqQ1: What's the difference between mass and weight?
ForceCalculator.faqA1: Mass is the amount of matter in an object, measured in kilograms (kg), and is constant everywhere in the universe. Weight is the force of gravity acting on that mass, measured in Newtons (N), and varies with gravitational field strength. Weight = mass × g. A 70 kg person has mass 70 kg everywhere, but weighs 686 N on Earth (g=9.8), 115 N on the Moon (g=1.6), and nearly 0 N in deep space. Weight changes, mass doesn't.
ForceCalculator.faqA2: Yes! Multiple forces can act on an object with zero net force, producing no acceleration (Newton's First Law - equilibrium). For example, a book resting on a table experiences downward gravitational force (weight) and upward normal force from the table. These equal and opposite forces cancel out (F_net = 0), so a = 0. The object remains at rest or moves at constant velocity. Force exists, but balanced forces produce zero acceleration.
ForceCalculator.faqQ3: What are common types of forces?
ForceCalculator.faqA3: GRAVITY: F = mg pulls objects toward Earth (or other masses). NORMAL: Perpendicular contact force from surfaces. FRICTION: Opposes sliding motion, F_friction ≤ μN. TENSION: Pull force through ropes/cables. APPLIED: Push/pull forces we directly exert. AIR RESISTANCE/DRAG: Opposes motion through fluids. SPRING: F = -kx (Hooke's Law). ELECTROMAGNETIC: Forces between charges and magnets. All forces cause acceleration according to F = ma.
ForceCalculator.faqQ4: How do you handle multiple forces?
ForceCalculator.faqA4: Add forces as vectors to find net force (F_net), then use F_net = ma. SAME DIRECTION: Add magnitudes (100N + 50N right = 150N right). OPPOSITE DIRECTIONS: Subtract (100N right - 60N left = 40N right). PERPENDICULAR: Use Pythagorean theorem (30N north + 40N east = √(30²+40²) = 50N at angle). For 2D problems, break forces into x and y components, sum separately, then recombine. The net force determines acceleration direction and magnitude.
ForceCalculator.faqA5: F = ma is one of the most fundamental equations in physics, connecting force (cause) to motion (effect). It explains everything from why heavy objects are hard to push to how spacecraft maneuver in orbit. Applications include: vehicle design (braking distances), sports (ball trajectories), engineering (structural loads), rocket science (thrust calculations), and safety (crash forces, airbag timing). Understanding F = ma is essential for all mechanics and is the foundation of classical physics.
ForceCalculator.faqQ6: What happens when mass or force is zero?
ForceCalculator.faqA6: If F = 0: No net force means a = 0 (Newton's First Law). Object maintains constant velocity (rest or uniform motion). If m = 0: Theoretically a = F/0 = infinite acceleration - physically meaningless since all matter has mass. Even photons (zero rest mass) follow different rules (E=mc²). If a = 0: Either F = 0 (equilibrium) or object moves at constant velocity. Zero acceleration doesn't mean zero velocity! These special cases reveal the boundaries of classical mechanics.
ForceCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid numbers for at least two quantities. Mass must be positive, force and acceleration can be positive or negative.

SpeedCalculator.metadataTitle: Speed Calculator - Calculate Speed, Distance, or Time | Free Online Tool
SpeedCalculator.metadataDescription: Free speed calculator. Calculate speed (v = d/t), distance, or time. Perfect for physics, travel planning, and athletics.
SpeedCalculator.metadataKeywords: speed calculator, velocity calculator, distance time calculator, speed formula, m/s, physics calculator, travel calculator
SpeedCalculator.title: Speed Calculator
SpeedCalculator.subtitle: Calculate speed, distance, or time using the fundamental motion formula
SpeedCalculator.selectCalculation: What would you like to calculate?
SpeedCalculator.formulaDescription: v = speed, d = distance, t = time
SpeedCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Distance and speed must be positive, time must be greater than zero.
SpeedCalculator.whatIsContent: Speed is the rate at which an object covers distance. It's a scalar quantity (has magnitude but no direction) measured in meters per second (m/s), kilometers per hour (km/h), or miles per hour (mph). Speed tells us how fast something is moving, calculated by dividing the distance traveled by the time taken. Velocity is similar but includes direction (making it a vector). Average speed considers total distance/time, while instantaneous speed is the speed at a specific moment. Understanding speed is fundamental to physics, transportation, sports, and everyday life.
SpeedCalculator.formulaContent: The basic formula relates speed (v), distance (d), and time (t): v = d/t. This can be rearranged to find distance: d = v × t, or time: t = d/v. The units must be consistent: if distance is in meters and time in seconds, speed will be in m/s. Common conversions: 1 m/s = 3.6 km/h = 2.237 mph. The formula assumes constant speed, but for variable speeds, use calculus (v = ds/dt) or average values. This linear relationship is one of the most basic and useful in all of physics.
SpeedCalculator.examplesContent:
Example 1 - Marathon Runner:
Distance: 42,195 meters (marathon)
Time: 7,200 seconds (2 hours)
Speed: 42,195 / 7,200 = 5.86 m/s (21.1 km/h)

Example 2 - Highway Travel:
Speed: 27.78 m/s (100 km/h)
Time: 3,600 seconds (1 hour)
Distance: 27.78 × 3,600 = 100,000 meters (100 km)

Example 3 - Sprint Time:
Distance: 100 meters
Speed: 10 m/s (world-class sprinter)
Time: 100 / 10 = 10 seconds

Example 4 - Light Travel:
Speed: 299,792,458 m/s (speed of light)
Time: 8.3 minutes (500 seconds) to Sun
Distance: 299,792,458 × 500 = 149,896,229,000 meters
SpeedCalculator.faqQ1: What's the difference between speed and velocity?
SpeedCalculator.faqA1: SPEED is scalar (magnitude only): "50 km/h" tells how fast you're going. VELOCITY is vector (magnitude + direction): "50 km/h north" tells both speed and direction. You can change velocity without changing speed (driving in a circle at constant 50 km/h - speed constant, velocity constantly changing due to direction change). Average speed = total distance/time. Average velocity = displacement/time (can be zero if you return to start!). In physics calculations, velocity's direction matters for vector addition.
SpeedCalculator.faqQ2: How do you convert between speed units?
SpeedCalculator.faqA2: COMMON CONVERSIONS: 1 m/s = 3.6 km/h (multiply by 3.6), 1 km/h = 0.278 m/s (divide by 3.6), 1 mph = 0.447 m/s = 1.609 km/h, 1 m/s = 2.237 mph. CONVERSION METHOD: Use dimensional analysis. Example: Convert 60 mph to m/s: 60 mph × (1.609 km/1 mi) × (1000 m/1 km) × (1 h/3600 s) = 26.8 m/s. Always check units cancel properly. For quick estimates: km/h ≈ mph × 1.6, m/s ≈ mph × 0.45.
SpeedCalculator.faqQ3: What is average speed vs instantaneous speed?
SpeedCalculator.faqA3: AVERAGE SPEED: Total distance divided by total time. Example: Drive 100 km in 2 hours = 50 km/h average, even if you stopped, sped up, slowed down. INSTANTANEOUS SPEED: Speed at a specific moment, what your speedometer shows. In calculus: v = lim(Δt→0) Δd/Δt = dd/dt. For constant speed, average = instantaneous. For variable speed, they differ. Your trip computer shows both: current speed (instantaneous) and average trip speed. Physics problems often need to specify which type.
SpeedCalculator.faqQ4: How does acceleration relate to speed?
SpeedCalculator.faqA4: ACCELERATION is the rate of speed change: a = Δv/Δt (change in velocity per time). POSITIVE ACCELERATION: Speed increases (car accelerating). NEGATIVE ACCELERATION (deceleration/braking): Speed decreases. CONSTANT SPEED: a = 0 (cruise control). With constant acceleration: v_final = v_initial + at and d = v_initial × t + ½at². CIRCULAR MOTION: Even at constant speed, there's centripetal acceleration (a = v²/r) due to direction change. Acceleration connects to force through F = ma (Newton's Second Law).
SpeedCalculator.faqQ5: What are typical speeds for different objects?
SpeedCalculator.faqA5: WALKING: 1.4 m/s (5 km/h). RUNNING: 3-6 m/s (11-22 km/h). SPRINTING: 10+ m/s (36+ km/h, Usain Bolt ~12 m/s). CYCLING: 5-15 m/s (18-54 km/h). CARS: Highway 28 m/s (100 km/h), city 14 m/s (50 km/h). TRAINS: 50-90 m/s (180-320 km/h for high-speed). AIRPLANES: Commercial 250 m/s (900 km/h), supersonic 600+ m/s. SOUND: 343 m/s in air. LIGHT: 299,792,458 m/s (universal speed limit). These help gauge if calculated values are reasonable.
SpeedCalculator.faqQ6: What happens at very high speeds?
SpeedCalculator.faqA6: RELATIVISTIC EFFECTS (near light speed): Time dilation (moving clocks run slow), length contraction (moving objects shorten), mass increase. Classical v = d/t breaks down - need Einstein's relativity. Nothing with mass can reach light speed (c). SPEED OF LIGHT: Absolute limit, same in all reference frames (299,792,458 m/s). Spacecraft: Current max ~17 km/s (Voyager), orders of magnitude below c. At everyday speeds (<1000 m/s), classical physics works perfectly. Relativistic effects become noticeable above ~10% of light speed.

EnergyCalculator.metadataTitle: Energy Calculator - Kinetic, Potential & Elastic Energy | Free Physics Tool
EnergyCalculator.metadataDescription: Free energy calculator. Calculate kinetic energy (KE = ½mv²), gravitational potential energy (PE = mgh), and elastic potential energy (EPE = ½kx²).

EnergyCalculator.title: Energy Calculator
EnergyCalculator.subtitle: Calculate kinetic, potential, and elastic energy with precision
EnergyCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Mass, spring constant, and velocity must be positive.
EnergyCalculator.whatIsContent: Energy is the capacity to do work or cause change. It's a fundamental concept in physics, measured in Joules (J). Energy exists in many forms but can never be created or destroyed, only transformed (Law of Conservation of Energy). KINETIC ENERGY: Energy of motion - anything moving has kinetic energy. POTENTIAL ENERGY: Stored energy due to position or configuration - gravitational (height), elastic (springs), chemical (bonds), etc. Energy transformations are everywhere: chemical energy in food → kinetic energy in movement, potential energy in water → electrical energy in hydropower, nuclear energy → heat → electricity in power plants.
EnergyCalculator.formulaContent: KINETIC ENERGY (KE = ½mv²): Energy of motion, proportional to mass and velocity squared. Doubling velocity quadruples kinetic energy! Used for moving objects: cars, bullets, electrons. GRAVITATIONAL POTENTIAL ENERGY (PE = mgh): Energy stored due to height in gravity field. m = mass (kg), g = gravitational acceleration (9.8 m/s² on Earth), h = height (m). Used for falling objects, roller coasters, hydropower. ELASTIC POTENTIAL ENERGY (EPE = ½kx²): Energy stored in stretched/compressed springs or elastic materials. k = spring constant (N/m, stiffness), x = displacement from equilibrium (m). Used for springs, rubber bands, shock absorbers. All measured in Joules (1 J = 1 N⋅m = 1 kg⋅m²/s²).
EnergyCalculator.examplesContent:
Example 1 - Moving Car (Kinetic):
Mass: 1,500 kg
Velocity: 25 m/s (90 km/h)
KE = ½(1,500)(25²) = 468,750 J = 469 kJ

Example 2 - Lifted Object (Potential):
Mass: 10 kg
Gravity: 9.8 m/s²
Height: 5 meters
PE = (10)(9.8)(5) = 490 J

Example 3 - Compressed Spring (Elastic):
Spring Constant: 200 N/m
Displacement: 0.15 m
EPE = ½(200)(0.15²) = 2.25 J

Example 4 - Falling Ball:
At top (10 m): PE = mgh = 490 J, KE = 0 J
At bottom: PE = 0 J, KE = ½mv² = 490 J
Total energy conserved: 490 J throughout!
EnergyCalculator.faqQ1: What is the Law of Conservation of Energy?
EnergyCalculator.faqA1: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another. Total energy in a closed system remains constant. Examples: Pendulum swings convert PE ↔ KE continuously. Falling object: PE → KE as it falls. Friction converts KE → heat energy. Battery: Chemical energy → electrical energy → light + heat. Nuclear: Mass energy (E=mc²) → heat → electricity. Energy 'loss' means conversion to less useful forms (usually heat), not destruction. This is one of the most fundamental laws in physics, with NO known violations.
EnergyCalculator.faqQ2: Why does kinetic energy depend on velocity squared?
EnergyCalculator.faqA2: KE = ½mv² has v² because accelerating requires work, and work over distance adds up. INTUITION: Doubling speed requires 4× energy because you must accelerate through twice the distance at higher average speed. DERIVATION: Work = Force × distance = (ma) × d. From kinematics: v² = 2ad, so d = v²/(2a). Thus Work = ma × v²/(2a) = ½mv². CONSEQUENCE: High speeds are energy-intensive. Going 100→120 mph requires more energy than 0→20 mph. This is why fuel efficiency drops at high speeds and why crashes are exponentially more dangerous at higher speeds.
EnergyCalculator.faqQ3: How do potential and kinetic energy relate?
EnergyCalculator.faqA3: They constantly transform into each other while conserving total energy. FALLING OBJECT: Starts with PE = mgh, KE = 0. As it falls: PE decreases (lower height), KE increases (faster velocity). At bottom: PE = 0, KE = ½mv² = mgh (all PE converted to KE). PENDULUM: At highest points: max PE, zero KE (stopped). At lowest point: zero PE (reference), max KE (fastest). Energy continuously flows PE → KE → PE. ROLLER COASTER: High points = high PE, slow KE. Low points = low PE, fast KE. Conservation enables speed/height calculations.
EnergyCalculator.faqQ4: What are common energy unit conversions?
EnergyCalculator.faqA4: JOULE (J): SI unit, 1 J = 1 N⋅m = force of 1 N over 1 m. KILOJOULE (kJ): 1 kJ = 1,000 J (typical food energy). CALORIE (cal): 1 cal = 4.184 J (raises 1 g water by 1°C). Food Calorie = 1 kcal = 4,184 J. KILOWATT-HOUR (kWh): 1 kWh = 3.6 MJ (electricity billing). ELECTRON VOLT (eV): 1 eV = 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ J (atomic scale). BTU: 1 BTU = 1,055 J (heating/cooling). EXAMPLE: 2,000 Calorie diet = 2,000 kcal = 8,368 kJ = 8.4 MJ per day.
EnergyCalculator.faqA5: No transformation is 100% efficient - some energy always converts to heat. HUMAN BODY: ~25% efficient (food → movement), rest = heat. INCANDESCENT BULB: ~5% efficient (electricity → light), 95% = heat. LED: ~40% efficient. ELECTRIC MOTOR: 85-95% efficient. COMBUSTION ENGINE: 25-35% efficient (fuel → motion). POWER PLANT: Coal ~33%, combined cycle gas ~60%, nuclear ~33%. PHOTOSYNTHESIS: ~3-6% efficient (sunlight → chemical energy). SOLAR PANEL: 15-22% efficient. Efficiency = (useful energy out / total energy in) × 100%. Heat loss is governed by thermodynamics - can't avoid it completely.
EnergyCalculator.faqQ6: What's the relationship between energy and power?
EnergyCalculator.faqA6: ENERGY is capacity to do work (Joules). POWER is rate of energy use/transfer (Watts = Joules/second). RELATIONSHIP: Energy = Power × Time, or Power = Energy / Time. EXAMPLES: 100W light bulb uses 100 J/s. In 1 hour: 100W × 3,600s = 360,000 J = 360 kJ = 0.1 kWh. Car engine: 150 HP ≈ 112 kW can deliver 112 kJ every second. Lifting 10 kg mass 5 m requires 490 J of energy. If done in 1 second: 490 W power. If done in 10 seconds: 49 W power. Same energy, different power. High power = fast energy transfer. Athletes have high power output for brief periods.

PowerCalculator.formulaDescription: P = power (W), W = work/energy (J), t = time (s)
PowerCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Power, work, and time must be positive numbers.
PowerCalculator.whatIsContent: Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred. It measures how fast energy changes form or location. Power is measured in Watts (W), where 1 Watt = 1 Joule per second. HIGH POWER means energy transfers quickly (sports car accelerating, microwave heating food). LOW POWER means energy transfers slowly (walking, phone charging overnight). Power determines how quickly tasks complete: A 2000W heater warms a room faster than a 1000W heater. A 300 HP engine accelerates faster than a 150 HP engine. Understanding power is crucial for electrical systems, mechanical engineering, energy efficiency, and everyday appliances.
PowerCalculator.formulaContent: The basic formula is P = W/t (Power = Work/Time). This can be rearranged: W = P × t (Work = Power × Time), or t = W/P (Time = Work/Power). UNITS: Power in Watts (W), Work/Energy in Joules (J), Time in seconds (s). 1 Watt = 1 Joule/second. Common units: kilowatt (kW) = 1,000 W, megawatt (MW) = 1,000,000 W, horsepower (HP) ≈ 746 W. For ELECTRICAL power: P = V × I (voltage × current), or P = I²R (current squared × resistance). For MECHANICAL power: P = F × v (force × velocity). The formula shows that doing the same work in less time requires more power.
PowerCalculator.examplesContent:
Example 1 - Light Bulb:
Work: 360,000 J (360 kJ)
Time: 3,600 seconds (1 hour)
Power: 360,000 / 3,600 = 100 W

Example 2 - Electric Heater:
Power: 1,500 W (1.5 kW)
Time: 7,200 seconds (2 hours)
Work: 1,500 × 7,200 = 10,800,000 J = 10.8 MJ = 3 kWh

Example 3 - Lifting Weight:
Work: 490 J (lift 10 kg, 5 m high)
Power: 98 W (moderate effort)
Time: 490 / 98 = 5 seconds

Example 4 - Car Engine:
Power: 150 HP ≈ 112,000 W (112 kW)
Time: 10 seconds acceleration
Work: 112,000 × 10 = 1,120,000 J = 1.12 MJ
PowerCalculator.faqQ1: What's the difference between power and energy?
PowerCalculator.faqA1: ENERGY (Work) is the total capacity to do work, measured in Joules (J). POWER is the RATE of energy use/transfer, measured in Watts (W = J/s). ANALOGY: Energy is like water in a tank (total amount). Power is like water flow rate (how fast it comes out). EXAMPLE: Two identical cars climb the same hill (same energy required). Sports car: High power, reaches top quickly. Economy car: Low power, reaches top slowly. Same energy consumed, different power output. A 100W bulb for 10 hours uses same energy as a 1000W heater for 1 hour (both = 1 kWh), but heater has 10× the power.
PowerCalculator.faqQ2: How do you convert between power units?
PowerCalculator.faqA2: COMMON CONVERSIONS: 1 kW = 1,000 W, 1 MW = 1,000 kW = 1,000,000 W. 1 horsepower (HP) = 746 W ≈ 0.746 kW. 1 metric horsepower (PS) = 735.5 W. 1 BTU/hour = 0.293 W. ELECTRICAL: From voltage & current: P = V × I (e.g., 120V × 10A = 1,200W). From current & resistance: P = I²R (e.g., 10² × 12Ω = 1,200W). MECHANICAL: From force & velocity: P = F × v (e.g., 1000N × 20 m/s = 20,000W = 20kW). Example: 200 HP engine = 200 × 746 = 149,200 W ≈ 149 kW.
PowerCalculator.faqQ3: What are typical power ratings for common devices?
PowerCalculator.faqA3: HOUSEHOLD: LED bulb 10-15W, incandescent 60-100W, phone charger 5-20W, laptop 45-90W, desktop PC 200-500W, microwave 800-1,200W, electric kettle 1,500-3,000W, air conditioner 1,000-4,000W, electric car charger 3,500-22,000W. HUMAN: Resting ~100W, walking ~200W, cycling ~200-400W, sprinting ~1,000-2,000W (brief), professional cyclist sustained ~400W. TRANSPORTATION: Small car ~75 kW (100 HP), sports car ~300+ kW (400+ HP), semi truck ~375 kW (500 HP), train ~3-6 MW. INDUSTRIAL: Wind turbine 2-15 MW, power plant 500-2,000 MW.
PowerCalculator.faqQ4: How does power relate to electricity bills?
PowerCalculator.faqA4: Electricity is billed by ENERGY (kWh), not power (kW). Energy = Power × Time. KILOWATT-HOUR (kWh): Energy used by 1 kW device for 1 hour. CALCULATION: Device power (kW) × hours used = kWh consumed. EXAMPLES: 100W bulb for 10 hours = 0.1 kW × 10 h = 1 kWh. 2,000W heater for 5 hours = 2 kW × 5 h = 10 kWh. At $0.12/kWh: Bulb costs $0.12, heater costs $1.20. HIGH POWER devices cost more IF used long. A 3,000W AC running 8 hrs/day = 24 kWh/day = 720 kWh/month ≈ $86/month. Understanding device power helps estimate costs.
PowerCalculator.faqQ5: What is peak power vs average power?
PowerCalculator.faqA5: AVERAGE POWER: Total energy divided by total time. What matters for most applications and billing. PEAK POWER (Maximum Power): Highest power reached, even briefly. Important for sizing equipment and circuits. EXAMPLES: Microwave rated 1,000W is peak power, but actual average ~700W (magnetron cycles on/off). Athletes: Usain Bolt peak power ~2,500W during sprint start, average over 100m ~1,200W. Electric motor: Peak power during startup (high current), lower average during normal operation. RATINGS: Device labels usually show peak/maximum power. Circuit breakers protect against peak power (prevent overload).
PowerCalculator.faqA6: EFFICIENCY = (Useful Power Out / Total Power In) × 100%. Measures how much input power becomes useful output (rest becomes waste heat). EXAMPLES: LED: 40% efficient (15W in → 6W light + 9W heat). Incandescent: 5% efficient (60W in → 3W light + 57W heat). Electric motor: 90% efficient (1000W in → 900W mechanical + 100W heat). Gas engine: 30% efficient (100 kW fuel → 30 kW mechanical + 70 kW heat). Solar panel: 20% efficient (1000W sunlight → 200W electricity + 800W heat). Power plant: 33-60% efficient. Higher efficiency = less wasted energy = lower operating costs. Energy Star appliances have higher efficiency ratings.

WorkCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. All inputs must be positive numbers.
WorkCalculator.whatIsContent: In physics, work is the energy transferred when a force moves an object over a distance. Work is only done when force causes displacement in the direction of the force. Formula: W = F × d × cos(θ), where θ is the angle between force and displacement. At 0°, maximum work is done. At 90°, no work is done (perpendicular force). Work is measured in Joules (J), where 1 Joule = 1 Newton-meter. Positive work adds energy to a system, negative work removes energy.
WorkCalculator.formulaContent: W = F × d × cos(θ). Force component in direction of motion does work. When force and motion are parallel (θ=0°): cos(0°)=1, so W=Fd. When perpendicular (θ=90°): cos(90°)=0, so W=0 (no work). When opposite (θ=180°): cos(180°)=-1, so W=-Fd (negative work). Example: Pushing a box 10m with 50N force at 0° angle: W = 50 × 10 × cos(0°) = 500 J. Carrying a box horizontally: gravity does no work because force (down) is perpendicular to motion (horizontal).

ImpulseCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
ImpulseCalculator.formulaDescription: J = impulse (N·s), F = force (N), Δt = time interval (s)
ImpulseCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Force and time must be positive numbers.
ImpulseCalculator.whatIsContent: Impulse is the change in momentum of an object when a force acts on it over time. Formula: J = F × Δt = Δp (change in momentum). Impulse equals the area under a force-time graph. Large force for short time = small force for long time (same impulse). This principle explains airbags: they extend collision time, reducing peak force on passengers. Impulse is measured in Newton-seconds (N·s) or kg·m/s. Understanding impulse is crucial for analyzing collisions, rockets, and sports impacts.
ImpulseCalculator.formulaContent: J = F × Δt (Impulse = Force × Time). Also: J = Δp = mΔv (change in momentum). IMPULSE-MOMENTUM THEOREM: Impulse on object equals its momentum change. Example: Catching a ball - you extend contact time to reduce force. Hard catch (0.1s): F = Δp/Δt = high force. Soft catch (0.5s): F = Δp/Δt = low force. Same impulse, different force. This is why: Airbags work (extend crash time), Martial artists break boards (concentrate force in short time), Follow-through in sports increases impulse.

KineticEnergyCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Mass and velocity must be positive numbers.
KineticEnergyCalculator.whatIsContent: Kinetic energy (KE) is the energy of motion - any moving object has kinetic energy. Formula: KE = ½mv². The ½ comes from integrating F=ma over distance. KE depends on mass and velocity squared, meaning doubling velocity quadruples energy! This explains why high-speed crashes are exponentially more dangerous. A 1,000 kg car at 20 m/s has KE = ½(1000)(20²) = 200,000 J. At 40 m/s, KE = 800,000 J (4× more energy). Kinetic energy is always positive (v² is always positive) and is measured in Joules.
KineticEnergyCalculator.formulaContent: KE = ½mv². Why v²? Because accelerating requires work, and work accumulates over distance. INTUITION: Doubling speed requires 4× energy because you must accelerate through twice the distance at higher average velocity. DERIVATION: Work = Force × distance = (ma) × d. From kinematics: v² = 2ad, so d = v²/(2a). Thus Work = ma × v²/(2a) = ½mv². CONSEQUENCE: High speeds are energy-intensive. Going from 100→120 km/h requires more energy than 0→20 km/h. This is why fuel efficiency drops at high speeds and accidents are exponentially more dangerous at higher velocities.

PotentialEnergyCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. All inputs must be positive numbers.
PotentialEnergyCalculator.whatIsContent: Gravitational potential energy (PE) is stored energy due to an object's position in a gravitational field. The higher an object, the more potential energy it has. Formula: PE = mgh, where m is mass, g is gravitational acceleration (9.8 m/s² on Earth), and h is height above reference point. PE can convert to kinetic energy (falling object) and vice versa (thrown object rising). A 10 kg object at 5 m height has PE = 10 × 9.8 × 5 = 490 J. If dropped, this PE converts to KE. PE is relative to a chosen reference level (usually ground).
PotentialEnergyCalculator.formulaContent: PE = mgh (mass × gravity × height). This formula assumes constant gravity and near Earth's surface. DERIVATION: Work against gravity = Force × distance = (mg) × h = mgh. This work becomes stored potential energy. ENERGY CONVERSION: Object at height h: PE = mgh, KE = 0. During fall: PE decreases, KE increases. At ground: PE = 0, KE = ½mv² = mgh (all PE converted to KE). APPLICATIONS: Hydroelectric dams: Water PE → KE → electrical energy. Roller coasters: PE at peaks, KE in valleys. Pendulums: Continuous PE ↔ KE conversion.

ProjectileCalculator.calculatesAll: Enter initial velocity and angle to calculate all projectile parameters
ProjectileCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Velocity must be positive, angle between 0-90°.
ProjectileCalculator.whatIsContent: Projectile motion is the curved path an object follows when thrown or launched near Earth's surface. Motion has two independent components: HORIZONTAL: Constant velocity (no acceleration, ignoring air resistance). VERTICAL: Constant acceleration due to gravity. The path is a parabola. At 45° launch angle, maximum range is achieved. Vertical velocity decreases going up (gravity opposing), becomes zero at peak, increases going down. Horizontal velocity remains constant throughout flight. Time to reach peak = time to fall from peak. Examples: thrown ball, fired cannonball, kicked soccer ball, water fountain arc.
ProjectileCalculator.formulasContent: VELOCITY COMPONENTS: vₓ = v₀cos(θ), vᵧ = v₀sin(θ). RANGE: R = v₀²sin(2θ)/g. Maximum at θ=45°. TIME OF FLIGHT: t = 2vᵧ/g = 2v₀sin(θ)/g. MAXIMUM HEIGHT: h = vᵧ²/(2g) = v₀²sin²(θ)/(2g). POSITION AT TIME t: x(t) = vₓt, y(t) = vᵧt - ½gt². KEY INSIGHTS: Range same for complementary angles (30° and 60° give same range). Doubling velocity quadruples range (v² relationship). On Moon (g=1.62 m/s²), projectiles travel 6× farther than Earth. Maximum height reached at half the total flight time.

AccelerationCalculator.metadataTitle: Acceleration Calculator - Calculate a, v, or t | Free Physics Tool
AccelerationCalculator.metadataDescription: Free acceleration calculator. Calculate acceleration (a = Δv/t), final velocity, or time. Essential for kinematics and physics calculations.
AccelerationCalculator.metadataKeywords: acceleration calculator, kinematics, velocity calculator, physics calculator, a=Δv/t, motion calculator
AccelerationCalculator.title: Acceleration Calculator
AccelerationCalculator.subtitle: Calculate acceleration, final velocity, or time
AccelerationCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
AccelerationCalculator.formulaDescription: a = acceleration (m/s²), vf = final velocity (m/s), vi = initial velocity (m/s), t = time (s)
AccelerationCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Time must be positive.
AccelerationCalculator.whatIsContent: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity over time. It measures how quickly an object speeds up, slows down, or changes direction. Formula: a = (vf - vi)/t. Positive acceleration = speeding up. Negative acceleration (deceleration) = slowing down. Acceleration is a vector - it has magnitude and direction. Earth's gravity causes downward acceleration of 9.8 m/s². A car going from 0 to 100 km/h in 10 seconds has acceleration of 2.78 m/s². Even circular motion at constant speed has acceleration (direction changes).
AccelerationCalculator.formulaContent: BASIC: a = Δv/Δt = (vf - vi)/t. VELOCITY: vf = vi + at. TIME: t = (vf - vi)/a. CONSTANT ACCELERATION EQUATIONS: vf² = vi² + 2ad (no time). d = vit + ½at² (distance). UNITS: SI unit is m/s² (meters per second squared). Also written as m·s⁻². REAL-WORLD: Car: 0-60 mph in 5s ≈ 5.4 m/s². Gravity: 9.8 m/s². Rocket launch: 30+ m/s². Emergency braking: -8 m/s². Centripetal acceleration in circular motion: a = v²/r.
AccelerationCalculator.examplesContent: EXAMPLE 1 - Car acceleration: A car accelerates from 20 m/s to 35 m/s in 5 seconds. Acceleration = (35-20)/5 = 3 m/s². EXAMPLE 2 - Braking: A bike traveling at 15 m/s stops in 3 seconds. Acceleration = (0-15)/3 = -5 m/s² (negative = deceleration). EXAMPLE 3 - Free fall: Object dropped from rest. After 4 seconds: vf = 0 + 9.8×4 = 39.2 m/s. EXAMPLE 4 - Rocket: Rocket with constant 25 m/s² acceleration. After 10s: vf = 0 + 25×10 = 250 m/s (900 km/h!).
AccelerationCalculator.faqQ1: What's the difference between speed and acceleration?
AccelerationCalculator.faqA1: Speed is how fast you're going. Acceleration is how quickly your speed changes. A car can have high speed but zero acceleration (cruising at constant velocity).
AccelerationCalculator.faqA2: Yes! Negative acceleration (often called deceleration or retardation) means slowing down. It occurs when final velocity is less than initial velocity, or when accelerating in the negative direction.
AccelerationCalculator.faqQ3: Why is gravity's acceleration always 9.8 m/s²?
AccelerationCalculator.faqA3: Near Earth's surface, gravity causes all objects to accelerate downward at approximately 9.8 m/s² (actually 9.80665 m/s²), regardless of mass. This value varies slightly with altitude and latitude.
AccelerationCalculator.faqQ4: How is acceleration different from velocity?
AccelerationCalculator.faqA4: Velocity measures motion (how fast and which direction). Acceleration measures change in motion (how quickly velocity changes). Units: velocity is m/s, acceleration is m/s² (per second per second).
AccelerationCalculator.faqQ5: Can you have acceleration with constant speed?
AccelerationCalculator.faqA5: Yes! In circular motion, speed can be constant but velocity changes direction continuously, creating centripetal acceleration directed toward the center. Example: Earth orbiting Sun, car turning at constant speed.
AccelerationCalculator.faqA6: Average acceleration = total velocity change / total time. Instantaneous acceleration = acceleration at one specific moment. For constant acceleration, they're the same. For variable acceleration (like car in traffic), they differ.

FrictionCalculator.metadataTitle: Friction Calculator - Calculate Friction Force | Free Physics Tool
FrictionCalculator.metadataDescription: Free friction calculator. Calculate friction force (f = μN), coefficient of friction, or normal force. Essential for physics and engineering.
FrictionCalculator.metadataKeywords: friction calculator, coefficient friction, normal force, physics calculator, f=μN, friction force
FrictionCalculator.title: Friction Calculator
FrictionCalculator.subtitle: Calculate friction force, coefficient, or normal force
FrictionCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
FrictionCalculator.formulaDescription: f = friction force (N), μ = coefficient of friction (dimensionless), N = normal force (N)
FrictionCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. All inputs must be non-negative.
FrictionCalculator.whatIsContent: Friction is the force that opposes motion between surfaces in contact. Formula: f = μN, where μ is the coefficient of friction (material property) and N is normal force (perpendicular force between surfaces). TWO TYPES: Static friction (prevents motion from starting, up to fs,max = μsN). Kinetic friction (opposes ongoing motion, fk = μkN). μs > μk (harder to start moving than keep moving). Friction converts kinetic energy to heat. Examples: Walking (need friction to push off ground), Car brakes (friction slows wheels), Lubricants (reduce friction). Friction depends on surface materials and roughness, NOT contact area.
FrictionCalculator.formulaContent: f = μN (friction = coefficient × normal force). COEFFICIENT VALUES: Ice on ice: μ ≈ 0.02-0.05 (very slippery). Metal on metal: μ ≈ 0.15-0.20. Wood on wood: μ ≈ 0.25-0.50. Rubber on dry concrete: μ ≈ 0.60-0.85 (high grip). Rubber on wet concrete: μ ≈ 0.45-0.75 (reduced). STATIC vs KINETIC: μs (static) > μk (kinetic). For rubber on concrete: μs ≈ 0.85, μk ≈ 0.70. NORMAL FORCE: On flat surface: N = mg (weight). On incline: N = mg cos(θ). WHY f = μN? Friction arises from microscopic surface interactions. More normal force = more contact = more friction.

GravityCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. All inputs must be positive.
GravityCalculator.whatIsContent: Gravitational force is the attractive force between any two masses in the universe. Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation: F = Gm₁m₂/r², where G = 6.674×10⁻¹¹ N⋅m²/kg² (universal gravitational constant), m₁ and m₂ are masses, r is center-to-center distance. KEY INSIGHTS: Force is ALWAYS attractive (never repulsive). Force follows inverse square law (doubling distance reduces force to ¼). Force acts along line connecting centers. Both masses experience equal and opposite forces (Newton's 3rd Law). EXAMPLES: Earth-Moon: F ≈ 2×10²⁰ N. Earth-Sun: F ≈ 3.5×10²² N. You-Earth: F = your weight. Two people 1m apart: F ≈ 10⁻⁷ N (negligible). Gravity is weakest fundamental force but dominates at large scales due to cumulative effect of mass.

MomentumCalculator.metadataTitle: Momentum Calculator - Calculate p = mv | Free Physics Tool
MomentumCalculator.metadataDescription: Free momentum calculator. Calculate momentum (p = mv), mass, or velocity. Essential for collision problems and physics calculations.
MomentumCalculator.metadataKeywords: momentum calculator, p=mv, physics calculator, collision, impulse, linear momentum
MomentumCalculator.title: Momentum Calculator
MomentumCalculator.subtitle: Calculate momentum, mass, or velocity
MomentumCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
MomentumCalculator.formulaDescription: p = momentum (kg⋅m/s), m = mass (kg), v = velocity (m/s)
MomentumCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Mass must be positive.
MomentumCalculator.whatIsContent: Momentum is the quantity of motion an object has. Formula: p = mv (mass × velocity). Momentum is a vector - it has magnitude and direction. CONSERVATION OF MOMENTUM: In a closed system, total momentum before = total momentum after (even in collisions). This is one of physics' most fundamental laws. CHARACTERISTICS: Heavy, slow object can have same momentum as light, fast object. Large momentum = harder to stop. Momentum can be positive or negative (direction). Unit: kg⋅m/s. EXAMPLES: Truck at 20 m/s has more momentum than car at same speed (larger mass). Bullet has significant momentum despite small mass (very high velocity). In collisions, momentum transfers between objects but total remains constant.

PressureCalculator.metadataTitle: Pressure Calculator - Calculate P = F/A | Free Physics Tool
PressureCalculator.metadataDescription: Free pressure calculator. Calculate pressure (P = F/A), force, or area. Essential for fluid mechanics and physics calculations.
PressureCalculator.metadataKeywords: pressure calculator, P=F/A, pascal, physics calculator, fluid mechanics, force per area
PressureCalculator.title: Pressure Calculator
PressureCalculator.subtitle: Calculate pressure, force, or contact area
PressureCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
PressureCalculator.formulaDescription: P = pressure (Pa), F = force (N), A = area (m²)
PressureCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Area must be positive.
PressureCalculator.whatIsContent: Pressure is force distributed over an area. Formula: P = F/A (Force per unit area). SI unit: Pascal (Pa) = 1 N/m². Smaller area with same force = higher pressure. KEY CONCEPT: Sharp knife cuts easily because small edge area creates high pressure. Lying on bed of nails works if weight distributed over enough nails (low pressure per nail). TYPES: Atmospheric pressure: ~101,325 Pa at sea level. Gauge pressure: measured relative to atmospheric. Absolute pressure: measured from perfect vacuum. EXAMPLES: Atmospheric pressure: 101 kPa. Car tire: 200-250 kPa. Hydraulic jack: >10,000 kPa. Deep ocean (11 km): >100,000 kPa. Pressure increases with fluid depth: P = ρgh.
PressureCalculator.formulaContent: P = F/A. Pressure inversely proportional to area. UNITS: Pascal (Pa) = N/m². Bar: 1 bar = 100,000 Pa. Atmosphere: 1 atm = 101,325 Pa. PSI (pounds per square inch): 1 psi ≈ 6,895 Pa. APPLICATIONS: Hydraulics use pressure to multiply force (Pascal's principle). Airplane wings generate lift via pressure difference. Blood pressure measured in mmHg (millimeters of mercury). Sharp objects concentrate force over small area for high pressure penetration.

TorqueCalculator.metadataTitle: Torque Calculator - Calculate τ = F×r | Free Physics Tool
TorqueCalculator.metadataDescription: Free torque calculator. Calculate torque (τ = F×r×sin(θ)), force, or lever arm distance. Essential for rotational motion and engineering.
TorqueCalculator.metadataKeywords: torque calculator, τ=F×r, rotational force, lever arm, physics calculator, moment of force
TorqueCalculator.title: Torque Calculator
TorqueCalculator.subtitle: Calculate torque, force, or lever arm distance
TorqueCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
TorqueCalculator.formulaDescription: τ = torque (N⋅m), F = force (N), r = lever arm distance (m), θ = angle between F and r
TorqueCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Distance must be positive, angle between 0-180°.
TorqueCalculator.whatIsContent: Torque (τ) is rotational force - it causes objects to rotate around an axis. Formula: τ = F × r × sin(θ), where F is force magnitude, r is perpendicular distance from axis (lever arm), θ is angle between force and lever arm. Maximum torque when θ = 90° (force perpendicular to lever). Zero torque when θ = 0° or 180° (force along lever). Unit: N⋅m (Newton-meter). INTUITION: Longer wrench = easier to turn bolt (larger r). Pushing perpendicular to door (away from hinge) is most effective. Pushing toward hinge produces zero torque. EXAMPLES: Opening door, using wrench, steering wheel, seesaw. Torque = rotational equivalent of force (force causes linear acceleration, torque causes angular acceleration).
TorqueCalculator.formulaContent: τ = r × F × sin(θ). PERPENDICULAR FORCE (θ=90°): τ = rF (maximum). PARALLEL FORCE (θ=0° or 180°): τ = 0 (no rotation). RELATIONSHIP TO ROTATION: τ = Iα (torque = moment of inertia × angular acceleration). Analogous to F = ma. APPLICATIONS: Wrenches: longer handle = more torque. Engine torque: measure of rotational power. Torque wrench: applies specific torque to fasteners. Gyroscopes resist torque, maintaining orientation. DIRECTION: Right-hand rule determines rotation direction (counterclockwise = positive, clockwise = negative).

AngularVelocityCalculator.metadataTitle: Angular Velocity Calculator - ω, θ, RPM | Free Physics Tool
AngularVelocityCalculator.metadataDescription: Free angular velocity calculator. Calculate ω, angle, time, or RPM for rotational motion using ω = θ/t.

AngularVelocityCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Time must be positive.
AngularVelocityCalculator.whatIsContent: Angular velocity (ω) measures how fast an object rotates around an axis. Formula: ω = θ/t, where θ is angular displacement (radians) and t is time. SI unit: rad/s (radians per second). RPM relationship: ω = 2πn/60, where n is revolutions per minute. One complete rotation = 2π radians. EXAMPLES: Earth rotation: ω ≈ 7.3×10⁻⁵ rad/s. Car wheel at 60 mph: ω ≈ 80 rad/s. CD spinning: ω ≈ 50-200 rad/s. Angular velocity relates to linear velocity: v = ωr (radius × angular velocity).
AngularVelocityCalculator.formulaContent: ω = θ/t (basic). ω = 2πf (f = frequency). ω = v/r (v = linear velocity, r = radius). RPM = 60ω/(2π). Relationship to linear velocity: v = ωr.

BuoyancyCalculator.metadataTitle: Buoyancy Force Calculator - Archimedes' Principle | Free Physics Tool
BuoyancyCalculator.metadataDescription: Free buoyancy calculator. Calculate buoyant force using Archimedes' principle: F = ρVg.
BuoyancyCalculator.metadataKeywords: buoyancy calculator, Archimedes principle, buoyant force, F=ρVg, flotation
BuoyancyCalculator.title: Buoyancy Force Calculator
BuoyancyCalculator.subtitle: Calculate buoyant force using Archimedes' principle
BuoyancyCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
BuoyancyCalculator.formulaDescription: F = buoyant force (N), ρ = fluid density (kg/m³), V = displaced volume (m³), g = 9.8 m/s²
BuoyancyCalculator.whatIsContent: Buoyancy is the upward force exerted by a fluid on an immersed object. Archimedes' Principle: F = ρVg, where ρ is fluid density, V is displaced fluid volume, g is gravity. FLOATING: Object floats when buoyant force equals weight. Sinks when weight > buoyant force. EXAMPLES: Water density ≈ 1000 kg/m³. Air density ≈ 1.2 kg/m³. Seawater ≈ 1025 kg/m³ (easier to float). Ships float by displacing large water volume. Balloons rise in air by displacing air mass.
BuoyancyCalculator.formulaContent: F_b = ρVg. Object floats if: ρ_object < ρ_fluid. Object sinks if: ρ_object > ρ_fluid. Neutral buoyancy: ρ_object = ρ_fluid.

CentripetalForceCalculator.metadataTitle: Centripetal Force Calculator - F = mv²/r | Free Physics Tool
CentripetalForceCalculator.metadataDescription: Free centripetal force calculator. Calculate force required for circular motion using F = mv²/r.
CentripetalForceCalculator.metadataKeywords: centripetal force, circular motion, F=mv²/r, physics calculator, rotation
CentripetalForceCalculator.title: Centripetal Force Calculator
CentripetalForceCalculator.subtitle: Calculate centripetal force for circular motion
CentripetalForceCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
CentripetalForceCalculator.formulaDescription: F = centripetal force (N), m = mass (kg), v = velocity (m/s), r = radius (m)
CentripetalForceCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Mass and radius must be positive.
CentripetalForceCalculator.whatIsContent: Centripetal force is the inward force required to keep an object moving in a circular path. Formula: F = mv²/r. Direction: always points toward center of circle. NOT a new type of force - it's the net force toward center (tension, gravity, friction, etc.). EXAMPLES: Moon orbiting Earth (gravity provides centripetal force). Car turning (friction provides force). String spinning ball (tension provides force). Higher speed or tighter curve needs more force. Larger radius needs less force.
CentripetalForceCalculator.formulaContent: F = mv²/r. Alternative: F = mω²r (using angular velocity). Centripetal acceleration: a = v²/r. The force is perpendicular to velocity, changing direction but not speed.

KineticEnergyCalculator.metadataTitle: Kinetic Energy Calculator - KE = ½mv² | Free Physics Tool
KineticEnergyCalculator.metadataDescription: Free kinetic energy calculator. Calculate kinetic energy, mass, or velocity using KE = ½mv².
KineticEnergyCalculator.metadataKeywords: kinetic energy, KE=½mv², energy calculator, physics, motion energy
KineticEnergyCalculator.title: Kinetic Energy Calculator
KineticEnergyCalculator.subtitle: Calculate kinetic energy of moving objects
KineticEnergyCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
KineticEnergyCalculator.formulaDescription: KE = kinetic energy (J), m = mass (kg), v = velocity (m/s)
KineticEnergyCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Mass must be positive.
KineticEnergyCalculator.whatIsContent: Kinetic energy is the energy of motion. Formula: KE = ½mv². Unit: Joule (J) = kg⋅m²/s². Energy is proportional to mass but to velocity SQUARED - doubling speed quadruples energy. CONSERVATION: Energy can't be created/destroyed, only transformed. Moving car has KE that converts to heat when braking. EXAMPLES: Car at 100 km/h: ~400 kJ. Bullet: ~3000 J. Baseball: ~100 J. KE depends on reference frame - train passenger is stationary to you but moving relative to ground.
KineticEnergyCalculator.formulaContent: KE = ½mv². Work-energy theorem: Work done = ΔKE. Stopping distance proportional to v² (doubling speed needs 4× stopping distance).

PotentialEnergyCalculator.metadataTitle: Potential Energy Calculator - PE = mgh | Free Physics Tool
PotentialEnergyCalculator.metadataDescription: Free gravitational potential energy calculator. Calculate PE, mass, height, or gravity using PE = mgh.
PotentialEnergyCalculator.metadataKeywords: potential energy, PE=mgh, gravitational energy, physics calculator, stored energy
PotentialEnergyCalculator.title: Gravitational Potential Energy Calculator
PotentialEnergyCalculator.subtitle: Calculate gravitational potential energy
PotentialEnergyCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
PotentialEnergyCalculator.formulaDescription: PE = potential energy (J), m = mass (kg), g = gravity (m/s²), h = height (m)
PotentialEnergyCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Mass and height must be positive.
PotentialEnergyCalculator.whatIsContent: Gravitational potential energy is stored energy due to an object's height. Formula: PE = mgh, where m is mass, g is gravitational acceleration (9.8 m/s² on Earth), h is height above reference point. Higher position = more PE. PE converts to KE when falling. EXAMPLES: Water behind dam stores PE, releases as KE flowing down. Roller coaster at peak has maximum PE, minimum KE. Dropped ball converts PE → KE until hitting ground. PE is relative to chosen reference height.
PotentialEnergyCalculator.formulaContent: PE = mgh. Conservation of energy: PE + KE = constant (ignoring friction). Falling object: PE decreases, KE increases. Total mechanical energy conserved.

WavelengthCalculator.metadataTitle: Wavelength Calculator - λ = v/f | Free Physics Tool
WavelengthCalculator.metadataDescription: Free wavelength calculator. Calculate wavelength, frequency, or wave speed using λ = v/f.
WavelengthCalculator.metadataKeywords: wavelength calculator, frequency, wave speed, λ=v/f, physics waves
WavelengthCalculator.title: Wavelength Calculator
WavelengthCalculator.subtitle: Calculate wavelength, frequency, or wave speed
WavelengthCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
WavelengthCalculator.formulaDescription: λ = wavelength (m), v = wave speed (m/s), f = frequency (Hz)
WavelengthCalculator.whatIsContent: Wavelength (λ) is the distance between successive wave peaks. Formula: λ = v/f, where v is wave speed and f is frequency. Inversely proportional to frequency: higher frequency = shorter wavelength. LIGHT: Speed c = 3×10⁸ m/s. Visible light: 400-700 nm. Radio waves: meters to km. X-rays: nanometers. SOUND: Speed ≈ 343 m/s in air. Middle C (262 Hz): λ ≈ 1.3 m. Wave properties determined by λ: diffraction, interference, resolution.
WavelengthCalculator.formulaContent: λ = v/f. For light: λ = c/f (c = 3×10⁸ m/s). Energy relationship: E = hf = hc/λ (h = Planck constant). Shorter wavelength = higher energy.

ElasticCollisionCalculator.metadataTitle: Elastic Collision Calculator - Momentum & Energy | Free Physics Tool
ElasticCollisionCalculator.metadataDescription: Free elastic collision calculator. Calculate final velocities after elastic collision conserving momentum and kinetic energy.
ElasticCollisionCalculator.metadataKeywords: elastic collision, momentum conservation, kinetic energy, physics calculator, collision
ElasticCollisionCalculator.title: Elastic Collision Calculator
ElasticCollisionCalculator.subtitle: Calculate velocities after elastic collision
ElasticCollisionCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Masses must be positive.
ElasticCollisionCalculator.whatIsContent: Elastic collision conserves both momentum and kinetic energy. Formula: v₁' = [(m₁-m₂)v₁ + 2m₂v₂]/(m₁+m₂), v₂' = [(m₂-m₁)v₂ + 2m₁v₁]/(m₁+m₂). CHARACTERISTICS: Objects bounce apart. Total KE unchanged. Momentum conserved. EXAMPLES: Billiard balls (nearly elastic). Gas molecules (perfectly elastic). Newton's cradle. SPECIAL CASES: Equal masses: velocities exchange. One mass stationary: moving mass can reverse or stop.
ElasticCollisionCalculator.formulaContent: Conservation of momentum: m₁v₁ + m₂v₂ = m₁v₁' + m₂v₂'. Conservation of KE: ½m₁v₁² + ½m₂v₂² = ½m₁v₁'² + ½m₂v₂'².

DopplerEffectCalculator.metadataTitle: Doppler Effect Calculator - Frequency Shift | Free Physics Tool
DopplerEffectCalculator.metadataDescription: Free Doppler effect calculator. Calculate observed frequency for moving sources and observers.
DopplerEffectCalculator.metadataKeywords: Doppler effect, frequency shift, wave physics, sound, light Doppler
DopplerEffectCalculator.title: Doppler Effect Calculator
DopplerEffectCalculator.subtitle: Calculate frequency shift due to relative motion
DopplerEffectCalculator.formulaDescription: f' = observed frequency, f = source frequency, v = wave speed, v_o = observer velocity, v_s = source velocity
DopplerEffectCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Wave speed must exceed velocities.
DopplerEffectCalculator.whatIsContent: Doppler effect is the frequency change when source or observer moves. Formula: f' = f(v ± v_o)/(v ∓ v_s). Approaching: higher frequency (shorter wavelength). Receding: lower frequency (longer wavelength). EXAMPLES: Ambulance siren pitch changes as it passes. Police radar measures car speed via frequency shift. Astronomical redshift shows galaxies moving away. SOUND: Wave speed ≈ 343 m/s. LIGHT: Relativistic Doppler formula needed at high speeds.
DopplerEffectCalculator.formulaContent: f' = f(v + v_observer)/(v - v_source) when approaching. f' = f(v - v_observer)/(v + v_source) when receding. Positive direction: toward each other.

PendulumCalculator.metadataTitle: Pendulum Period Calculator - T = 2π√(L/g) | Free Physics Tool
PendulumCalculator.metadataDescription: Free pendulum calculator. Calculate period, length, or gravity using T = 2π√(L/g).
PendulumCalculator.metadataKeywords: pendulum calculator, period, T=2π√(L/g), simple pendulum, oscillation

PendulumCalculator.subtitle: Calculate pendulum period, length, or gravity
PendulumCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
PendulumCalculator.formulaDescription: T = period (s), L = length (m), g = gravity (m/s²)
PendulumCalculator.whatIsContent: A simple pendulum is a mass suspended from a fixed point that swings back and forth. Period: T = 2π√(L/g), where L is length and g is gravity. KEY INSIGHT: Period independent of mass or amplitude (for small angles <15°). Longer pendulum = longer period. Stronger gravity = shorter period. EXAMPLES: Grandfather clock: L ≈ 1 m, T ≈ 2 s. Foucault pendulum demonstrates Earth rotation. Used historically to measure gravity.
PendulumCalculator.formulaContent: T = 2π√(L/g). Frequency: f = 1/T = (1/2π)√(g/L). For large angles, period increases (nonlinear). Simple harmonic motion for small angles.

HookesLawCalculator.metadataTitle: Hooke's Law Calculator - F = kx | Free Physics Tool
HookesLawCalculator.metadataDescription: Free Hooke's Law calculator. Calculate spring force, spring constant, or displacement using F = kx.
HookesLawCalculator.metadataKeywords: Hooke's law, spring force, F=kx, spring constant, elastic force
HookesLawCalculator.title: Hooke's Law Calculator
HookesLawCalculator.subtitle: Calculate spring force, constant, or displacement
HookesLawCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
HookesLawCalculator.formulaDescription: F = force (N), k = spring constant (N/m), x = displacement (m)
HookesLawCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Spring constant must be positive.
HookesLawCalculator.whatIsContent: Hooke's Law describes elastic materials: F = kx, where F is restoring force, k is spring constant (stiffness), x is displacement from equilibrium. Force proportional to displacement (linear). Negative sign in F = -kx indicates force opposes displacement. SPRING CONSTANT: Stiff spring = large k. Soft spring = small k. Unit: N/m. ELASTIC LIMIT: Law valid only within elastic region. Exceeding limit causes permanent deformation. EXAMPLES: Springs, rubber bands, diving boards (all approximately follow Hooke's Law).
HookesLawCalculator.formulaContent: F = -kx (restoring force). Elastic potential energy: PE = ½kx². Period of spring-mass system: T = 2π√(m/k).

FreeFallCalculator.metadataTitle: Free Fall Calculator - h = ½gt² | Free Physics Tool
FreeFallCalculator.metadataDescription: Free fall calculator. Calculate height, time, or final velocity for objects in free fall.

FreeFallCalculator.subtitle: Calculate free fall motion under gravity
FreeFallCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
FreeFallCalculator.formulaDescription: h = height (m), t = time (s), v = final velocity (m/s), g = 9.8 m/s²
FreeFallCalculator.whatIsContent: Free fall is motion under gravity alone (air resistance neglected). Formulas: h = ½gt², v = gt, v² = 2gh. All objects fall at same rate regardless of mass (Galileo's discovery). g = 9.8 m/s² on Earth. Velocity increases linearly with time. Distance increases quadratically with time. EXAMPLES: First second: falls 4.9 m, reaches 9.8 m/s. After 3 seconds: falls 44 m, reaches 29 m/s. Terminal velocity (with air): ~120 mph for human.
FreeFallCalculator.formulaContent: h = ½gt². v = gt. v² = 2gh. These assume initial velocity = 0 and upward is positive direction.

HydraulicPressCalculator.metadataTitle: Hydraulic Press Calculator - Pascal's Principle | Free Physics Tool
HydraulicPressCalculator.metadataDescription: Free hydraulic press calculator. Calculate force multiplication using Pascal's principle: F₁/A₁ = F₂/A₂.
HydraulicPressCalculator.metadataKeywords: hydraulic press, Pascal's principle, force multiplication, F₁/A₁=F₂/A₂, hydraulics
HydraulicPressCalculator.title: Hydraulic Press Calculator
HydraulicPressCalculator.subtitle: Calculate force multiplication in hydraulic systems
HydraulicPressCalculator.formulaDescription: F₁/A₁ = F₂/A₂ (Pascal's Principle: pressure constant in fluid)
HydraulicPressCalculator.whatIsContent: Hydraulic press uses fluid pressure to multiply force. Pascal's Principle: pressure applied to confined fluid transmits equally throughout. Formula: F₁/A₁ = F₂/A₂. Small force on small piston creates large force on large piston. Mechanical advantage = A₂/A₁. TRADE-OFF: Output piston moves less than input piston (work conserved). EXAMPLES: Car brakes, hydraulic jacks, industrial presses. If A₂ = 100×A₁, then F₂ = 100×F₁ (but output moves 1/100 distance).
HydraulicPressCalculator.formulaContent: F₁/A₁ = F₂/A₂. Pressure: P = F₁/A₁ = F₂/A₂. Mechanical advantage: MA = F₂/F₁ = A₂/A₁. Work in = Work out (conservation).

MomentOfInertiaCalculator.metadataTitle: Moment of Inertia Calculator - I = Σmr² | Free Physics Tool
MomentOfInertiaCalculator.metadataDescription: Free moment of inertia calculator. Calculate rotational inertia for common shapes.
MomentOfInertiaCalculator.metadataKeywords: moment of inertia, I=Σmr², rotational inertia, angular mass, physics calculator
MomentOfInertiaCalculator.title: Moment of Inertia Calculator
MomentOfInertiaCalculator.subtitle: Calculate rotational inertia for common shapes
MomentOfInertiaCalculator.formulaDescription: I = moment of inertia (kg⋅m²), measures resistance to rotational acceleration
MomentOfInertiaCalculator.whatIsContent: Moment of inertia (I) is rotational analog of mass - resistance to angular acceleration. Formula: I = Σmr² (sum of mass × distance² from axis). Depends on mass distribution and rotation axis. FORMULAS: Solid cylinder: I = ½MR². Solid sphere: I = (2/5)MR². Thin rod (center): I = (1/12)ML². TORQUE RELATION: τ = Iα (torque = inertia × angular acceleration), analogous to F = ma. Higher I = harder to spin/stop.
MomentOfInertiaCalculator.formulaContent: Solid cylinder/disk: I = ½MR². Hollow cylinder: I = MR². Solid sphere: I = (2/5)MR². Hollow sphere: I = (2/3)MR². Thin rod (center): I = (1/12)ML². Thin rod (end): I = (1/3)ML².

PulleySystemCalculator.metadataTitle: Pulley System Calculator - Mechanical Advantage | Free Physics Tool
PulleySystemCalculator.metadataDescription: Free pulley system calculator. Calculate mechanical advantage, force reduction, and rope distance.
PulleySystemCalculator.metadataKeywords: pulley calculator, mechanical advantage, simple machines, force multiplication
PulleySystemCalculator.title: Pulley System Calculator
PulleySystemCalculator.subtitle: Calculate mechanical advantage of pulley systems
PulleySystemCalculator.formulaDescription: MA = Number of supporting ropes. Effort = Load / MA
PulleySystemCalculator.whatIsContent: Pulley system uses wheels and ropes to lift heavy loads. Mechanical Advantage (MA) = number of rope segments supporting load. MA = 2: half the force needed. MA = 4: quarter the force needed. TRADE-OFF: Must pull more rope. With MA = 4, pull 4 meters to lift load 1 meter (work conserved). TYPES: Fixed pulley (MA = 1, changes direction). Movable pulley (MA = 2). Block and tackle (MA > 2). EXAMPLES: Construction cranes, flagpoles, elevators.
PulleySystemCalculator.formulaContent: MA = Number of supporting ropes. Effort force = Load / MA. Distance pulled = MA × distance lifted. Work in = Work out (ignoring friction).

InclinedPlaneCalculator.metadataTitle: Inclined Plane Calculator - MA = L/h | Free Physics Tool
InclinedPlaneCalculator.metadataDescription: Free inclined plane calculator. Calculate mechanical advantage, force, and components on ramps.
InclinedPlaneCalculator.metadataKeywords: inclined plane, ramp calculator, mechanical advantage, simple machines, MA=L/h
InclinedPlaneCalculator.title: Inclined Plane Calculator
InclinedPlaneCalculator.subtitle: Calculate forces and mechanical advantage on ramps
InclinedPlaneCalculator.formulaDescription: F_parallel = mg sin(θ), F_perpendicular = mg cos(θ), MA = L/h
InclinedPlaneCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Angle between 0-90°.
InclinedPlaneCalculator.whatIsContent: Inclined plane is a flat surface tilted at an angle - a simple machine that reduces force needed to lift objects. Mechanical Advantage: MA = L/h (length/height) = 1/sin(θ). FORCES: Parallel component: F∥ = mg sin(θ) (pulls object down ramp). Perpendicular: F⊥ = mg cos(θ) (normal force). Shallower angle = easier to push but longer distance. EXAMPLES: Ramps, roads on mountains, screw threads, wedges. A 30° ramp has MA ≈ 2 (half the force, double the distance).
InclinedPlaneCalculator.formulaContent: MA = L/h = 1/sin(θ). F_parallel = mg sin(θ). F_perpendicular = mg cos(θ). Effort force ≈ mg sin(θ) (ignoring friction).

ImpulseCalculator.metadataTitle: Impulse Calculator - J = FΔt = Δp | Free Physics Tool
ImpulseCalculator.metadataDescription: Free impulse calculator. Calculate impulse, force, time, or momentum change using J = FΔt.
ImpulseCalculator.metadataKeywords: impulse calculator, J=FΔt, momentum change, physics calculator, collision
ImpulseCalculator.title: Impulse Calculator
ImpulseCalculator.subtitle: Calculate impulse and momentum change
ImpulseCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
ImpulseCalculator.formulaDescription: J = impulse (N⋅s), F = force (N), Δt = time (s), Δp = momentum change (kg⋅m/s)
ImpulseCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Time and mass must be positive.
ImpulseCalculator.whatIsContent: Impulse is the change in momentum caused by a force over time. Formula: J = FΔt = Δp = mΔv. Unit: N⋅s (Newton-seconds) = kg⋅m/s. IMPULSE-MOMENTUM THEOREM: Force × time = momentum change. Same impulse can come from: Large force, short time (hammer hitting nail). Small force, long time (pushing car). SAFETY APPLICATIONS: Airbags increase collision time, reducing peak force. Crumple zones extend impact duration. Landing bent-knee reduces impact force.
ImpulseCalculator.formulaContent: J = FΔt (force × time). J = Δp = m(v_f - v_i) (momentum change). For constant force: F = Δp/Δt. Area under F-t graph = impulse.

WeightCalculator.metadataTitle: Weight Calculator - W = mg | Free Physics Tool
WeightCalculator.metadataDescription: Free weight calculator. Calculate weight, mass, or gravity using W = mg.
WeightCalculator.metadataKeywords: weight calculator, W=mg, mass vs weight, gravity, physics calculator
WeightCalculator.title: Weight Calculator
WeightCalculator.subtitle: Calculate weight, mass, or gravitational acceleration
WeightCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
WeightCalculator.formulaDescription: W = weight (N), m = mass (kg), g = gravitational acceleration (m/s²)
WeightCalculator.whatIsContent: Weight is the gravitational force on an object. Formula: W = mg, where m is mass and g is gravitational acceleration. MASS vs WEIGHT: Mass is amount of matter (constant everywhere). Weight is force (varies with gravity). On Moon: mass unchanged, weight = 1/6 Earth weight. EARTH: g = 9.8 m/s². 1 kg mass has weight ≈ 9.8 N. Unit: Newton (N), not kg. Bathroom scales actually measure weight but display mass (assuming Earth gravity).
WeightCalculator.formulaContent: W = mg. Different planets: Moon g ≈ 1.6 m/s², Mars g ≈ 3.7 m/s², Jupiter g ≈ 25 m/s². Weight varies with location, mass doesn't.

WorkCalculator.metadataDescription: Free work calculator. Calculate work done by force, displacement, or angle using W = Fd cos(θ).

WorkCalculator.subtitle: Calculate work done by a force
WorkCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
WorkCalculator.formulaDescription: W = work (J), F = force (N), d = displacement (m), θ = angle between F and d
WorkCalculator.invalidInput: Please enter valid values. Force and displacement must be positive, angle 0-180°.
WorkCalculator.whatIsContent: Work is energy transferred when a force moves an object. Formula: W = Fd cos(θ), where θ is angle between force and displacement. Unit: Joule (J) = N⋅m. IMPORTANT: Force must have component in direction of motion. θ = 0°: maximum work (force along motion). θ = 90°: zero work (force perpendicular). θ = 180°: negative work (force opposes motion). EXAMPLES: Lifting box: W = mgh (against gravity). Pushing car: W = Fd (if pushing horizontally). Carrying box horizontally: W = 0 (force perpendicular to motion).
WorkCalculator.formulaContent: W = Fd cos(θ). Work-energy theorem: W_net = ΔKE. Positive work adds energy. Negative work removes energy. Power = Work / time.

SpringConstantCalculator.selectCalculation: What do you want to calculate?
SpringConstantCalculator.formulaDescription: k = spring constant (N/m), F = force (N), x = displacement (m)
SpringConstantCalculator.whatIsContent: Spring constant (k) measures spring stiffness. From Hooke's Law: k = F/x. Larger k = stiffer spring (more force needed for same displacement). Unit: N/m (Newtons per meter). MEASURING k: Apply known force, measure displacement. Slope of F-x graph = k. EXAMPLES: Car suspension: k ≈ 20,000-40,000 N/m. Mattress spring: k ≈ 5,000 N/m. Pen spring: k ≈ 100-500 N/m. Slinky: k ≈ 1 N/m. Springs in series: 1/k_total = 1/k₁ + 1/k₂. Springs in parallel: k_total = k₁ + k₂.
SpringConstantCalculator.formulaContent: k = F/x (from Hooke's Law: F = kx). Elastic PE: U = ½kx². Period of oscillation: T = 2π√(m/k). Higher k = shorter period.
