solenoid-magnetic-field.metadataTitle: Solenoid Magnetic Field Calculator | Physics Tool
solenoid-magnetic-field.metadataDescription: Calculate the magnetic field strength inside a solenoid using the formula B = μ₀nI. Includes number of turns, current, and length.
solenoid-magnetic-field.metadataKeywords: solenoid magnetic field, ampere's law, magnetic flux density, physics calculator, electromagnetism
solenoid-magnetic-field.title: Solenoid Magnetic Field Calculator
solenoid-magnetic-field.description: Calculate the magnetic field strength (B) inside an ideal solenoid.
solenoid-magnetic-field.whatIs:
What is a Solenoid's Magnetic Field?

A solenoid is a coil of wire wound into a tightly packed helix. When an electric current flows through it, it creates a nearly uniform magnetic field inside its core, similar to a bar magnet.

The strength of this magnetic field depends on the current, the density of turns (turns per unit length), and the magnetic permeability of the core material.
solenoid-magnetic-field.howTo:
How to Calculate Solenoid Magnetic Field

The magnetic field (B) inside an ideal solenoid is calculated using the formula:

B = μ₀ × (N / L) × I

B = μ₀ × n × I

  • B: Magnetic field (Tesla, T)
  • μ₀: Permeability of free space (4π × 10⁻⁷ T·m/A)
  • N: Total number of turns
  • L: Length of the solenoid (meters)
  • I: Current (Amperes)
  • n: Number of turns per unit length (N/L)

faq.question: Why is the field stronger inside than outside?
faq.answer: Inside the solenoid, the magnetic field lines from each turn of wire add up constructively, creating a strong, uniform field. Outside, the field lines from different parts of the coil tend to cancel each other out, resulting in a much weaker field.

faq.question: Does the diameter of the solenoid affect the field?
faq.answer: For an ideal, long solenoid (where length is much greater than diameter), the field strength inside is independent of the diameter and only depends on the turn density and current.

faq.question: What is the permeability of free space (μ₀)?
faq.answer: μ₀ is a physical constant that represents the capability of a vacuum to support a magnetic field. Its value is approximately 1.256637 × 10⁻⁶ T·m/A.

electric-potential.metadataDescription: Calculate the electric potential at a point due to a point charge or group of charges.
electric-potential.metadataKeywords: electric potential, coulomb's law, electrostatics, potential energy, physics calculator
electric-potential.title: Electric Potential Calculator
electric-potential.description: Calculate the electric potential (V) created by a point charge at a specific distance.
electric-potential.whatIs:
What is Electric Potential?

Electric potential (often called voltage) is the amount of work energy needed to move a unit of positive charge from a reference point to a specific point inside an electric field without producing an acceleration.

In simpler terms, it describes the "potential energy per unit charge" at a given location in space.
electric-potential.howTo:
How to Calculate Electric Potential

For a single point charge, the electric potential (V) is calculated as:

V = k × Q / r
  • V: Electric Potential (Volts, V)
  • k: Coulomb's constant (≈ 8.99 × 10⁹ N·m²/C²)
  • Q: Charge magnitude (Coulombs, C)
  • r: Distance from the charge (meters, m)

faq.question: Is electric potential a vector or scalar?
faq.answer: Electric potential is a scalar quantity. Unlike the electric field (which is a vector), potential does not have a direction, only a magnitude. This makes it much easier to add potentials from multiple charges.

faq.question: What is the difference between potential and potential energy?
faq.answer: Electric potential is the energy per unit charge (V = PE/q). Electric potential energy is the total energy of a specific charge in that field.

faq.question: Can electric potential be negative?
faq.answer: Yes. The sign of the potential depends on the sign of the charge. A positive charge creates positive potential, and a negative charge creates negative potential.

carnot-efficiency.metadataDescription: Calculate the maximum theoretical efficiency of a heat engine based on the temperatures of the hot and cold reservoirs.
carnot-efficiency.metadataKeywords: carnot efficiency, thermodynamics, second law of thermodynamics, heat engine, physics calculator
carnot-efficiency.title: Carnot Efficiency Calculator
carnot-efficiency.description: Calculate the maximum possible efficiency for a heat engine operating between two temperatures.
carnot-efficiency.whatIs:
What is Carnot Efficiency?

Carnot efficiency defines the absolute maximum theoretical limit of efficiency that any heat engine can achieve, as derived by Sadi Carnot in 1824.

It is based on the Second Law of Thermodynamics and shows that no engine can ever be 100% efficient as long as it operates between finite temperatures.
carnot-efficiency.howTo:
How to Calculate Carnot Efficiency

Efficiency (η) depends only on the absolute temperatures (in Kelvin) of the reservoirs:

η = 1 - (Tc / Th)

Multiply by 100 for percentage (%)

  • η: Efficiency (decimal)
  • Th: Temperature of the hot reservoir (Kelvin)
  • Tc: Temperature of the cold reservoir (Kelvin)

Note: Temperatures MUST be in Kelvin (K = °C + 273.15).

faq.question: Can an engine reach Carnot efficiency?
faq.answer: No. The Carnot cycle is an ideal, reversible process with no friction or heat loss. Real engines always have efficiencies significantly lower than the Carnot limit due to irreversibilities.

faq.question: How can I increase the efficiency of an engine?
faq.answer: According to the formula, you can increase efficiency by either increasing the temperature of the hot reservoir (Th) or decreasing the temperature of the cold reservoir (Tc).

faq.question: Is 100% efficiency possible?
faq.answer: Theoretically, 100% efficiency would only be reached if the cold reservoir (Tc) was at Absolute Zero (0 K), which is physically impossible to achieve according to the Third Law of Thermodynamics.

thermal-conduction.metadataDescription: Calculate the rate of heat transfer through solid materials using the law of thermal conduction.
thermal-conduction.metadataKeywords: thermal conduction, heat transfer, thermodynamics, thermal conductivity, physics calculator
thermal-conduction.title: Thermal Conduction Calculator
thermal-conduction.description: Calculate the rate of heat flow through a material based on its conductivity, area, and temperature difference.
thermal-conduction.whatIs:
What is Thermal Conduction?

Thermal conduction is the transfer of internal thermal energy by collisions of microscopic particles and movement of electrons within a body.

It occurs when there is a temperature gradient between two regions of a solid or fluid, and heat flows from the hotter region to the colder one.
thermal-conduction.howTo:
How to Calculate Heat Conduction Rate

The rate of heat transfer (P or Q/t) is given by Fourier's Law:

P = (k × A × ΔT) / d
  • P: Heat transfer rate (Watts, W)
  • k: Thermal conductivity (W/m·K)
  • A: Surface area (m²)
  • ΔT: Temperature difference across the material (K or °C)
  • d: Thickness of the material (m)

faq.question: What material has the highest thermal conductivity?
faq.answer: Among common materials, silver and copper have very high thermal conductivity. However, diamond is one of the best known thermal conductors at room temperature.

faq.question: What is the difference between conduction, convection, and radiation?
faq.answer: Conduction is transfer within a solid. Convection is transfer through fluid motion (gas or liquid). Radiation is transfer via electromagnetic waves (no medium required).

faq.question: How does thickness affect heat loss?
faq.answer: Heat transfer is inversely proportional to thickness. Doubling the thickness of an insulation layer will halve the rate of heat loss.

relativistic-ke.metadataDescription: Calculate the kinetic energy of objects moving at speeds near the speed of light using Special Relativity.
relativistic-ke.metadataKeywords: relativistic kinetic energy, special relativity, lorentz factor, einstein, physics calculator
relativistic-ke.title: Relativistic Kinetic Energy Calculator
relativistic-ke.description: Calculate the kinetic energy of an object moving at relativistic speeds.
relativistic-ke.whatIs:
What is Relativistic Kinetic Energy?

In classical mechanics, kinetic energy is predicted by ½mv². However, as an object's speed approaches the speed of light (c), classical physics fails, and Einstein's Special Relativity must be used.

Relativistic kinetic energy accounts for the fact that mass effectively increases with speed and that no massive object can ever reach the speed of light.
relativistic-ke.howTo:
Relativistic Energy Formulas

First, we calculate the Lorentz Factor (γ):

γ = 1 / √(1 - v²/c²)

Then, the Kinetic Energy (KE) is:

KE = (γ - 1) × m₀ × c²
  • m₀: Rest mass (kg)
  • v: Velocity (m/s)
  • c: Speed of light (≈ 3 × 10⁸ m/s)

faq.question: When should I use the relativistic formula?
faq.answer: The classical formula (½mv²) is very accurate for speeds up to about 10% of the speed of light. Above that, the relativistic formula is necessary for precision. As speed increases, the difference becomes massive.

faq.question: What happens as velocity reaches the speed of light?
faq.answer: As v approaches c, the Lorentz factor (γ) approaches infinity. This means that an infinite amount of work (energy) would be required to accelerate a massive object to the speed of light.

faq.question: Does this include rest energy?
faq.answer: The total energy (E) is KE + m₀c². Our calculator specifically solves for the additional energy due to motion (KE).

de-broglie-wavelength.metadataTitle: de Broglie Wavelength Calculator | λ = h/p
de-broglie-wavelength.metadataDescription: Calculate the wavelength of a moving particle like an electron using de Broglie's wave-particle duality theory.
de-broglie-wavelength.metadataKeywords: de broglie wavelength, quantum mechanics, wave-particle duality, planck's constant, physics calculator
de-broglie-wavelength.title: de Broglie Wavelength Calculator
de-broglie-wavelength.description: Calculate the wavelength associated with a particle based on its mass and velocity.
de-broglie-wavelength.whatIs:
What is the de Broglie Wavelength?

Proposed by Louis de Broglie in 1924, this theory suggests that all matter exhibits wave-like properties. This concept, known as wave-particle duality, is a fundamental pillar of quantum mechanics.

Essentially, every moving object—from an electron to a baseball—has an associated wavelength, though it's only detectable for subatomic particles.
de-broglie-wavelength.howTo:
The de Broglie Equation

The wavelength (λ) is inversely proportional to the particle's momentum (p):

λ = h / p = h / (m × v)
  • λ: Wavelength (meters)
  • h: Planck's constant (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s)
  • m: Mass (kg)
  • v: Velocity (m/s)

faq.question: Why don't we see waves for large objects?
faq.answer: Because Planck's constant (h) is extremely small. For a large mass (like a car), the resulting wavelength is so incredibly tiny that it cannot be measured or observed. For tiny masses like electrons, the wavelength is comparable to atomic scales.

faq.question: What does this wavelength mean?
faq.answer: According to quantum mechanics, it represents the probability wave of the particle's position. It is verified experimentally through diffraction patterns, such as in Electron Microscopy.

faq.question: What happens if velocity is zero?
faq.answer: If velocity is zero, the wavelength is mathematically undefined (infinite). A particle must be in motion to exhibit a measurable de Broglie wavelength.

photon-energy.metadataTitle: Photon Energy Calculator | E = hf = hc/λ
photon-energy.metadataDescription: Calculate the energy of a photon based on its wavelength or frequency. Supports units like nm, THz, and eV.
photon-energy.metadataKeywords: photon energy, planck's equation, light energy, quantum physics, physics calculator
photon-energy.title: Photon Energy Calculator
photon-energy.description: Calculate photon energy in Joules and electronvolts (eV) given its wavelength or frequency.
photon-energy.whatIs:
What is Photon Energy?

A photon is a quantum of light or electromagnetic radiation. Unlike classical waves, light behaves as discrete packets of energy.

The energy of a single photon is directly proportional to its frequency and inversely proportional to its wavelength.
photon-energy.howTo:
Planck-Einstein Relation

Photon energy (E) can be calculated in two ways:

  1. Using Frequency (f):
    E = h × f
  2. Using Wavelength (λ):
    E = (h × c) / λ
  • h: Planck's constant (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s)
  • c: Speed of light (299,792,458 m/s)

faq.question: What has more energy: Red or Blue light?
faq.answer: Blue light has a shorter wavelength and higher frequency than red light. Therefore, a blue photon has more energy than a red photon.

faq.question: What is an Electronvolt (eV)?
faq.answer: An eV is the amount of kinetic energy gained by a single electron accelerating through an electric potential difference of one volt. It is a more convenient unit for photon energy than Joules.

faq.question: Do photons have mass?
faq.answer: No. Photons have zero rest mass. However, they do have momentum and carry energy, which is why they are affected by gravity (Relativity).
